Hobbema Indian Agency

Director
Indian Affairs Branch
OTTAWA, Ontario

I enclose herewith an application for admission to the Edmonton Indian Residential School on behalf of Jackson Peter ROAN, number 222, of the Ermineskin Band.

For your information, this child has been attending the Edmonton Indian Residential School for some time. I would recommend the admission of this boy as a grant earning pupil.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent

Encl. GAL-ehg
27th April, 1949.

Mr. H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Hobbema, Alberta.

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant enclosing application for the admission of Jackson Peter Ryan to the Edmonton Residential School, it is noted that this boy's religion is stated to be Roman Catholic, and under Section 10(2) of The Indian Act he is not eligible for admission to the Edmonton Residential School as a grant earning pupil.

His admission is, therefore, not approved and no grant can be allowed for him.

PP/ST

Bernard Z. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Hobbema Indian Agency

Director
Indian Affairs Branch
OTTAWA, Ontario

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School - Admission & Discharges

With reference to your 753-10 (E-6) of May 18th, I beg to inform you that I will attempt to get the matter of attendance at the Edmonton Indian Residential School checked.

For your information, we do not receive the quarterly reports or discharge forms from this school, and never have. This creates a great deal of work, writing and visiting the school to find out the goings and comings of the Indians from this Agency. Due to the fact that the Indians from the various Reserves of this Agency take their children to Edmonton without notifying this office, we do not have any record officially of who is there. At the beginning and the end of the year, we get a list from the Principal as we have to report to Family Allowances. Despite our efforts, late arrivals usually are not listed and often result in overpayments in Family Allowances.

I would suggest that a separate quarterly report be prepared for the children from each Agency attending this school, and sent to the interested Agency. Mr. G. H. Gooderham, Regional Supervisor Indian Agencies, has taken up this matter in the past, but none of his instructions were carried out.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent
June 7, 1949.

2 June 1949

Director
Indian Affairs Branch
OTTAWA, Ontario

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

With reference to your 753-10 (E-1) of May 28, 1949 in which you refer to our letter of May 20, I beg to inform you that we have no knowledge of such a letter. Possibly you refer to a letter from the Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

We had no knowledge that John Haly Curry, son of John Curry, number 83 Montana Band, was at the Edmonton Indian Residential School. This boy is 19 years of age, and from what knowledge we have of his school attendance, has not been in the school for over a year or so. As previously stated in our 112-6-1 of May 26, the lack of factual knowledge of school attendance is leading to considerable difficulty in dealing with matters regarding pupils attending this school.

We will inform the principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School that the discharge of John Haly CURRY, has been approved.

Yours very truly,

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent
BF NEARY ESQ
Supt of Education
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept of Mines and Resources

Retel Easter Holidays Residential Schools in my absence field agent advised Superintendent Lesser Slave Agency that you agreed release pupils on June 18th stop.

Since request was specifically made for Edmonton and Blue Quills I hope you concur with his action.

GH Gooderham EG Sup of Indian Agencies

July 18, 1949.

Rev. E.J. Staley,
Principal,
Edmonton Indian Res., School,
Edmonton, Alta.,

Donald Avalik

The Northwest Territories administration have made enquiries concerning the above Eskimo boy sent to your school during the winter.

It is thought he should be sent North to Aklavik to attend one of the day or residential schools conducted by the Department. However, before such action can be taken, the Northwest Territories administration would appreciate receiving a short report from you concerning his progress in and out of classes.

You might also comment on the proposal to send him North again.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Rev. E.J. Staley,
Principal,
Edmonton Indian Res., School,
Edmonton, Alta.,

Donald Avalik

The Northwest Territories administration have made enquiries concerning the above Eskimo boy sent to your school during the winter.

It is thought he should be sent North to Aklavik to attend one of the day or residential schools conducted by the Department. However, before such action can be taken, the Northwest Territories administration would appreciate receiving a short report from you concerning his progress in and out of classes.

You might also comment on the proposal to send him North again.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

[Handwritten note:]
Dear Mr. Neary, This boy never reached the school. He is still in hospital at the hospital. Yours truly, D. J. Malby.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Donald Ayalik

Referring to your letter of July 8th to Rev. E. J. Staley, Principal, Edmonton Residential School, in connection with the above named Eskimo boy.

This boy was not turned over to the Edmonton School and is still at the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital. Dr. Meltzer advises me that each time they have had him ready, there has been a break-down in the skin graft. He is under treatment again just now but should not be too long clearing up and Dr. Meltzer feels that the transfer to a school at Aklavik should be possible in the near future.

E. A. Robertson,
Superintendent.
August 3rd, 1949.

Memorandum:

MR. GIBSON

Re: Donald Ayalik

I had an enquiry from the Northwest Territories Branch some weeks ago regarding the above Eskimo boy. The following letter dated July 27th, 1949, has been received from Indian Superintendent Robertson, Edmonton, Alberta:

"Referring to your letter of July 8th to Rev. E.J. Staley, Principal, Edmonton Residential School, in connection with the above named Eskimo boy.

This boy was not turned over to the Edmonton School and is still at the Charles Camsell Indian hospital. Dr. Meltzer advises me that each time they have had him ready, there has been a break-down in the skin graft. He is under treatment again just now but should not be too long clearing up and Dr. Meltzer feels that the transfer to a school at Aklavik should be possible in the near future."

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Director
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Baptiste Mission Day

John and Mina Curry treaty number 83 Montana Band have applied to have the following children transferred from the Edmonton Indian Residential School to the Montana Baptiste Mission Day School. They are:

1. Olive Curry Grade 5
2. Victor Curry Grade 5

For your information this family has two children attending this day school:
1. Jean Curry Grade 2
2. Christina Curry Kindergarten

Another child Violet Curry (Kindergarten) had completed a month or so attendance at the Montana Day School before she was unfortunately found to be suffering from T.B. and was admitted to the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital Edmonton.

Subject to your approval it seems that this family would best be educated in a group at the one School. I would therefore recommend that Olive and Victor be allowed to attend the Montana Day School.

The distance these children would have to go to the school is approximately one-half mile.

H. N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.
August 8th, 1949.

Mr. H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Hobbema, Alta.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School.

The Department approves the discharge of the following two pupils:

No. 0256 - Olive Curry
No. 259 - Victor Curry

BFH:ST

Bernard F. Neary,

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alberta.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

The admission of the following pupils to
the Edmonton Residential School is authorized:

Clara Jackson - Born 5th November, 1940.
Emma Favell (Cardinal) - Born 25th May, 1934.
Elsie Wood - Born 1st March, 1940.
Edgar Sparkling Eyes - Born 1st June, 1937.
Esther Breast (Cardinal) - Born 14th January, 1940.
Maria Breast - Born 9th April, 1940.
Jimmy Jackson - Born 8th August, 1940.
Barbara Stamp - Born 2nd February, 1941.
George Bereton (Giant) - Born 1st May, 1942.
Mary Sunday - Born 19th April, 1938.
Sylvia Jackson - Born 4th July, 1937.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded
to Rev. E.J. Staley, Principal of the Edmonton School,
for his information.

It is noted that the applications for
admission are dated March and that most of the physical
examinations were conducted in April, whereas 4 pupils
took up residence in January, 2 in February and 5
in March. Many of these pupils are well over the age
for admission, and should, therefore, have been in
residence since September. It is hoped that the normal
procedure for admission at the beginning of the next academic year will be implemented.

Bernard F. Beary,
Supt. of Indian Education

cc Reg.Sup. G.H. Gooderham
Rev. E.J. Staley
September 15, 1949.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.

School Attendance - Frog Lake Reserve

The Inspector of Schools in his most recent report, comments on the poor attendance of many pupils at the Frog Lake Indian Day School.

It is understood that there are on the reserve a number of pupils who use as an excuse for their poor attendance the distance of their homes from the school.

The new school as sited will not obviate this excuse. It is considered, accordingly, that steps should be taken to arrange for the attendance at appropriate residential schools of those children whose homes are beyond the legal limit for pupil-travel. The attendance of those within a reasonable radius of the Day school should be enforced in the usual way.

There may be still accommodation for Roman Catholic pupils at the Onion Lake Residential school. For children of other denominations it is possible that accommodation still exists at the Edmonton residential school. Please make early investigation of the accommodation available and of the children for whom it should be arranged and take action accordingly.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

My dear Mr. Staley:

My deliberations on your problems led me to prepare this statement of the potential school population at Rocky Mountain House (Sunchild Cree Band) from which you have received into residence one pupil. To-day I met a headman of the band, Louis Sunchild, who wants to discuss with Mr. Goderham the possibility of sending more of the band's children to Edmonton. Enquiries are being made concerning the time-factor as it is getting rather close to the Christmas vacation.

You may have seen some of the newspaper articles that have recently appeared concerning the aborigines of this area. In addition to the children who appear in the attached statistics there are a number who would be eligible if their parents were to come into treaty. The Presbyterian and Mennonite missionaries are doing some work among these people, and on one occasion I met Rev. F.W. Benke at Rocky Mountain House.

Consideration is being given to erecting a new day school in the Rocky Mountain House area. It seems, however, that your school and these Indians might co-operate in working out problems of the present and immediate future.

Yours most sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark
Educational Survey Officer

DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

Indian Affairs Branch

Hobbema, Alberta
14 November, 1949

Director
Indian Affairs Branch
O T T A W A, Ontario

Re: Residential School Attendance and Family Allowances Payments

With reference to your 80-1 of November 8th, I beg to inform you that difficulty was encountered to some extent at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, Hobbema, due to failure of the Principal in the 1948 - 49 term to submit form I.A. 1069, Admission and Discharges. During the present school term, 1949 - 50, no difficulty has been encountered at this school.

The matter of such reports from the Edmonton Indian Residential School is completely unsatisfactory. As you are aware, this school draws pupils from several Agencies, including Hobbema. Fifty or more pupils regularly attend from this Agency. It is only with great difficulty that we find out which pupils are or are not attending. Within the past year the Principal, Reverend E. J. Staley, has been good enough to submit a list of those in school. However such a list is unsatisfactory, as I have recently found a case at this school, where a child reported returning from the Residential School in June, 1949, was actually a truant since December 20, 1948. You will see that an overpayment for July and August was made and a great deal of corrective correspondence follows.

It appears neither the St. Paul Agency (Saddle Lake Agency) or the Hobbema Indian Agency receives either form I.A. 1069 or the quarterly report, or departmental admissions or discharges report, and never have, from this school. The entry or discharge from this school never comes to our knowledge directly. I believe this quarterly report is forwarded directly to Ottawa without copies being sent to the Agencies concerned which you will see puts no responsibility on the Agencies concerned regarding school attendance.

I would therefore recommend and suggest that a quarterly report and departmental admission and discharge report concerning the children from the Hobbema Indian Agency be sent through this office and that the Principal be requested to complete form I.A. 1069.

(Sgd.) H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent

OTTAWA.

Re: Family Allowances — your file 80-3

I have your letter of November 8th regarding the problem of reporting admissions and discharges of Indian children at residential schools in this province.

The Edmonton Indian Residential School is the one that was involved in this discussion. It receives pupils from the Saddle Lake, Hobbema and Edmonton Agencies.

We have previously asked the Principal of the school to provide copies of his quarterly report to the three Superintendents concerned. We are in receipt of a copy of Mr. Woodsworth's letter of November 14th, file 112-10-4, which indicates that he is still not receiving a copy of the quarterly report. In a discussion with Superintendent Robertson several days ago, it was discovered that he was not receiving from the Principal the monthly report of admissions and discharges (form 41).

I left for Edmonton on Tuesday this week intending to see the Rev. Mr. Staley, Principal of the school, and the three Superintendents concerned before attempting to answer your letter of November 8th. However, illness forced me to abandon the journey and return to Calgary.

I notice that Superintendent Robertson has asked you to supply the Rev. Principal with some No. 41 forms. If Mr. Staley will complete these forms at the end of each month, one for each agency and send them to the respective Superintendents for signature, and if he will supply the Superintendents with copies of the quarterly return, there should be no further difficulty.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Messrs. Robertson, Woodsworth and Taylor and the Rev. Mr. Staley.

(signed) G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,

Re: Residential School Attendance and Family Allowances Payments.

With further reference to our letter of November 8th, 1949, and your reply of November 15th under file 110-10-4, quoted below is an extract from a letter from Mr. Woodsworth of the Hobbema Agency in regard to difficulty experienced by him in dealing with this school.

"The matter of such reports from the Edmonton Indian Residential School is completely unsatisfactory. As you are aware, this school draws pupils from several Agencies, including Hobbema. Fifty or more pupils regularly attend from this Agency. It is only with great difficulty that we find out which pupils are or are not attending. Within the past year, the Principal, Reverend E. J. Staley, has been good enough to submit a list of those in school. However, such a list is unsatisfactory, as I have recently found a case at this school where a child reported returning from the Residential School in June, 1949, was actually a truant since December 20, 1948. You will see that an overpayment for July and August was made and a great deal of corrective correspondence follows.

"It appears neither the St. Paul Agency (Saddle Lake Agency) nor the Hobbema Indian Agency receives either form I.A. 1069 or the quarterly report, or departmental admissions or discharges report, and never have, from this school. The entry or discharge from this school never comes to our knowledge directly. I believe this quarterly report is forwarded directly to Ottawa without copies being sent to the Agencies concerned which you..."
will see puts no responsibility on the Agencies concerned regarding school attendance."

A supply of the necessary forms I.A. 1069 have already been forwarded to Mr. Staley. In view of the fact that you are located so close to this school, would you be kind enough to call on Mr. Staley and explain the problem to him.

Please request Mr. Staley to show at the top of form I.A. 1069, where "Agency" appears, the name of the Agency from which the child comes, rather than the Agency in which the school is located. A copy of the form should then be sent to each of the Indian Superintendents concerned after completion of columns 1, 2, 3, 4 and, if possible, 5. The Indian Superintendents on receipt of their copy of the form will complete the last three columns and forward to the Regional Director for action.

The above procedure ensures that each Superintendent, with children attending the Edmonton School, receives prompt advice of the admission and discharge of such children and can then relay this information to the Regional Director for the necessary adjustments in Family Allowances payments.

Your co-operation in ensuring that Mr. Staley is fully aware of the procedure to be followed in using this form, particularly in regard to children attending from outside Agencies, will be very much appreciated.

Please forward a brief report of your conversation with Mr. Staley at your convenience.

H. M. Jones,
Superintendent of Welfare.

Re: Edmonton Residential School

The Principal of the Edmonton Residential School phoned long distance yesterday to complain bitterly about the possible removal of pupils from his institution to a day school at Goodfish Lake, Saddle Lake Agency. He stated that Dr. Dorey was very much disturbed about this rumour and asked him to ascertain if there were other pupils to replace the Goodfish Lake children, for it was his understanding that the pupilage at his school would be kept up to the number that are now attending.

It is realized here that this institution has been properly staffed to care for and properly instruct 160 pupils. The Principal has employed qualified teachers at the going salary plus board and lodging, as understood. Major Clark's report should indicate that everything in this respect is highly satisfactory. It is obviously very disorganizing and a difficult situation to face in and when a number of pupils are removed in the middle of their school year. I must add also that I had told Mr. Staley before the commencement of the school year that the attendance would be in the neighbourhood of 160 for this year.

I informed Mr. Staley that the whole situation would be carefully surveyed and when I had more facts available I would report to you in the hope that some assurance of correcting this be given either by admitting pupils from other points or by extra financial assistance. I immediately took steps as follows:

(1) The Superintendent of the Saddle Lake Agency has been advised to report on what children from the Goodfish Lake must still attend the Edmonton Residential School. It is our surmise that there would be a few who will be too far distant from the day school and in grades higher than will be taught at it, to return to Edmonton.

(2) I got in communication with Superintendent (a) J. E. Pugh in regard to children from the Stony Reserve. As you are aware, the residential school can only accommodate about 80 pupils and there are at least 140 of school age on the reserve. Surely there are some parents who would voluntarily send their children to Edmonton. Mr. Pugh doubts it but is canvassing the situation. Unfortunately we haven't accommodation for all the children that are not in attendance and therefore we cannot put pressure on some and not on others, can we?

(b) Then I asked Mr. Pugh in respect to the
Col. B. F. Neary.  
December 13, 1949.

to the situation on the Sunchild Cree Reserve. There are 26 children of school age according to the latest report and none of them are getting any education. The Assistant Agent has been required to canvass the possibility of getting some of these to voluntarily attend the Edmonton School. Mr. Pugh will be there on Wednesday to see what has been done and possibly do some canvassing himself. As these Indians are still pagans, I would like to be instructed as to whether we can compel them to attend any particular school. Of the total who are of school age, some will be physically unfit, while others are too old to start as beginners in residential school, and it is my surmise that if we compel those others, they would total about the same as will be taken out of residence to Goodfish.

The foregoing is the only way that I see of keeping up the pupilage at Edmonton. I would like to have your immediate reply to this stating:

(1) If the parents should be compelled to send their children to the Edmonton School from either the Stony or Sunchild Bands, or both.

(2) What alternative you have to offer for the position in which the Edmonton School may be left if a number of pupils are taken out to the day school with no replacements.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies

AIR MAIL

Mr. G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
507 Public Bldg.,
Calgary, Alberta.

Edmonton Residential School - Pupilage

Reference your 110/6-1-2 of December 13

Your letter crossed mine of December 12 in the mail. The Edmonton Residential School will continue to give trouble in maintaining its pupilage. The point which you have raised concerning the Goodfish Lake children indicates that there are some who should not be discharged at Christmas as they will be too far away from the Day School to walk daily.

We can put pressure on the children of the Stony Reserves and on the Sunchild Reserves but in the long run we are merely making trouble for both the Department and the management of the school. If the school were closer to both these Reserves, then we would be in favour of exerting such pressure. Due to the distances involved, it is suggested that only voluntary enrolment be contemplated. The Sunchild Cree Indians, purely from a welfare and health point of view should be persuaded to send their children to Edmonton pending the completion of their own Day School.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Rocky Mountain House, Alberta,
November 30th., 1949

To the Minister... Clerks of Session

The Synod of Alberta

Fathers and Brethren:

At the recent meeting of the Synod, permission was given to circularize the Congregations within the bounds, on behalf of the non-treaty Chipewa Indians who live in the western part of our province, mainly in the area out from Rocky Mountain House.

We are hoping that as many churches as possible will hold White Gift services or make some appropriate collection of food and/or clothing for these people who are in considerable need.

The clothing should be warm, clean and serviceable. The food should consist mainly of the staples, such as - flour, cereals (rolled oats, Red river and the like) tea, sugar etc. Some persons may prefer to make a contribution of money; out of such monies the shipper could prepay the freight or express, and the balance could be sent to me and with it I will purchase food or clothing here. All shipments should be prepaid, as I have no funds with which to meet such expenses.

The matter of distribution entails several difficulties since these Indians are nomadic, and live mainly by hunting and trapping. They aren't localized in any way and are hard to reach. However, the majority of them come to town around Christmas and distribution can be made then. We assure you we will do our utmost to make suitable distribution of your gifts to these needy people. Perhaps the time is not too far away when they will enter into 'treaty' and be cared for and supervised by the government.

Thanking you in anticipation,

Yours sincerely,

H.G. Marsh.
Superintendent of Indian Education:

Non-Treaty Chippewas:

Attached is a copy of a circular that was given me by the Rev. H. G. Marsh during a recent discussion at Rocky Mountain House. Mr. Marsh told me that his contacts with these people are actually few and slight, the "contact man" being Mr. Henry Steffel.

I have previously suggested that some of the children might be received by Edmonton Residential School. We give similar privileges to the "non-treaty" Sioux. Our field officials might use the opportunities presented by the Christmas season to do some recruiting. Louis Sunchida told me that his people—the nearby Sunchida Cree—might be persuaded to send some children to Edmonton.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Pupilage, Edmonton Residential School

Further to your correspondence, and particularly yours of the 15th of December, the Superintendents of the Edmonton, Stony-Sarcee, Hobbema and Saddle Lake Agencies made a drive for pupils to attend this residential school for the balance of the school year, with very poor results:

(1) Mr. Robertson of the Edmonton Agency stated that there is only one family from which there might be recruits but there is a dispute as to whether they are R.C. or Protestant and from what I know of it these children cannot be forced to attend the Protestant School, so no pupils can be expected from that Agency.

(2) Superintendent J. E. Pugh got no response from the Stones at Morley, nor did he and his assistant get any volunteers among the Treaty and Non-Treaty Indians at Rocky Mountain House. It is believed that with some pressure, pupils can be obtained from the Sun Child-Gree Band. The Principal of the Morley School is opposed to recruiting for Edmonton as he thinks he should have more pupils in his Residential School. Mr. Pugh and I are of the opinion that the School is now at capacity. As a result we did not use any pressure.

(3) Superintendent Woodsworth has recruited 2 and a possible third.

(4) As stated in a letter to you regarding the Goodfish Day School, Superintendent Taylor has recruited 2 pupils off the Saddle Lake Reserve and 1 off the Goodfish.

From the foregoing you will note that the total recruited is 6, at best. However, it is expected that a number of the Goodfish children will return and that there will be a very slight reduction in the total pupilage.

Yours truly,

G. H. Gooderham,
Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Edmonton Indian Residential School

Dear Doctor Dorey:

Please find attached a copy of a self-explanatory letter to the Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School. With the non-payment of Family Allowances to children who are attending residential schools, it is obvious that our Principals must be very careful in reporting the admission of children. A great deal of confusion has been caused by our Principals not reporting this information to the Indian Superintendents concerned. The result has been the overpayment of Family Allowances to the Indian parents and when this is discovered, steps have to be taken to recover these sums. A great deal of ill will has been caused and I am sure that you will appreciate the need for this matter being forcibly brought to the attention of this Principal.

Identical letters have been sent to Principals of schools operated by other denominations.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Dear Mr. Staley:

Mary Tomenaguk - Road Island

The Department has approved the admission of the above Eskimo girl to your school. She has recently been discharged from the Charles Gassell Hospital and her maintenance will be the responsibility of the Northwest Territories Administration. At the end of each quarter, you can submit to the Northwest Territories Administration, Department of Resources and Development, a quarterly Return listing the name of this Eskimo girl and any other Eskimo patients who might have been admitted to your school in the meantime. The Quarterly Return is to be completed in exactly the same way as for Indian children.

It is very likely that other Eskimo children may be admitted to your school after discharge from the Charles Gassell Hospital. I would suggest that Mr. Robertson and yourself might discuss this matter with Dr. Falconer so that you will know ahead of time concerning these Eskimo students.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Reverend E. J. Staley,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alberta.

Copies sent to: Dr. Falconer,
Mr. Robertson,
Mr. Gooderham,
Mr. J. C. Jackson,
Arctic Division
Dear Dr. Falconer:

Mary Tomenaguk - Reed Island

This will refer to your letter of January 3, my reply of January 9, and to the attached copy of a letter from Mr. L.E. Drummond dated January 14, all concerning Mary Tomenaguk from Reed Island.

It is our understanding from Mr. Drummond's letter that you feel it would be preferable to send Mary to the Indian Residential School near Edmonton, presumably until next summer when, if well enough, she might be sent to join her family at Reed Island. If this is your recommendation, it will be in order to arrange for Mary's admittance to the Indian Residential School, and this Administration will be responsible for the child's maintenance while at this school. It is assumed that you will examine this child again in the spring, and advise both Indian Health Services and this Administration what action should be taken at that time.

Incidentally the statement in the first paragraph of Mr. Drummond's letter to the effect that this Administration had advised you there would be no opportunity of placing this girl in the Protestant School at Aklevik is not understood, as we do not appear to have any information to this effect. Perhaps this advice was received from some other source.

Yours very truly,

Sgd: R.A. GIBSON,

R.A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner.

Dr. W.L. Falconer,
Medical Director,
Charles Camell Indian Hospital,
Edmonton, Alta.

c.c. Dr. P.E. Moore
Mr. L.E. Drummond.

Superintendent, Yukon Indian Agency:

Billy Johnson:

Inspector Spanton, R.C.M.P., told me about this boy (with the variety of names) who is completing his school-age years in jail at Whitehorse. The offenses mentioned were repeated petty thefts.

It might be worth investigating the possibility of having this boy assigned to Edmonton Residential School. There might be a chance to do something with him there this summer while only a fraction of the pupilage is in the school.

You would have to give the Rev. E.J. Stacy all the facts in the case and get his concurrence before requesting Departmental approval for the move.

C.A.F. Clark

Copy to Superintendent of Education.
July 5, 1950.

Reverend H.B. Gibson,
United Church Mission,
God's Lake, Man.

My dear Mr. Gibson:

You may already have heard from the Reverend Dr. Dorey of your Church that he is going to explore the possibility of getting a contingent of residential school pupils from Manitoba to complete the enrolment at Edmonton Residential School.

I do not wish to seem to anticipate action by the proper Church authorities in this matter. You will understand that my official interest is to get adequate schooling for the maximum number of Indian children with the minimum of expense to the tax-payers and the least possible difficulty to the religious denominations involved. Another reason for writing you in this matter is that I had marked the file containing your letter of April 19, 1950 for attention today after returning from places west of Manitoba.

Reference to your copy of that letter will show you that therein you nominated 23 children for admission to a residential school. At that time you had in mind the school at Brandon. It may turn out now that you will be among those whom Dr. Dorey will request to find pupils for Edmonton.

It seems to me that in finding these pupils we ought to try to give the Principal who will receive them as early notice as possible of all the information possible regarding the educational condition of the child. In regard to the
23 pupils mentioned in your letter I note that you have given information concerning the number of years (or months) that the child has been in school. May I suggest that if possible you add one more item—an indication of the child's competency in English. This may help the Reverend Principal at Edmonton to plan the organization of his classes and may serve to indicate the need for different teaching methods and supplies.

Subject always to Dr. Dorey's instructions, it seems to me that it would be helpful for those concerned to receive a compilation of prospective pupils showing the name, age, sex, treaty number, previous schooling and competency in English. The Departmental officials, through whose offices the formal applications for admission should pass, will probably wish to review such compilations so as to ensure that we are not robbing any Day schools of pupils who can and ought to attend them.

As I do not know what mail service you are getting now, nor the date when a doctor might be available this summer to examine any prospective pupils, I am enclosing a number of application blanks which have to be completed (in duplicate) on both sides before the form is submitted to the concerned Agent for his recommendation. I gather from your letter that you have assisted in the preparation of these forms on previous occasions. As these children have a long journey in prospect, any irregularities in the admission procedure would be a cause of regret.

If it is any comfort to you in attempting the task of persuading parents to permit their children to travel so far, may I say that we have pupils who make the journey from Churchill and York Factory to Prince Albert; likewise from points in the Yukon to Lesser Slave Lake in Alberta; and again from Northern British Columbia by rail and steamer to schools on Vancouver Island. In your area, I suppose, the
most difficulty would arise in getting the children to the railway. I assume that this would be a matter of planned plane-loads and I understand that your missionaries have had plenty of practice in coping with such arrangements.

May I extend my wishes for success in this venture. I regret that I can give it only momentary attention as there are situations elsewhere that are equally demanding.

Yours most sincerely,

C.A.F.C.

G.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

July 12th, 1950.

Mr. C.A.F. Clark,  
Educational Survey Officer,  
Indian Affairs Branch,  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Clark,

Thank you for your letter of July 6th. We were indeed pleased to have the opportunity of placing some of our children in a good Residential School. In past years we have experienced a great deal of difficulty in getting children into St. Georges at Lytton and the Alberni Indian Residential School, although Mr. Caldwell at the latter establishment, has been very kind and considerate of our needs.

We still have about thirty children whose home environment requires that they be sent to a Protestant Residential School, and we have forwarded application forms to parents of these children. In the near future we shall correspond with the Reverend Principal of the Edmonton Residential School informing him exactly how many children we will be sending. I do not think we shall require any advertising material to induce parents to send their children along. We have here the best possible recommendation for the establishment in the form of 3 or 4 former pupils. They stand out among their fellow Indians on the Reserve.

Yours sincerely,

sgd. J.V. Boys,  
Indian Superintendent.

RE EDMONTON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL ARE SIXTY PUPILS FROM SKEENA
AND BABINE AGENCIES COMPLETE PUPIL REQUIREMENTS STOP CAN
SECURE CONSIDERABLY MORE FROM SKEENA AGENCY IF SPACE AVAILABLE

21/20372 AUG JCVAC
507 Public Building,
Calgary, Alberta,
August 21st, 1950.

Rev. E. J. Staley,
Principal,
Edmonton Indian Residential School,
EDMONTON, Alberta.

Dear Sir:

We are advised by the Department that as a result of action taken by the Departmental officials, we are assured that 30 pupils from Babine Indian Agency and 30 pupils from Skeena Indian Agency will be sent to the Edmonton Residential school.

In addition to this there will be 53 pupils available from the Hobbs Indian Agency and 54 pupils from the Saddle Lake Agency.

However, there will be a day school erected on the Saddle Lake Reserve this year which will take 30 out of the 54 pupils from that Agency. It is expected that this school will be completed by Christmas, so that the 30 pupils will return to the Edmonton Residential school in September, along with the 24 others from Saddle Lake.

There may be 2-3 pupils attending from the Edmonton Indian Agency, but we are not counting on them.

In other words, you should have about 165 pupils in September, and we shall ascertain from the Department whether or not the 30 children from Saddle Lake Agency will be withdrawn from your school at Christmas if the day school on the Saddle Lake Reserve is ready and a teacher is available.

Yours truly,

for: G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

c.c. Mr. Robertson, Mr. Woodsworth,
Mr. Taylor
Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

Attn: Superintendent Education

Re: Pupilage, Edmonton Residential School

I am attaching copy of a letter sent to the Reverend E.J. Staley, Principal of the Edmonton Residential School, which covers the points mentioned in your Army Message of August 16th.

I have added the following note to copies of the letter which have been sent to Superintendents Robertson, Woodsworth and Taylor:

"Please try to do everything you can to get these pupils into the Edmonton School promptly in September. You should advise all parents that if their children return to the school the first week of September, Family Allowances will be paid on behalf of the children, for the month of September. If they do not return promptly, Family Allowances will not be paid."

If the Saddle Lake Day School No. 2 is ready by Christmas, should the 30 children which it will take out of the Edmonton Residential School enrolment be accepted into the day school, or should they be returned to the Edmonton Residential School until the end of June, 1951? If they are returned to Edmonton, then the day school will not be able to operate until September, 1951.

for G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

RE: Edmonton Indian Residential School

Referring to your telegram of August 16th in regard to the above.

As instructed, I have advised Mr. Staley that he can expect 60 pupils from Babine and Skeena Agencies. In this connection I would advise that Mr. Staley requests that these pupils do not arrive prior to September 6th as the repairs now being done will not be completed prior to that date.

In regard to prospective enrollment for the coming year, Edmonton Agency will possibly have 4 pupils. Mr. Taylor advises that Saddle Lake Agency expect to send in 54 pupils provided Saddle Lake Day School #2 does not open. If it should open, they will have 24 for Edmonton School. Hobbema Agency advise that they expect to have 53 pupils. This would make a total of 111 from Alberta Agencies.

E.A. Robertson,
Superintendent.
W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
PO Box 70, Vancouver, BC.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

With reference to my letter of July 19th in connection with obtaining pupils for the above school, we have now received from Indian Commissioner Arneil definite assurance that 60 children from the Babine and Skeena Agencies will be sent to Edmonton.

We have also received a letter from Superintendent Robertson at Edmonton regarding the children from Reserves in Alberta who will attend the Edmonton School. This letter reads in part as follows:

"In regard to prospective enrollment for the coming year, Edmonton Agency will possibly have 4 pupils. Mr. Taylor advises that Saddle Lake Agency expect to send in 54 pupils provided Saddle Lake Day School #2 does not open. If it should open, they will have 24 for Edmonton School. Hobbema Agency advise that they expect to have 53 pupils. This would make a total of 111 from Alberta Agencies."
I might add that the Saddle Lake #2 School will not be ready for the reception of pupils until after Christmas, and in the meantime, we are advising Mr. Robertson that the children who will eventually attend that school should enrol at the Edmonton School for the period September 1st to December 31st, 1950.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
August 30th, 1950.

Mr. E.A. Robertson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
405 Post Office Building,
Edmonton, Alberta.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School. Your File 110-23-16

We received your letters of the 21st instant with reference to the probable enrolment at the above school for the coming academic year.

The children who will subsequently attend the Saddle Lake #2 School should return to the Edmonton Residential School at the beginning of the 1950-51 term and remain there until the Saddle Lake #2 School is ready to receive pupils, which we hope will be early in 1951.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Date: July 31, 1950
Time of day: 3:40 P.M.

M.D.
Babine Agency
Hazelton, B.C.
Sept. 6th, 1950.

Rev. E.J. Staley,
Principal,
Edmonton Indian Residential School,
EDMONTON, ALTA.

Dear Reverend Staley,

I enclose copies of Application for Admission Forms for a party of children from this Agency, leaving here on September 7th.

We are very glad indeed to have the opportunity this year of sending away all those children who should be in a Residential School. For several years past we have had to confine our admissions to a very limited accommodation at Alberni and Lytton, although we have always received excellent cooperation from the Principals of these schools.

In selecting the children to go away our criterion has been their home environment. We have been guided entirely by what is best for the child rather than convenience of the parents, with the result that in most cases these children come from poorer than average homes. They are perhaps not the kind of material you would prefer to have, but if your excellent Institution can build them into worth while citizens and give them a chance in life, that is a great deal more than could have been expected had they remained on their Reserves. I am sure we are going to see wonderful changes in them on their return. No doubt it will take you some little while to sort them out, but if there is any information or assistance we can give you regarding their home background, please do not hesitate to write.

With kind regards and best wishes to you and your staff.

Yours truly,

J.V. Boys,
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA. ONT.

Enclosed are Application for Admission Forms for a number of children to the Edmonton Indian Residential School. Copy of our letter to the Reverend Principal is attached hereto. This will explain the reason for the large number of admissions from this Agency this year.

In all cases it was necessary that these children be sent for institutional care and training.

I trust that the Applications may have your approval.

J.M. Boys,
Indian Superintendent.

JVB/pbj
Encl.
September 14, 1950.

Mr. J.V. Boys,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Hazelton, B.C.

GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS

1. Original to be submitted on Form IA 506(C), YELLOW. Copies on Form IA 506 (B), WHITE.

2. Insert Agency File No. and Voucher No. in spaces provided.

3. Designate whether or not a "CREDIT" Voucher.

4. If a "CREDIT" Voucher, insert serial number of Departmental Cheque being accounted for in space provided.

5. Where known, the following information must be included on Voucher:
   (i) Purchase Order Number (P.O.)
   (ii) Encumbrance Requisition Number (E.R.)
   (iii) Whether charged against appropriation or Band Funds.
   (iv) Letter of Authority (File number and date).

6. If chargeable to Band Funds, particulars of amounts, Band names and account numbers must be included in the body of the Voucher.

7. Attach invoices, supporting receipts, etc. to ORIGINAL.

8. If the invoice includes prepaid freight, express or other delivery charges, receipts must be forwarded with the Voucher.

9. All cash payments must be supported by receipts.

10. Vouchers should be confined to only one Subject.

11. For detailed instructions on the preparation and submission of Vouchers, consult your "INDIAN AGENTS' REFERENCES AND REGULATIONS."
R.S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
537 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Clara Bee
Azola McKay

The first two named children are Roman Catholic and consequently they should not be placed in the Edmonton School, but should be sent to the Cross Lake School, which the father requests.

With regard to the other children, I wish to refer you to our signal of September 28th in which you were advised that the Edmonton Residential School had no further vacancies, and therefore, authorized...
you to place them in any of the Protestant Residential Schools in Manitoba where there is a vacancy.

Please let us know what action you have taken and the name of the school in which the seven last named children have been placed.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
The Pas, Manitoba,
September 28th, 1950.

R.S. Davis, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
536 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Re: Schools Nelson House

On September 26th I left for Nelson House and had a meeting of the band on the 27th, 90% of the members being present.

I stated my reason for the meeting and asked all the members present who had children who were not attending school if they wished to make application for the children to attend residential schools, but was unable to get a single application. They stated that they had never instructed anyone to write the Department saying that they wished to do so. However they did say that they sent a petition requesting a U.C. Residential School to be established at Nelson House to my office with Assistant Agent J. Arnfinson, and I have this petition in this office at the present time.

With regard to their petition, I explained to them that there wasn't suitable land on the Nelson House Reserve for a residential school. They then suggested that there was a suitable location at Beaver Dam Lake, about 40 miles west of Wabowden between Nelson House and Wabowden. They said the reason for requesting a residential school was that they had no suitable place to leave their children when they went trapping.

At treaty time considerable discussion took place regarding the schools at Nelson House and the members present at the band meeting requested that we should try and change the academic year to June 1st to March 31st so that the children would have holidays during April and May. This would help bring up the average attendance of all children attending school, as every family goes to their trap line during these two months.
I am of the firm belief that what is needed on these northern reserves is a boarding house where the parents could leave their children instead of a residential school.

There has been considerable interference by both the Priest and the U.C. Minister at this particular reserve. This reserve has received more attention than any other in this Agency, having an Assistant located there, but due to outside interference the Indians are encouraged to press for more and more all the time.

I think it would be in order for me to request the Department to forward a letter to the above mentioned parties and advise them that I am quite capable of attending to the affairs of the Indians situated at Nelson House.

E. Law,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Upon receipt of your wire, dated September 25th, regarding sending children to Edmonton Residential School, I immediately got in touch with Superintendent Law; and he went in to Nelson House by a small plane and had a meeting with the Indians.

None of these Indians wish to send their children away to a boarding school, but they would like a boarding school at home - which most Indians do - so they will have their children near home and cared for without cost to themselves. This request is pretty general throughout the north, and I would take little notice of it. I have written to you under separate cover, regarding an extra room for the day school at this point.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

encl.
RSD/ES
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Citizenship and Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

I have the September Quarterly Return for your school which is being returned for adjustment. In order to avoid hardship on the school we are forwarding a part payment of $8,000 pending the adjustment of the Return.

When forwarding the Quarterly Return to the Department it is customary to enclose the admission and discharge forms with the Return in order that the two may be compared for the admission of new pupils and the discharge of those pupils not returning to residence. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would forward these admission and discharge forms when returning your adjusted Per Capita return.

On checking the September Return, it is noted that the following pupils have been dropped while full grant was claimed for them on the June Quarter:

It is presumed that these children did not return to residence after September 1. In cases of this nature, the school is entitled to a grant of sixty-two days covering July and August; therefore, you should insert the names of these pupils on the September Return and claim sixty-two days for each.

3rd January, 1951.

W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., VANCOUVER, B.C.

Pearl and Peggy MOWATT

Further to my telegram of 22nd November and your letter of 29th. Our reason for sending these two girls to Edmonton last fall was that at that time their mother had been in and out of hospital several times and their father was suspected of active tuberculosis. There are eight children in this family, seven of whom are girls, all considerably younger than Pearl and Peggy.

Pearl was ready to enter Grade 3 this year having passed Grade 8 at Hazelton Indian Day School last year to the satisfaction of both her teacher and the principal of the Provincial High School at Hazelton. Because no high school facilities are available to her at Edmonton she has been obliged to take grade 8 again this year. The parents, both of whom have recovered their health, complain that the children are not receiving a satisfactory education. In view of Mr. Anfield's report following his recent visit there is reason to believe that the complaints have some foundation.

Under the circumstances I feel that it would be better to allow the children to come home.

"B.M. Hobbs"

for J.V. Boys,
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Edmonton Residential School - Mowatt Children

I attach, for your information, a copy of a letter received from Mr. J.V. Boys, Superintendent of the Babine Agency.

It will be noted that at the time of the admission of these children to the Edmonton School, there were reasons which justified this action. These reasons are no longer applicable.

It is unfortunate that there is no opportunity for Grade 9 instruction at the Edmonton School but in view of the Department's comments, no action is being taken to secure discharge of these children.

Enclosure

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

January 29, 1951.

Mr. H.N. Woodsworth,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Hobema, Alta.,

Your file 112/25-2-753

Referring to your letter of January 22nd in connection with Freda Buffalo and the Rowan children, it is noted that one of the children is six years of age and the parents in all cases are living.

In view of the fact that the Edmonton Residential School is over the authorized pupilage already and a day school on the Samson Reserve is operating, it would be appreciated if you would advise why these children should receive institutional care.

Would it be possible to postpone their admission until September, when it is felt that there may be more room at the school due to discharges.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
Director
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept. Citizenship and Immigration
Ottawa, Ontario

Re: Admissions - Edmonton Indian Res. School

With reference to your letter of January 29, file 753-10 (E.6), I beg to advise you that Freda Buffalo, treaty number 342 Samson Band and Joseph and Jenson Roan, treaty number 307 Samson Band are in attendance at the Edmonton Indian Residential school, and have been in attendance since January 9th, 1951.

In the case of Freda Buffalo; she was sent to the Edmonton Indian Residential School by her father who already has had his six older children in that institution. The two who have been discharged and Frank, who is still in school, have attained high school levels of education. He is anxious for Freda to do the same.

This child did not enter school in the fall term due to family problems necessitating her presence at home. It is impossible for her to attend the Samson Day School due to the fact that her parents live seven miles away.

Regarding the Roan boys, I beg to advise you that their mother placed them in the Edmonton Indian Residential school where their sister is already in attendance. The mother wished the boys to start together for companionship, so she states. As the family resides permanently at Pigeon Lake, they could not attend day school here. The family is very large and very poor. It appears to me that the mother is wise in her choice and I recommend her action. There is incidence of t.b. in the family which also makes institutional attendance more advisable than day school, as the boys can be checked regularly at the nearby Camsell Hospital.
I have contacted the Reverend E. J. Staley, Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School, and he informs me that due to recent discharges, there is room in his institution within the authorized pupilage.

Mr. Stealey further advises that 15 pupils have been discharged to attend Day school at Saddle Lake Indian Agency and seven to Rocky Mountain House. It would appear therefore, if I am to follow instructions received from the Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Mr. Goodenham, that we must endeavor to recruit every available child who could qualify for school attendance at the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent
Hobbema Indian Agency

February 7, 1951.

Mr. H.N. Woodsworth,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Hobbema, Alta.,

Your file 112 (25-2-753)

Your letter of February 2nd dealing with the admission of Freda Buffalo and the Rowan children has been received and carefully noted.

The Department agrees with your views that all the children in the Agency who qualify for school attendance should be placed in school. However, it should be kept in mind that the authorized enrolment for the Edmonton Residential School is 153 pupils. Should some serious illness break out at the school or a fire, and the school is over the authorized pupilage, the Department is open for severe criticism. Furthermore, there are only sufficient funds voted to pay per capita grants for 153 pupils in the Edmonton school. If this figure is increased, some other school will have to suffer or the Department might be forced to pay for the authorized pupilage only.

In view of the above information it would be appreciated if you would keep these points in mind when considering future applications for admission to this school.
In view of the information you have provided, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Edmonton Indian Residential School:

Edna Laura Twins,
Jensen Rowan
Frances Rowan
Freda Eliza Buffalo.

Philip Phelan,
Acting Superintendent of Education.
Director
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept. Citizenship and Immigration
Ottawa, Ontario

Re: Authorized Pupilage Edmonton I.R.S.

In order to ensure your instructions regarding overcrowding of residential institutions is carried out, it would be appreciated if you could advise us the authorized pupilage of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School.

As you are aware, thirty-five children are attending this institution as day school pupils, and approximately 150 are in residence.

H. N. Woodsworth
Superintendent
Hobbema, Indian Agency

RE: Edmonton Indian Residential School

Mr. Staley has inquired as to what arrangements should be made in regard to returning the pupils from B.C. points to their homes for the summer holidays, also as to what date they should leave.

The children claim that their Superintendent has advised their parents that they will be returning in May.

When coming to the School last fall, they had a special coach also special dining car. Should similar arrangements be made for the return trip?

E.A. Robertson,
Superintendent.

P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

The following letter has just been received from Superintendent Robertson:

"Mr. Staley has inquired as to what arrangements should be made in regard to returning the pupils from B.C. points to their homes for the summer holidays, also as to what date they should leave.

"The children claim that their Superintendents had advised their parents that they will be returning in May. When coming to the school last fall they had a special coach also special dining car. Should similar arrangements be made for the return trip?"

We do not understand the statement to the effect that the children are under the impression that they would return to their homes in May. As you know, residential schools do not close until the end of June.

Our residential schools in Eastern Canada have always been obliged to keep a number of children during the summer holidays, due to unsuitable home conditions. In the case of those children whose home conditions are satisfactory, we have allowed them to go home on leave, but the parents are expected to pay the cost either way.

Possibly the Superintendents of the Agencies from where these children come made some promise to the...
parents regarding summer holidays, and if so, we do not appear to have any such correspondence on our file.

I would appreciate it if you would give the matter your early consideration and advise what action you consider should be taken.

PP/ST

Philip Phelan
Superintendent of Education
Rev. E.J. Staley,
Principal,
Edmonton Indian Res. School,
Edmonton, Alta.,

This refers to your March Quarterly Return for the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

It is noted that pupils who have been absent from school during the whole of the December Quarter have been dropped entirely from the March Return.

In order to keep our records up to date and to avoid future difficulties, it is imperative that the necessary data on these pupils should be shown on Form I.A. 411, when pupils are discharged from a residential school.

When the pupils are shown on this form, we are prepared to consider their discharge. The discharge of every pupil should be approved by this office before his or her name may be dropped from the Return.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Prince Rupert, B.C.
May 28, 1951.

To the Principal,
Edmonton Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alberta.

Dear Mr. Staley:

Will you please advise by return if your statement to me still stands that you do not wish children from B.C. to return to the E.R.S. next year. In our discussions last fall you seemed to feel that these children would not adapt themselves to life on the prairie, but it may be that following a full ten-month period at the school, conditions have clarified and you may have a different opinion.

This situation should be clarified without delay as we have requests from parents that their children remain at the school during the summer months this year. I would like to have your opinion as to whether you keep any children in or not. The regulations of the Dept. are that if parents are unable to pay the fares, or if home conditions are unsatisfactory, children should be retained at the school. Would you be good enough to write to me at once regarding these matters, so that plans for the coming year may be finalized. I would also like to know if any specific date has been set for the departure of these children from Edmonton and also if the school is prepared to assist with their meals on the way home by taking basket food supplies on the train in charge of the escort from the school. I would be pleased to hear from you regarding these matters.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

P.S./ay
Attached hereto is a copy of a letter received by the Rev. E.J. Staley, Principal of the Edmonton Residential School from Mr. E. Anfield, Superintendent of the Babine Indian Agency. Mr. Staley turned this letter in to the Edmonton Agency office from where it was forwarded to this office with a covering letter which states that Mr. Staley was very concerned about its contents and felt that it was completely out of his power to handle and asked that it be passed on for consideration and reply. He pointed out that he had no money to assist these pupils and had intended to follow his usual policy of sending all pupils home for the holidays and closing the school for the holiday months.

Correspondence on your file indicates that Mr. Staley has been very ill and away from the school for some time. Apparently he recently returned and it is not known whether or not he proposes to remain after the end of the school year. As has been reported by this office and Inspector Waller this school has virtually ceased to function as an institution of education and some definite action must immediately be taken in respect to the manner in which it is operated in the future.

I have suggested that this is an opportune time to seriously consider that it be operated as a Departmental school, but as I do not know what is to be done about it, it is impossible for me to make a suggestion in respect to the disposition of the pupils from B.C. From what I know of the existing conditions I see no alternative but to arrange for their return to their homes at the end of the school year.

Awaiting your instructions.

Yours truly,

G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

07/21/45 JUNE JOUR
To the Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alberta.

Reference your telegram of May 30th, attached please find carbon copy of a night letter, answering same.

I should point out that the sole and only delay in this matter has been collection of fares from the parents of the children of this Agency, attending the Edmonton Residential School.

For your information a circular was received from the Department earlier this Spring stating that due to the cut in estimates, the Department would be positively unable to render any assistance in connection with the movement to and from Residential Schools, of Indian pupils proceeding on vacation. Parents were contacted in the usual way and fares have been coming in during the past week or so. I attach herewith 2 cheques and list of children for whom money has been received. Further sums will be forwarded to you as received, and it is hoped that most of the children from this Agency will be able to leave Edmonton on Friday June 8th.

It is unnecessary for me to point out to you that responsibility for returning these children on vacation is that of the school. Last year the Department did authorize payment of the fare of an escort from the school for this purpose in all residential schools in British Columbia, where children proceed in large parties, to their homes for the summer. My interpretation is that the Department's circular for this year cancels any possibility for such an authority for this year. It is noted in your wire that your school is completely closed during the summer, and that it will not be pos-
unable to retain any pupils therein, during the summer months.

The Department has ruled repeatedly that children whose home conditions are unsatisfactory or whose parents are unable to pay their fares are to remain in the school during the summer vacation. It is also my understanding that the Department pays per capita grants for all school pupils for 12 months per year, thus taking care of the maintenance of such children who are unable to return home, for the reasons mentioned herein.

These matters are all covered by Departmental policy and have been for many years, and I am sure that with your long experience in this work, must be well known to you.

I should also mention that Mr. J.V. Boys, Indian Superintendent at Hazelton, was contacted regarding movement of children to his Agency from Edmonton. Mr. Boys informed me that so far he had only been able to collect one or 2 fares and this would be remitted to you immediately. I understand that Mr. Boys will be writing to you direct regarding children for whom no fares can be collected, or whose home conditions are unsuitable. For your information I should mention, also, that Mr. Boys is in process of being transferred to another Agency and dealings regarding the Babine children will likely be carried out by the Assistant at Hazelton, Mr. Appleby.

It is hoped that this somewhat lengthy letter will clarify the point raised in your telegram of May 30th.

P. Earl Amfield, Superintendent,
Skeena River Agency #168,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration.

DEPT. CITIZENSHIP & IMMIGRATION
OTTAWA ONT.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of June 2nd, under date of May 26th we informed Mr. Boys and Mr. Anfield that the matter of the return of the pupils from the above named school to their homes for the summer vacation should be arranged by the Superintendents concerned and the Principal of the school and it is assumed from Supt. Anfield's letter of June 1st to the Principal, a copy of which is attached, that satisfactory arrangements are being made although some difficulty in financing transportation for some of the pupils is being encountered. I am asking Mr. Anfield to keep me informed of the arrangements made.

Since writing the above we have received a copy of Supervisor Gooderham's letter of June 6th and confirmation of my Army Signal message in this connection is attached. This office was not aware that, as would appear from Mr. Gooderham's letter, the school management was more or less disorganized, presumably due in part to the illness of the Principal.

Normally we would require the parents of the pupils to provide transportation to their homes for the summer months and return to the school in the Fall but as it seems likely that the pupils will not be returning to Edmonton in the Fall I doubt if we can reasonably expect the parents to pay their fare home. Mr. Anfield has been successful in collecting the fare for most of his pupils but as it apparently is quite out of
the question for any pupils to remain at the school during the summer the Department should provide transportation for the others. It is disturbing to note that this school has virtually ceased to function as an institution of education and in view of this it is felt that the pupils should be returned home as soon as arrangements can conveniently be made.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

With reference to recent correspondence regarding the management of the above school, we are somewhat worried about the situation that apparently will develop at the end of the current month.

Early last summer the Principal of the Edmonton School made representations to us to the effect that he would have difficulty in securing sufficient pupils for the academic year 1950-51. As a result, departmental officials communicated with Indian Commissioner Arneil and arranged to send a number of children from British Columbia agencies to the Edmonton School. As a consequence, the Edmonton School has been able to draw its full per capita allowance during the academic year just closing.

However, many of the children from British Columbia come from broken homes, and in the past it has always been found necessary to retain a certain number of children in the Edmonton School during the months of July and August. However, field officials now inform me that it will not be possible to follow the same procedure this year, and if so, we will be obliged to return all the children from British Columbia to their homes, and it is doubtful if we will be able to induce them to return to the Edmonton School in September.
As you can see, the situation is rather serious both from the school's standpoint and ours. It would, therefore, be appreciated if you would let me hear from you as soon as possible, intimating if it is your intention to appoint a new Principal, and if so, the approximate date on which he will take charge of the school.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education

Re: Pupils, Edmonton Residential School,

This office has had an inquiry from Mr. Superintendent Anfield concerning the Department's policy with regard to the admission of pupils from his Agency to the Edmonton Residential School.

In view of the difficulties experienced last year, this office would appreciate being informed as to whether or not the Department wishes to have the pupils now registered returned. If such is the Department's wish, it is expected that we will have some difficulty in securing the return of these children because of the very poor reputation of this school among the natives of the Babine and Skeena Agencies. Although there are a large number of children needing institutional care in these areas it will be difficult to make up the quota of 60 allotted last year. Mr. Anfield informs me that a number of the parents of the pupils who have been enrolled have already requested a discharge or transfer of their children. It appears that unless there has been a radical change in the management of the school there would be considerable difficulties similar to those which arose last year if B.C. pupils are to be admitted.

The Department's instructions will be appreciated.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Edmonton Residential School

A telegram from Mr. W.S. Arneil has been received worded as follows:

"Believe I can supply 70 or 80 pupils for Edmonton Residential School. Please inform regarding acceptable number."

My letter of August 7th, file 110/25-1, explained the situation in part.

The anticipated enrolment for the Edmonton School is 100 pupils from Alberta and a maximum of 80 pupils from B.C. The present seating capacity of 140 would have to be increased to 180 and a fourth classroom would have to be opened.

We are of the opinion that the school can provide accommodation for the anticipated 170 - 180 pupils.

Mr. Staley has been informed of the possible transfer of 70 - 80 B.C. pupils.

L.G.P. Waller,
Inspector of Schools.

Mr. L.G.P. Waller,
Regional Inspector of Indian Schools,
620 Public Building,
Calgary, Alberta.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

We have your letter of the 14th instant with reference to the possible number of children that could be secured for the above school for the coming academic year.

At the present time we only have sufficient funds to pay for an enrolment of 160. As a matter of fact, the authorized pupilage at this school is 153, but we have been allowing grant for the extra number.

You will recall that there was some complaint on the part of some of the children from British Columbia last year, regarding conditions at the Edmonton School. Your own report regarding your inspection of the Edmonton School on May 15th and 16th indicated that several changes would be necessary in order to assure that conditions during the coming academic year would be better than they have been during the past year.

Certain sections of your report were forwarded to Dr. Dorey, Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church in Canada in June.
Rev. Dr. Macdonald of the United Church Missionary Society, interviewed the Director and myself last week, and he appeared to be rather vague regarding the present condition of the Rev. Mr. Staley's health.

I would appreciate it very much if you could find it convenient to spend one day this week at the Edmonton School, and on your return to Calgary let me know if you consider Mr. Staley is able to carry on for the coming academic year, and if the United Church authorities have issued any instructions to Mr. Staley regarding possible changes arising out of your report.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,

Re: Edmonton Residential School

Acknowledging your 163/25-2 of August 7th re above named subject, it is noted that the Department wishes an effort made to return children to the Edmonton Residential School and also that changes have been made in administration that should bring more satisfactory conditions than prevailed last year.

Every effort will be made to set up a positive list for Edmonton as soon as possible. I think it could be safely said that from this Agency we will secure 20 children at least and efforts will be made towards that end.

It is presumed that the Hazelton Agency has been similarly notified. I will work in conjunction with Mr. Jutras as to transportation arrangements.

There is a point that will have to be settled however, in this matter of the 30 children from this Agency in residence in June, so many of these, 16 through their parents paid cash fares to bring their children home. The balance were apparently taken care of by the Department. This action has undoubtedly got around and I would like a directive as to whether or not the Department intends to assist in transportation for pupils of this school returning to Edmonton for further studies.

It is of course understood that new admissions will be charged to the Department in the usual way.

(Sgd.) F. E. Anfield,

Indian Superintendent.

Re: Edmonton Residential School.

Attached please find a self-explanatory letter from Mr. Superintendent Anfield concerning the enrolment of B.C. children in the above named Residential School. Mr. Anfield has made a correction in the number of children who will be available from his Agency for enrolment at this school; the figure 20 in his letter of August 10 should read 30 or 40.

I shall appreciate the Department giving a decision on the point raised in the fourth paragraph of Mr. Anfield's letter. This office is aware that the Department has already ruled that pupils returning home from Residential Schools for summer vacation will not receive any Departmental assistance to cover the cost of transportation. This has been the policy with regard to Protestant children from the Skeena and Bahine Agencies for some time but apparently the action of the Department in paying for some of the children to return home from the Edmonton School last June has given rise to the impression that certain groups were being discriminated against. The Department will appreciate, of course, that the distance involved will make the cost to parents considerable. If the Department is anxious to have this school operate to capacity it is felt that perhaps some allowance might be made in this particular case.

W. S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Edmonton School

Attached please find a self-explanatory letter from Superintendent Anfield, concerning the enrolment of pupils from his agency to the Edmonton School.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
November 7, 1951

Mr. H.N. Woodsworth,
Supt. Indian Agency,
405 P.O. Bldg.,
Edmonton, Alta.,

Attached, we are returning
the September Quarterly Return for the Edmonton
Indian Residential School.

It would be appreciated if you
would ask Reverend Staley to retype the last
page of this Return omitting this entry in the
"Remarks" column.

The "Remarks" column is intended
for entries regarding individual pupils. When a
general remark is to be made it should be made on
a covering letter.

As the school is now open,
Reverend Staley should be in a position to know
which pupils are not returning to the school and
should be officially discharged. He should claim
a grant of sixty-two days for these pupils.

To avoid financial difficulties,
we are arranging to forward a part payment of $5,000.

Kindly arrange to have the attached
Return corrected and returned for payment.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Encl:

Ottawa, Ontario.

Attached please find the following application for admission to the Edmonton Residential School, from the Queen Charlotte Island Agency, Masset, B.C., forwarded at the request of the Indian Superintendent, Mr. J.A. Findlay.

White, Miriam Nora - Band #11-01-159, B.C.H.I.S. # -04
White, Rufus Godfrey - #11-01-159, B.C.H.I.S. # -02
White, Rosalind - #11-01-159, B.C.H.I.S. # -01
Farnell, Daisy Christina, #11-01-111-01 (B.C.H.I.S.)

The first three of these children have both parents living but the father is an unemployable arthritic who is also involved with the police and may shortly be sentenced to a term. The Farnell child's home conditions are most unsatisfactory.

Carbon copy of application is being forwarded to the Principal of the School for his files.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.
