Attached please find the following applications for admission to the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

Adams, Eva M. - born May 28, 1943, Gitlakdamix Band. Parents live in a Cannery the year round without adequate school facilities.

Clayton, Elizabeth - Parents are constantly separated; father drunkard.

Davis, Gerald - Parents are constantly on the move and impossible to get children established in school.

Gurney, Matthew
Gurney, Magnus - Father a gross drunkard and a wife beater. Home is anti-social. Both children should be removed.

Lawson, Ramona - Father living in cannery without school facilities.

Moore, Sadie - An orphan with no home worth the name.

Nisvok, Samuel - Father unable to care for children by reason of chronic illness.

Nisvok, Jonathan - Mother dead, no real home for the children.

Robinson, Everett - No real home at all: child being sent from one place to the other.

Russ, Arthur William - Parents live away from school facilities for at least 6 months a year.
Smith, Murray - Parents domiciled at Cassiar Cannery away from school. Childred refused admission to nearest school (Provincial) on account crowding.

Stewart, Dorothy -
Stewart, Joseph - Parents living at North Pacific Cannery. No school facilities at all.

Tatt, Norman
Tatt, Chester - Parents living in cannery without school facilities.

Gray, Ella
Gray, Jean - Father a hopeless invalid; unable support family.

Woods, Virginia - Father a drunk and home anti-social.

Wells, Gordon & Parents refused admission of child at Sunnyside Cannery where school overcrowded.

Brown, Patricia
Brown, Bertie - Father dead (T.B.) mother unable support the family.

Admission of all aforementioned new pupils is recommended.

In addition to the above, the following pupils who were at Edmonton Indian Residential School last year were returned to the school on October 31st, 1951, and their continuance as grant earning pupils is recommended.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration, Ottawa, Ont.

Your File No. 753/10(E.6)
Dated 12th November 1951

Reference your letter of above date and file I wish to advise that both the Hillis and Lattie children should be admitted to the Edmonton Indian Residential School for the following reasons:

Hillis Children
The father, a T.B. case, as well as the mother live in a small cabin some twenty-five miles from the nearest school where they cut poles for their livelihood. Due to his condition his earnings are not sufficient to pay board and room for the children near a school and the children were kept at the pole camp, and had not attended school since September.

Lattie Children
There are nine children in this family between the ages of one and sixteen years. The father, Dick Lattie, works in the woods, and the distance to the logging camp makes it impossible for him to come home more than once per month. The mother has no control over the children and they run the streets of Hazelton till all hours of the night getting into trouble and making general nuisances of themselves. It was felt all along that these children should be in school and arrangements were made for their admission after pressure from the local citizens, including the R.C.M.P.

These two cases were thoroughly discussed with the local teachers and Mr. Davey, Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., and it was felt that their admission was in the best interest of all and should not be delayed.

In closing I would advise that the Edmonton School has since opened and the Hillis and Lattie children were sent along with the other
thirty three children from this Agency. It was thought that the Department would approve their admission in view of the home conditions.

M. G. JUTRAS
Indian Superintendent

Your file 112/25-2-753

With reference to your letter of November 26 regarding the admission of Herman Patrick Louis to the Edmonton Indian Residential School, it is noted that this child is of the Roman Catholic Faith; consequently his admission can not be approved at this time.

You should notify the Principal that child shall not be admitted to the Edmonton school and if he is at the school his name shall not be shown on the Quarterly Return until you have been advised otherwise.

The Department is reviewing all applications of this nature and when a definite decision has been reached you will be advised accordingly.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Mother's full name and No.: SAMFSON Martha No. 21

Religion: Salvation Army
Does applicant speak English?: yes

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration, OTTAWA, Ont.

Brenda Rita BROWN
No.21 Glen Vowell Band

I enclose herewith Application for Admission to the Edmonton Residential School on behalf of the above noted girl.

Her brother, Segrid Larry Brown, was enrolled at the Edmonton School last year, and they were both being sent this year with the other children for the school. Unfortunately they were late arriving at the station and did not get on the train.

Both these children are presently attending the Glen Vowell Indian Day School, however, due to the home conditions, they must be sent to Residential School. The father is dead and the mother, an active T.B. case, is being admitted to Miller Bay Indian Hospital this month. This will leave no one at home to care for the children.

M. G. JURAS
Indian Superintendent

MGJtbh

P.S. Since writing this letter I have managed to find someone who will escort them to Edmonton at no cost to the Department. They will leave tomorrow morning in order to take advantage of this offer.

M. G. J.

Encl.
December 27, 1951

Re: Frank Clifford Buffalo-Treasury #342
Samson Band

The above-noted lad, born in April, 1935, wishes to return to the Edmonton school. The father spoke to me personally about him, expressing an opinion that he would like Clifford to keep up with his school work so that he might attend the Agricultural School next fall.

If funds permit, I should like to see Clifford continue with his Grade VIII work under Mrs. Dent at the Edmonton school, where there is ample room for additional pupils.

L.G.P. Waller,
Inspector of Schools.

Your file 112/25-8

With reference to your letter of December 20 regarding the re-admission of Frank Clifford Buffalo to the Edmonton Indian Residential School, it is presumed you are referring to pupil # 257 Frank Buffalo shown on the September Quarterly Return of the Edmonton school.

Our records do not indicate that this boy has been discharged from the Edmonton school as yet, consequently it is in order for him to continue school for the balance of the present academic year.

This case should be reviewed at the end of June to ascertain whether he should continue school next year.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
January 22, 1952.

Mr. J.R. Wild,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Hobbema, Alta.,

This refers to the applications for admission to the Ermineskin school for Louise, Johnny B. and J. Archie Lightning and Percy Williams.

It appears from our files and from the membership lists that these children are of the same family. Please verify this.

Our records also indicate that the above-mentioned children were admitted to the Edmonton residential school which is a United Church school, several years ago; yet the applications for admission showed the religious denomination to be Roman Catholic, and that these children were admitted to the Edmonton school due to limited space in the Ermineskin school.

In view of the above information, the Department is prepared to approve the admission of the four children to the Ermineskin school as grant-earning pupils. Please advise the Principal of the Ermineskin school to enter these pupils' names on the March Quarterly Return and claim grant for them from the date of their admission to the school.

Would you advise this office as soon as possible whether these children are at school and if so, when they were admitted also whether they are of the same family.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Your file 112/25-2-753

With reference to your letter of November 26 regarding the admission of Herman Patrick Louis to the Edmonton Indian Residential School, it is noted that this child is of the Roman Catholic Faith, consequently his admission can not be approved at this time.

You should notify the Principal that child shall not be admitted to the Edmonton school and if he is at the school his name shall not be shown on the Quarterly Return until you have been advised otherwise.

The Department is reviewing all applications of this nature and when a definite decision has been reached you will be advised accordingly.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Francis Callihoo - Age 10
Freddie Callihoo - Age 11
TN 122 - Michel Rd.

Confirming telephone conversations,
I beg to advise you that the Superintendent of Education
has informed this office by letter, March 10/52, that it
is not possible for the Department to consider the appli-
cations submitted on behalf of the above Indian children
presently attending your School for the reason that they
are of the Roman Catholic Faith and the Edmonton School
is of the United Church Faith.

The Superintendent of Education
suggests these children be placed in the Ermineskin Indian
Residential School. You will no doubt be seeing the
father of these children shortly and we would appreciate
his decision as to what he intends to do. It is under-
stood he is living in Edmonton and to date has been unable
to find a home or someone to care for these children, who
are without a mother. To date we have been unable to con-
test Mr. Callihoo.

H. N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

c.c. Director,
Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA.

With reference to your letter of May 21st regarding the transportation of British Columbia children from the Edmonton school to their homes and later returning the children to the Edmonton school if this is necessary, you are advised that the Department is prepared to bear some of the transportation costs.

The respective Indian Superintendents should make every effort to collect transportation costs from as many parents as possible.

You will note that we are instructing Mr. Woodsworth to the effect that the children must not leave the Edmonton school prior to June 25 which is the official closing date of all our schools.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
May 27, 1952.

Mr. H.M. Woodsworth,
Supt., Indian Agency,
405 P.O. Bldg.,
Edmonton, Alta.,

I have a letter from Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia regarding the transportation of British Columbia children from the Edmonton Indian Residential School to their homes for the summer vacation.

The Department is prepared to pay some of the transportation costs for the return of these children if it is necessary to return the children to the school at the end of the summer holidays. You should contact Reverend Stanley and ascertain from him the number of children who will be returning to their parents and advise him to proceed with making the necessary arrangements for their transportation.

It should be clearly understood that the Department will not tolerate returning the children to their homes prior to June 25 at the earliest. We do not want a repetition of last year's incidence where the children were returned early in the month of June and reached their respective reserves before the day schools were closed.

When the necessary arrangements have been completed and a definite date for their departure from Edmonton has been established you should contact the respective Indian Superintendents in British Columbia in order that they may be prepared to receive the children when they arrive at their destination.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
I was informed by Mr. Anfield that he has received a telegram from Mr. Staley, Principal, Edmonton Residential School, to the effect that all children were being returned home next month and the school closed until the opening of classes in September. This situation is most unsatisfactory and will put us in a very awkward position in that many of the children were sent to the school because of poor home conditions. As a matter of fact some of the children are orphans while others have no father and the mother is in Miller Bay Hospital. To place them in other homes is next to impossible as many families spend the summer months on the fishing grounds.

I would strongly recommend that some steps be taken by the Department to keep those children in school during the summer months if at all possible.

"M. G. Jutras"

Rev. E.J. Staley,

Re: Quarterly Returns

During the past year it has been your custom to submit the Quarterly Returns, in duplicate, to this office, being the Agency copy and a copy for Ottawa and retaining your own copy in your office. During the year it has been noted that there are several errors, sometimes in name, age and especially Band designation, that due to the fact that your copy of this Report is not sent to this office, remain uncorrected at your end.

In future, therefore, it will be appreciated if you would send all three copies of the Quarterly Return to this office and your copy will be returned to you after it is corrected and will provide a basis on which you will be able to supply a constantly accurate Report.

H.M. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dep't of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School

Please refer to your letter of June 27, 1952, in regard to the above.

I called at the Edmonton Residential School this morning accompanied by Field Agent Robertson.

We found that 32 of the B.C. pupils had not returned home, 26 of them were at the School and 6 are in Chas. Camsell Hospital.

Mr. Staley was absent over the weekend and had not returned while we were there. Mr. Krause, his Assistant, accompanied the B.C. children to Prince Rupert and will return tonight. Mrs. Weatherby and the cooks were supervising the children.

Mr. Staley has since returned and in telephone conversation with him he advises that he does not anticipate any difficulty in retaining sufficient Staff to properly look after the children.

Mr. Staley states that he has had no intimation as to when he will be relieved. While he is anxious to get away, he will remain in charge for the time being.

H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.
July 3, 1952.

Philip Phelan,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration, OTTAWA, Ont.

Admission to Residential School
Roderick Charles CLIFFORD

I enclose herewith, in duplicate, application for admission into the Edmonton Residential School on behalf of Roderick Charles Clifford, an Indian of the Hazelton Band.

This boy is the son of Charles Clifford Jr. and Kathleen Clifford, who have been separated for a number of years. The whereabouts of Mrs. Clifford is not known at present while Mr. Clifford spends his time between Hazelton and Prince Rupert. Since their separation the boy has been cared for by Mr. Clifford's parents. The grandparents can no longer cope with Roderick and have asked that he be removed from their home. The boy's father is far from co-operative and has made no effort to find a home for him. I would therefore recommend that he be sent to the Edmonton Residential School.

Your approval by wire would be appreciated so that the child can be sent along in the special C.N.R. coach which will be returning the children from the Skeena River and this Agency on 1st September.

M.G. JUTRAS
Indian Superintendent

Principal, Edmonton Residential School

Fanny Ridley - bn. Feb. 7, 1940 - Kitkatla Band #063
Parents are separated, father t.B. case.

Frank James Watts, bn. Feb. 16, 1941 - (Kincolith Band
Roger Norman Watts, " Jan. 5, 1949 - (Number 124.
Mother T.B. case; 3 brothers T.B. cases also.

Oscar Max McNeil, bn. Sept. 13, 1942 (Lakalzap Band
Violet Rose McNeil," June 5, 1945 (Number 068.
Anti-social home; father consistent drunkard. Mother keeps child at Cannery with no school facilities.

Cordelia Victoria Gray, bn. Oct. 22, 1945 - Lakalzap #34.
Father is mental case in Hospital.

Patricia Betty Woods, bn. Jan. 21, 1942. Gitlakdamix #91
Parents live on year round basis in Cannery with no school facilities. Wilfred Carl Woods, bn. Dec. 17/39, ditto.

John Russell Clayton, born Oct. 18, 1941 (Gitlakdamix Band
Margaret Faith Clayton, " July 6, 1944 (No. 23.
Father dead - mother unable to support children.

Betsy Davies, bn. Septe. 15/39 - Gitlakdamix Band #026.
Parents live at Cannery most of the year without school facilities.

cont.
Application papers, Form I.A.406 is attached for each child. In view of the shortness of time before the Edmonton party leaves, will you please wire authority to admit these pupils who are due to leave Prince Rupert on September 1st, next.

A copy of Form I.A.406 is being forwarded to the Principal of the School and also to the Superintendent at Edmonton for their files.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

P.S. Application papers for Violet Rose McNeil waiting further medical advice.

These children are at the present time being moved about from one house to another. The mother is dead and the father who is engaged in the fishing industry is unable to properly care for them. Their admission is recommended.

3. Davis, Austin John, age 12, #95 of the Masset Band

This boy is one of two, who, due to unsatisfactory family conditions has been a problem during the past year. The mother of this child has been married 3 times as has the stepfather. A sister of this boy has recently returned from the girls Industrial School. Admission is strongly recommended.

4. Wiat, Clive (Bright) age 11, Masset Band

This is an orphan living with his grandmother a widow who is almost blind. This boy with Austin John Davis, listed above has also been a problem during the past year. There is no home supervision and his admission is also strongly recommended.
Williams, Noel, age 13, #171 Masset Band

6. Williams Larry, age 7, #171 Masset Band

These boys, brothers, have had no adequate home supervision for several years since the death of their mother. The father, John Williams has re-married recently and the situation as regards these boys has by no means improved. Their admission is recommended.

7. Parnell, Verna Marjorie, age 6, #119 Masset Band.

Application for admission in this case is made for economic reasons. The father Earl Parnell suffered an injury which has temporarily prevented him from carrying on his usual fishing activities. The family is large (5 minor children). Admission is recommended.

8. Brown, Lois Rebecca, age 14, #44 Masset Band.

This girl has developed into a problem child, careful investigation of family situation has caused me to suggest her admission to Residential School for a year. I believe the change to Residential School life with its accompanying discipline is the answer in this case and will forestall trouble with this girl. Admission of this pupil is urgently recommended.

9. Parnell, Dolly, age 12, #112 Masset Band.

Reason for this application is simply one of unsatisfactory home conditions, drunkenness prevails in this home and the girl should be removed from these surroundings for the present time. The application is recommended.

10. Collison, Clarence, age 12, #61 Masset Band.

The father of this child is dead and the mother is forced to work to support the rest of the family. Admission of this child would relieve the present economic situation and provide badly needed supervision for this boy. Admission is recommended.
Pryce, Bernice Sarah, age 11, #63 Skidegate Band

The father of this child is a long term patient at Miller Bay Hospital. The step-mother works and the child is left to herself. She is clear in so far as X-Ray and T.B. tests are concerned and her admission is recommended.

Forms have been completed for No. 1 and 2 and are attached hereto. Despite regulations as set out in the recent circular regarding admissions to Residential Schools, it is impossible to have application forms completed on time in many cases. In this particular instance, there is no doctor at Masset or in the vicinity, thus the children will not be examined until Saturday, August 30th when they arrive in Prince Rupert. They then leave for Edmonton on Monday, September 1st. Forms will then be airmailed.

Since I have been relieving Mr. Anfield in the Skeena Agency for the past 3 weeks I would request that a wire be sent to him approving admission of these children subject to satisfactory medical examinations. I will have returned to Masset by that time and he has very kindly agreed to attend to the final details for me.

J. A. Findley
Indian Superintendent

/s/

Mr F E Anfield  
Superintendent Indian Agency  
Prince Rupert British Columbia

The children were taken to the Edmonton Indian Residential School by Medical authorities of the Charles Camell Indian Hospital who recommended their admission and at the request of Mr. and Mrs. George Bearhead.

They are recommended as grant earning pupils.

H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

29 September 1952

Mr. F. Barnes
[INDIAN AFFAIRS]
Principal
Edmonton Indian Residential School
EDMONTON, Alberta

I am today in receipt of a letter from Mr. Philip Phelan Superintendent of Education, in which he advises that the Department approves the admission of the following children to your school, as grant earning pupils:

Stanley GREEN, Number 377 Samson Band
Allan Leslie POTTS, Number 86 Montana Band
Marietta Doris POTTS, Number 86 Montana Band
Laura TWINS, Number 39 Louis Bull Band.

In regard to Phylis Edna Strongman, number 81 Montana Band, they have declined approval of admission and have stated as follows:

"It is noted that Phylis Edna Strongman is of the Roman Catholic faith, while the Edmonton School is United Church. In view of this fact, this girl's admission to the Edmonton School is denied. If for any reason this girl has already been placed in the Residential School, she should be immediately returned to her parents. It is noted that she previously attended the Montana Day School. Under the circumstances she should return to this school."

In view of the foregoing, it is requested that Phylis Edna Strongman be returned to Hobema to her parents as ordered by Ottawa.

J. R. Wild
Superintendent
Hobema Indian Agency

JRW/ehm
October 14, 1952.

Mr. H.R. Woodsworth,
Supt. Indian Agency,
403 P.O. Bldg.,
Edmonton, Alta.,

Attached I am returning the September Quarterly Return for the Edmonton Indian Residential School as there are certain discrepancies on the Return which will make it impossible for us to have the account passed by the Treasury officials and if the Return was paid as presented the school would be definitely jeopardized as many of the pupils who were in residence during the month of June were omitted from the September Return.

Our circular of July 23rd clearly indicated that the school is entitled to sixty-two days grant for the months of July and August for pupils who were in residence during June. On checking the September Return for this school we have noted that the following pupils were in school during June but were omitted on the September Return, consequently the Principal has neglected to claim sixty-two days grant for them: 320, 321, 346, 350, 351, 378, 383, 274, 0298 and 0351.

It is quite possible that these children returned during the month of September and the school is entitled to more than the sixty-two days grant, however, this matter should be reviewed and the proper grant claimed for them.
The following children were entered on the September Return for the first time: #257, 364, 0406, 0407, 0408 and 0409, although we have no information as to who these children are and why grant should be claimed for them. If these children are re-admissions this fact should be shown in the Remarks Column indicating the date they returned to school and the proper number of days claimed.

Please advise the Principal that we are sending to the Treasurer of the United Church of Canada a part payment of $5,000. on the September Return. The balance will be forwarded when the amended Return is received.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Patsy Children, No.46 Hazelton Band

I enclose herewith applications for admission to the Edmonton Residential School on behalf of the following children:

1. PATSY May Victoria
2. PATSY Garry George
3. PATSY Melvin Charles
4. PATSY Kelly Edward
5. PATSY Brenda Deanna

The father of these children does considerable drinking and when intoxicated takes great pleasure in beating his wife. Apparently this has been going on for a number of years. Last week, as a result of a sound beating, she left him taking the three youngest children with her. Patsy has had the school children with him but they receive no care or attention. As a matter of fact I do not know how they keep body and soul together as he has been unemployed for a number of months.

I should like to recommend that the above named be sent to residential school as they are bright children and I should not like to see them lose a year which will happen if they run the streets and Chinese cafes the way they have been for the last week.

Kindly wire approval as the Principal of the school is reserving beds for them.

M. G. JUTRAS
Indian Superintendent

Superintendent of Education,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: The September Quarterly Return
Edmonton Indian Residential School

Dear Mr. Phelan:

May I refer you to Departmental letter dated the 14th instant, file 753-10 (E6) in which it is pointed out to Superintendent Woodsworth that the present Principal, Mr. Barnes, neglected to claim for 62 days grant for 10 pupils which were shown to be in attendance in the June Quarter and also stating that there are six pupils shown on the September Quarterly Return for which your Division had no former information.

From the few records that have been made available from the files of the School by Mr. Barnes and the Edmonton Indian Agency files it is indicated that 9 of the 10 pupils shown in attendance in June were not in attendance or were the duplicates for which the grant was paid; two numbers, 344 and 0351 are the duplicates of the same pupils as were paid on the numbers 383 and 0383. Pupil #346 was in attendance and was omitted on the September report and now has been added to the Register.

Five pupils which were entered for the first time in September, that is 364, 0406, 0407, 0408 and 0409, were actually in attendance for the entire school year for 1951-52; pupil #257 was in attendance in 1950-51 but did not attend 1951-52 and has returned to this school this year.

In the final analysis therefore, the school was apparently paid for four more pupils than were in attendance in the June term.

continued...
The Administration of the Edmonton Residential School during the past school year appeared to have been very lax. At the request of Mr. Barnes a report is being made by our Treasury Auditor and his report will shortly be available.

I must record the fact that pupils at this school come from three Agencies in British Columbia and four Agencies in Alberta. As all reports and returns are submitted for signature of Superintendent of the Edmonton Indian Agency, Mr. Woodsworth, it is next to impossible for him to check and as a result he must rely on the accuracy of the return as submitted by the Principal of the School.

Yours very truly,

G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Mr. J.H. Wild,

Further to our letter of September 24th regarding the admission of Phyllis Edna Strongman to the Edmonton Indian Residential School, attached is a copy of a letter recently received from Superintendent H.M. Woodsworth regarding this family.

Please advise on what grounds this pupil's family was indicated to be Roman Catholic on the application dated September 2nd for admission as Mr. Woodsworth's letter would seem to indicate that this family is protestant.

An immediate reply would be appreciated.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Sept. 24, 1952

Mr. J. B. Wild,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Hobbema, Alberta.

With reference to your letter of September 18, the Department approves the admission of the children, except Phyllis Edna Strongman to the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

It is noted that Phyllis Edna Strongman is of the Roman Catholic faith, while the Edmonton School is United Church. In view of this fact this girl's admission to the Edmonton School is denied. If for any reason this girl has already been placed in the Residential School, she should be immediately returned to her parents. It is noted that she previously attended the Montana Day School. Under the circumstances she should return to this school.

Please advise.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
DEPARTMENT OF CITIZENSHIP AND IMMIGRATION
Indian Affairs Branch
Edmonton Agency

403 Post Office Bldg.,
EDMONTON, Alberta.
November 19, 1952.

Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School
Pupil No. 0393 Edna (Phyllis) Strongman
Montana Indian Reserve

With reference to your 753-10 (E6) letter of November 12, 1952, the Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School, Mr. F. Barnes, was advised that you have disallowed the thirty day grant for the above mentioned Indian child.

Mr. Barnes informs me that Edna (Phyllis) was brought into the school by the United Church Missionary, Mr. Kay, of Hobbema along with other pupils for admission from that Agency September 4, 1952. Your instructions to Mr. J.R. Wild, Supt., Hobbema Indian Agency, were carried out according to Mr. Barnes under protest and Phyllis was removed from the Edmonton Indian Residential School October 4, 1952, when her mother Emily Strongman came and escorted her home.

The removal of this child from the Edmonton Indian Residential School according to information presented to this office by Mr. Barnes and Protestant Missionaries at Hobbema appears contrary to the wishes of Mrs. Strongman. According to these missionaries Mrs. Strongman has never been a Roman Catholic and does not wish to be so listed, or have her children so listed. The following facts were reported which are for your information:

"John Strongman and Emily Littlepoplar were united in marriage December 19, 1939, in the manse of the United Church in Hobbema. Reverend A.J. Law and Reverend J.F. Woodsworth were officiating Ministers."

cont'd..
The above were married by Ranne. Witnesses were Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Louis of Hobbema.

Evidently of recent months John Strongman separated himself from Emily and has taken a common-law wife, unknown to this Agency, and it has been reported that Emily is seeking support from John for her children. Accompanied by her father Fred Littlepoplar, Councillor Samson Band, Emily has taken steps to have her husband support the children and also to have her name placed on the Protestant list and that of Edna (Phyllis) in particular. Evidently all her children are in her custody. I gathered this support and definition of religious status is being sought through a legal firm in Wetaskiwin.

If the religious status of Edna (Phyllis) is ruled as Protestant by the Department, it is hoped the Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School will receive the thirty day per capita grant resulting from the presence of Edna (Phyllis) at the school.

H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

Dear Mr. Findley:

Re: Rose White and Lois Brown

I am sorry to have to dismiss these two girls from my School but it seemed the only course open to the Matron and myself under the circumstances, since they have been at this School they have shown at times a spirit of rebellion to rules and regulations as well as a lack of respect and courtesy to various staff members.

Recently they have been involved in having some boys come to their dormitory during the night. I hope something can be done for them but this school is not a place of correction such as they require.

Two Alberta boys were sent home yesterday and one or two more may have to go today as well as a girl or two. The whole matter is not yet settled.

In future I wonder if you could screen your students a little more closely when they have so far to come? I had travel warrants issued for their passage to Prince Rupert and have wired Mr. Anfield to have them met there tomorrow evening and sent on to Masset.

Yours sincerely,

"F. Barnes"
Principal
Queen Charlotte Agency.

Masset, B.C.,
Nov. 12, 1952.

Mr. F. Barnes, B.SC., B.Ed.,
Edmonton Indian Residential School,
Box 186,
Edmonton, Alberta.

It was with some surprise that I received a phone call from Mr. Anfield advising me of the return home of Rosie White and Lois Brown. These girls had not been particularly troublesome at other schools or at home. Rosie was spending her second year at Edmonton and it was our belief that she was completely settled and happy.

I am beginning to be of the opinion that the Dolly Farnell case had some bearing on these two. It may be that they saw the opportunity of also being sent home if they misbehaved.

I do not wish to appear critical of your actions, since I appreciate quite well the problems with which you have to contend. I trust there will be no more trouble but would ask that should the unforeseen happen, that you forward me a report before taking action in sending pupils home. Due to distance and difficulties involved in travel it makes it most inconvenient if we are advised after the action has been taken. I seriously request this consideration.

While appreciating your statements regarding the school not being a place of correction, I suggest that as far as pupils from this Agency are concerned, they are not sent with that purpose in mind. However, as you will I am sure agree strict discipline in many of these cases is not out of the way.

c.c. Mr. Anfield

J.A. Findley,
Agency Superintendent,

JAP/da
Queen Charlotte Agency,

Dec. 17, 1952.

Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.

I wish to acknowledge your letter dated Dec. 10, 1952, File 167/27-8(E) with regards to transportation Warrant T 10578 issued to Queen Charlotte Airlines for Lois Brown and Rosie White of Masset Band.

These girls were returned home from Edmonton Residential School. I have attached a copy of a letter from Mr. Barnes as well as a copy of my reply in this connection.

Earlier in the term a Masset girl, Dolly Parnell, was sent home and being advised ahead of time we were in accord with the proposed action.

However, the first intimation of the return of the two girls, was a phone call from Mr. Anfield that he had received a wire to the effect that they were on their way to Prince Rupert. He had no previous knowledge of the matter either.

Both Mr. Anfield and I agree that despite reasons, we should be notified of any such proposed action ahead of time in order that we may consult and consider the matter. Hasty action in sending pupils home may not be the answer to school problems which arise.

From Mr. Barnes' letter it appears that there had been considerable trouble at the school with, as he states, several others involved. The two girls in question have never been troublesome before and in Rosie's case this was her second consecutive year at the school. She, a brother and younger sister even remained there during the summer months and letters to her mother indicated they were quite happy. Incidentally the father of these children has been in and out of jail several times over the past few years.
When Mr. Anfield phoned me about the girls' return, it was too late to take steps to at least delay the action and a warrant was issued for them to return to Masset. If they had waited in Prince Rupert until our regular steamer, it would have involved 10 days room and board.

J.A. Findlay,
Agency Superintendent.

Edmonton Indian Res. School,
Edmonton, Alta.,

Dear Mr. Barnes:

I have recently been informed that a number of Indian children have been expelled from the Edmonton Indian Residential School. Our records do not indicate any report or comments received from you regarding these cases. In one instance, the Indian Superintendent advised that two of the girls from his Agency were expelled from the Edmonton Residential School. As these girls had never been troublesome before and as they had been in the Edmonton school for two years he felt they were well established in their academic studies.

It is the Department's policy to be fair to both the Indian Superintendent and the Principal in that we are anxious to assist the Principal in the management of the residential school and often children who are in a residential school have no home to go to and it is often difficult for the Indian Superintendent to arrange for the children's keep when they leave a residential school.

As this Branch is responsible for all children attending residential schools, it is essential that no pupils be discharged or expelled from a residential school until authority has been obtained from the Department.
As our records are very sketchy regarding the expulsion of pupils from the Edmonton Residential School during the present academic year, it would be appreciated if you would forward this office a full report indicating the names of the pupils expelled, the reason for their expulsion and the Agency where the children have been returned.

It is possible that we will receive inquiries regarding this matter and it would be appreciated if you would forward this report as soon as possible and give complete details.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

December 31, 1952.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education,
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

In reply to your letter of 26 inst. #753-10 re expulsion of four children from this School may I say that it comes to me rather as a shock. I note in previous records where children have been dismissed by both my predecessors at their discretion. In fact, one of the children which was dismissed had previously been dismissed by Mr. Staley without permission. It is difficult to understand why a Principal with my experience and qualifications should not have the same prerogative.

Four children were dismissed Nov. 5 and 6. They were: Rose White and Lois Brown of Masset; Francis Buffalo, Hobbsma and Francis Makokis Saddle Lake. I am sorry that you did not write about this as it would have showed up in my December Return.

When I arrived here the acting Matron complained that Rose White was a bad influence in the School and that she swore at her when corrected. I talked to Rose and she promised to do better. In September, Miss MacDonald came as Matron and Mrs. McIlwraith as assistant. Both of these ladies have years of experience with Indian children. Before a month was up both of these ladies complained that Rose White and Lois Brown were a bad influence in the School and incorrigible. In spite of this they talked with them and tried to influence them for the better.

Late in October we found that two of the girls and some of the boys had become involved in promiscuous relations and had broken the rules of the School by the girls inviting the boys up to their dormitory at night and letting them in the fire-escape door. The girls were to blame, of course, for going. By this time Miss MacDonald had to know that action had to be taken at once so we decided to send home the ring-leaders. She picked the two girls and I picked the two boys. If the Masset Agency is not happy with regard to our actions then I am sorry but we had to keep Alberta children out of the School this Fall because of no room so it might be best if no Masset children were sent to the school. I know that I would wish a Principal of mine to act likewise if I were in my former position of Inspector of Schools and had a Principal in charge of a dormitory housing both boys and girls. The final visit was made on November 4 so then we acted immediately. I cannot and will not tolerate such behavior in any school or which I am in charge.

If I have been wrong in what I have done it is only because of ignorance since I have only been in the Indian Service for five months but I have acted as I felt you would wish me to under the circumstances. Please do not forget that Ottawa is a long distance from here and we must be given some opportunity to use our own judgment or the Schools cannot operate efficiently. I have understood that the Schools operated under the School Act of each respective Province. If I am wrong in this please advise. The Alberta Act states that a Principal shall dismiss any
January 8th, 1953.

Mr. Findlay Barnes, B.Sc., B.Ed.,
Principal,
Edmonton Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alberta.

Dear Mr. Barnes:

I wish to thank you for your letter of December 31st and I regret that this has caused you so much concern.

The department understands the many difficulties presented in endeavouring to operate a residential school, and wishes to be helpful and to support our principals wherever possible. I appreciate that in many cases we must accept the recommendation of the principal and our field staff. However, the department has a responsibility to the children and their parents, as well as the Superintendent of the Agency to which they belong, and for this reason the department requires that the Superintendent of the Indian Agency be consulted, wherever possible, before a child is expelled and that the principal submit a report immediately following any action taken.

I note that you have made reference to the Alberta Act with respect to the responsibilities of a principal concerning discipline. The 1952 revision of the Act, Section 366, reads as follows:

"(1) A teacher may suspend from a class or from school a pupil who is guilty of open opposition to authority, wilful disobedience, habitual neglect of duty, the use of profane or improper language, or other conduct injurious to the moral tone or well-being of the school."
(2) The teacher shall report any suspension immediately to the principal if in a graded school.

(3) The principal of the school, or the teacher in the event of there being no principal, shall—

(a) prepare forthwith a written report of the suspension setting out all the circumstances; and

(b) send the report—

(i) to the board by which the teacher is employed; and

(ii) to the superintendent, if any; and

(iii) to the attendance officer.

(4) The board may take such action as it deems necessary with regard thereto.*

The policy of the department in requiring principals to report immediately and not to take hasty action without receiving full information concerning all the circumstances, is in keeping with the spirit of the Alberta Act.

I believe the reason for this requirement will be apparent when you know that it is the department's policy to give priority to the admission to residential schools of children whose home conditions are unsatisfactory. For this reason, among your pupilage there will be many children from broken homes, children who are orphaned and other underprivileged children whose discharge from the residential school presents considerable difficulties to the Superintendent of the Indian Agency concerned. In the case of Rose White, for example, her home conditions were so unsatisfactory that she had to remain at Edmonton during the past summer holidays. The sudden unexpected return of a pupil such as this may mean that she has to be returned to these unsatisfactory home circumstances, or that the Superintendent has no home for her. It is not the policy of the department to use our residential schools as institutions for correction, but we do wish them to
serve pupils who, if left in their home environment, are likely to run into difficulties with the law. The department agrees that a principal cannot permit one or two pupils to undermine the discipline of his school, but before action is taken, there should be consultation with officials knowing the home circumstances. In some cases the use of the long distance telephone would certainly be warranted.

It is noted that the boys gained admission to the girls' dormitory through the fire escape door. This, of course, must not be locked, but this occurrence could be prevented by the placement on the door of a simple switch to close a battery-operated alarm system when the door is opened. The bell should be located in the Supervisor's room or where the opening of the door would be signalled to the staff.

May I say that I appreciate the frankness with which you wrote to me and the motives which led you to enter the service of our Indian people. I have learned of some improvements which you have already instituted at Edmonton, and I wish to assure you that the department values the contribution which you have already made through these to the cause of Indian education.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education
January 20, 1953.

Mr. H.H. Woodsworth,
Supt. Indian Agency,
405 P.O. Bldg.,
Edmonton, Alta.,

With reference to your letter of December 24th regarding the admission of Norman Adams to the Edmonton Indian Residential School, please be advised that as the school to which other children of this family should attend is under dispute no action can be taken on the application for Norman Adams.

When the school to which the Adams children should attend is designated you will be advised accordingly and Norman Adams may be placed in that school at that time. In the meantime, no action should be taken on placing him in any school.

Philip Phelan,

Application is made to admit Grace Faith Mokey, born March 8, 1942, Lekelzep Band #056, to the Edmonton Residential School immediately.

A year ago this child was seriously burned and has been hospitalized ever since. She came perilously close to death and required many skin grafts to pull her through. The doctor has certified that she must be close to medical supervision for some time to come, and that as she has no mother and her father is indigent, she must be kept in a home until it is possible to get her into School. In December the hospital demanded her discharge at once and as we had no word of any vacancy we placed her locally with a woman in Prince Rupert who has kept her. We now have word from Edmonton Residential School that they can take her in. We also have word from Miller Bay Hospital of an escort going to Edmonton at the end of January. Permission is requested to send her to Edmonton on a Travel Warrant as a grant earning patient. Form I.A.406 is attached. May I be advised at once if her admission is approved.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

Re: Norman Adams, TN 135 Paul's Bd.

With reference to your file 753-10 (E6), letter January 20, 1953.

I beg to advise you that Norman Adams is in the Edmonton Indian Residential School. He was placed there with his two brothers by the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital. The grandmother was unable to care for the children and the mother was in the Camsell Hospital with T.B., as was Norman for sometime and until December 1952. The three children in the Edmonton Indian Residential School would have faced serious problems regarding care and the action of the Charles Camsell Hospital is appreciated.

Mr. F. Barnes, Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School took Norman knowing of the dispute over religious status. His action prevented the child being completely neglected. As you are aware the father and grandmother wish the children to attend the Edmonton Indian Residential School, the mother evidently opposes this.

I recommend there is no other solution at the moment than leave Norman in the Edmonton Indian Residential School and, or, until the religious dispute is settled.

H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

With reference to the December Quarterly Return for the Edmonton Indian Residential School, it is noted on checking the Return that the Principal has made several errors due to the fact that he is not familiar with the preparation of the Quarterly Return. It is our intention to bring certain facts to his attention for his guidance when preparing future Returns.

Form I.A. 411 which accompanies every Quarterly Return should include the names of pupils who were not on previous Quarterly Returns, and it is intended to drop from future Quarterly Returns. During the Quarter there usually are a number of children who enter the residential school for the first time. The practice has been to add the names of these children at the end of the Quarterly Return under the girls and boys section as the case may be and include their names on Form I.A. 411. It is often decided during the Quarter that certain children should be discharged from the school but grant should be claimed for the quarter for which the Return is prepared; consequently these children are usually entered on Form I.A. 411 under the discharged group and their names are included on the Quarterly Return and grant claimed for them for the period they were in school during the Quarter. These children's names will be omitted from future Quarterly Returns.
On checking the December Return for the Edmonton School, it is noted that the Principal has included on Form I.A. 411 a number of children who were absent during part of the September Quarter and returned to school during the December Quarter. Please advise the Principal that it is not necessary to show the names of those children on Form I.A. 411. We are returning Form I.A. 411 for the necessary changes. It is necessary that the Principal insert the pupils' register numbers in all cases on the Return and on Form I.A. 411.

In several instances it is noted that the children were absent from residence for hospitalization, attending a funeral or other reasons. In such cases, the Principal must indicate the reason for absence and the date the pupil left the school and later returned to school.

With reference to pupil # 0356, the Principal has claimed thirty-one days grant and has indicated "hospitalized last of September". We have disallowed the grant as it is not clear the date this pupil was admitted to hospital. If the school is entitled to grant for this pupil, the Principal may claim grant for her on the March Return.

Please advise the Principal that he has made an error in addition on Page 3. The total for this page should have read 7320 rather than 5438. Please advise the Principal that we are allowing the grant based on our figures.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Edna Phyllis Strongman

This family is from the Hobbema Agency in the Province of Alberta.

Attached (marked "A") is an application signed by the mother requesting the admission of this girl to the Edmonton U.C. Indian Residential School. The application states that the family is of the Roman Catholic Faith. Mr. and Mrs. John Strongman were married in 1939 in the Manse of the United Church in Hobbema (Marriage Certificate marked "B" is attached).

Superintendent Wild states:

"In recent months John Strongman deserted his wife Emily and has taken on a common-law wife. This person is not known by the Hobbema Agency. It has been reported that Emily is seeking support from John for her children. Accompanied by her father, Fred Littlepoplar, Councillor, Sampson Band, Emily has taken steps to have her husband support the children and also to have her name placed on the Protestant list and that of Edna Phyllis in particular. Evidently all her children are in her custody."
Edna Phyllis was baptized a Roman Catholic (Certificate of Baptism marked "C" is attached). The mother was baptized in the United Church Faith, (Certificate of Baptism marked "D" is attached). Regarding the father's religious connections Superintendent Wild states:

1. The parents of John Strongman are listed as Roman Catholic.

2. John Strongman is listed as Roman Catholic.

It would be appreciated if a ruling were given on Mrs. Strongman's request that her child be placed in the Edmonton U.C. Indian Residential School.

Director.

Attach:

MFT/HD
COPY

Ottawa, February 19, 1953.

MEMORANDUM TO MAJOR MACKAY:

Reference your memorandum of February 11th, 1953, concerning Edna Phyllis Strongman, whose mother has applied for admission to the Edmonton U.C. Indian Residential School.

It is noted that, although the father is stated to be of the Roman Catholic faith, the marriage was performed before a U.C. Minister. Consequently, it cannot be said in this case that the mother, before marriage, would have agreed to educate her children in the Roman Catholic faith. No explanation is being given on the circumstances under which this child was baptised by the Roman Catholic Church. The father having deserted his wife, it would appear that the responsible parent is the mother who is not of the Roman Catholic faith and, consequently, I am of the opinion that the request of the mother for the admission of her daughter to the Edmonton U.C. Indian Residential School should be approved.

(Sgd) Laval Fortier.
REGISTERED MAIL

February 20, 1953

Mr. J.R. Wild,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Hobbema, Alta.,

Please be advised that it has been ruled that Phyllis Edna Strongman may be admitted as a grant-earning pupil at the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

Please arrange to have this girl placed in the above-mentioned school and instruct the Principal that he may claim grant for her from the date she entered the school.

Attached, I am returning Certificates of Baptism for Phyllis Edna Strongman, Emily Little Poplar and Registration of Marriage for John Strongman and Emily Little Poplar. These documents have served their purpose and should be returned to their owners.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Mr. Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir,

Re: your letter 753-10 (E6) Feb. 3rd, 1953

1.- It is to be noted that the name Paul Adams has been registered as Paul Paul when married.

2.- It was impossible to locate any Church Documents from the Rocky Mountain House Church; nevertheless we had been able to secure the inclosed document from the Bureau of Vital Statistics in Edmonton, certifying that the Adams (Paul) were married by Father MacKenzie, Roman Catholic priest.

3.- As far as the children are concerned, we cannot find any other records.

4.- The object of my first letter was to tell you the request of one of my patients at the Camell Hospital, Mrs. Paul Adams (or Paul) who was married in the Catholic Church and wants her children to be brought up as Catholics in a Catholic School.

5.- Since no church records can be obtained I am just sending you the humble and Bona Fide request of a sick mother, patient at our hospital here, regarding her own children.

Yours sincerely,

E. Rhéaume O.M.I.,

February 14th 1938.

Mr. M. Christianson,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Christianson;

Mr. H. Goodland whom you know, and who has been in our Indian work for many years, has requested me to write you a personal letter relative to the purchase of a new car.

In purchasing a FORD we have always been given the advantage of a remit on the taxes and other advantages which this company gives to Government employees. Mr. Goodland however wishes to purchase either a Hudson, or a Nash product and he wishes to know if he would be able to secure similar discounts on these makes as are accorded by the Ford people.

If you are able to obtain any consideration for Mr. Goodland in the purchase of his car such action will be much appreciated.

Since leaving Alberta we often think of you and our associations of past years. I trust you are enjoying your work in Ottawa. If at any time you come West we will be glad to have a visit from you.

Sincerely Yours,

J.F. Woodsworth.
Principal.
OTTAWA,
February 18, 1938.

Memorandum

Mr. Bailey,

I am in receipt of a letter from Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, B.A., principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School, who informs me that Mr. H. Goodland, farming instructor at the school, wishes to purchase a car, either a Hudson or a Nash.

In the past the Ford people have always given the residential school the advantage of a remit on the taxes and other advantages which they give government employees. Mr. Woodsworth is asking that we take this question up with the Hudson and Nash companies. I should be glad if you would take this matter up with them.

For your information I might say that the residential school is the property of the Dominion Government and is operated under the auspices of the United Church on a per capita grant.

General Superintendent of Agencies.

Dear Sir,-

We are in receipt of your letter of February 28th, advising that Mr. H. Goodland, Farming Instructor at the Edmonton Indian Residential School, has under consideration the purchase of a car.

We would be glad to recognize Mr. Goodland as entitled to fleet owner's discount as a Government official but you will realize, of course, that if he has a car to trade in, the discount allowed by our Edmonton distributors, The Freeman Company of Alberta, Ltd., would apply only on the difference in price between the used car and the new.

Yours very truly,

(sgd) Ross Mackinnon,

Vice-President.
Memorandum:

Mr. M. Christianson.

With reference to your memorandum of the 16th ultimo, relative to a car requested by the Farming Instructor at the Indian Residential School, Edmonton, I am forwarding herewith, for your information, a copy of a letter from the Hudson Motors of Canada, Limited.

The Breay-Nash Motors have advised that the request forwarded their firm has been sent on by them to the Supervisor of the territory, viz: the Motordrome Company, Edmonton, requesting that they reply direct. When this reply is received a copy will be forwarded you.

Departmental Purchasing Agent.
Dear Sir:

The Hudson Motor Company will be glad to recognize Mr. Goodland as entitled to fleet owner's discount, but if he has a car to trade in, the discount will apply only to the difference between the price of the new car and the trade-in value of the old one. This rule applies on Departmental trades also.

The Breay-Nash Motors have taken the matter up with their Edmonton representatives and you will be further advised when their reply is to hand.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

For General Superintendent of Agencies.

Rev. J. F. Woodsworth,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of
[Name], Pupil No. [Number]
of the [School Name] Indian Residential School at [Location],
who died at [Hospital Name] (place) on November 18, 1936.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the
Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry,
consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical
Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's
presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of
Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's
death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be
permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked
if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be
attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
tical for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him.
A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal
Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including
an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? Sept 13/35
2. At what time of day? Noon of that date
3. When and to whom did she report this illness or accident? To the Matron at this hour
4. What remedies were taken to afford relief? She immediately sent for Dr. Woodworth
5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? None
6. When was the doctor called? At 2 P.M.
7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? Immediately by ambulance
8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school?
9. Add any other useful information here.

The girl is another from B.C. She has had treatment for T.B. since she came here. She has been a source of anxiety.

J. Woodworth
Principal

I attended Olive Whales from Sept 13/35 to Nov 13/35. The immediate cause of death was hyperacidity - endocarditis. The contributory cause of death was Tubercular pneumonia. Our work before death developed capillaries.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? Yes
Did they follow out your professional instructions? Yes

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

I was immediately notified on Sept 6th by Miss MacDonald the Matron of the school on Sept 13/35 when Olive Whales became acutely ill with a sudden heart attack.

G. L. Williamson M.D.

EDMONTON, November 14, 1935

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sirs:

Regarding Olive Whale a pupil of the Indian Residential School, Edmonton, who died on November 13th, 1935 in the Isolation Hospital here.

She was examined by me on June 12th, 1935, and found to be in average health. She had lost the sight of her left eye when a child, and she had some enlarged glands on both sides of her neck which had not broken down. She remained at the school during the summer holidays. She complained of not feeling well on September 12th, and she was sent to bed by the Matron, and I examined her that morning at the school. Temperature was normal and pulse 80. She complained of a slight pain in her chest. Examination of her heart revealed some leakage in valves. I advised keeping her at rest and under observation. Between one and two o'clock that day I was called urgently to the school to see her. I was at the school in approximately one half hour and found her to be in very serious condition. She was suffering from Dyspnea, pain in chest, coughing slightly; she was cyanosed, very weak and pulse 140. Saved her life by administration of Morphine and Strychnin and sent her to the hospital. X-ray report in hospital was that her heart was enormously enlarged both to right and left and lungs were congested. She did not run a high temperature at any time. Her pulse rate the first two or three days was between 140 and 160 and respirations as high as 55. Her lung condition cleared up considerably. With rest, Digitalis and Morphine she remained fairly comfortable. Her liver increased in size and she later developed edema in the lower extremities and abdomen and a nephritis.

During the past three weeks she had increased pain and was failing in strength.

On November 5th she developed a low grade erysipelas on her face. She was moved to the Isolation Hospital. Her temperature and pulse increased; she became weaker and died on November 13th, 1935.

Apparently a malignant form of endocarditis, and practically hopeless from the beginning of her illness in September.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

G. L. Williamson, M.D.

1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of Charles Francis Henry have been recorded? Yes. If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

I would recommend that the Principal of the School be instructed to communicate with the parents as soon as any child is sent to hospital from the school. In this case the father was not advised until Friday morning just before the boy died.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

Charles Francis Henry, son of Mr. Henry, was present at the inquiry. All questions and answers were understood. He then, afterwards stated that he was satisfied everything was done he could have done. That he had no statement to make except that he thought he should have been advised as soon as the boy was sent to Hospital.

G. F. Cleghorn
Chairman Indian Agent.

I attended Isaac Bird from Nov 14/37 to Nov 14/37. The immediate cause of death was... The contributory cause of death was...

G.R. Williamson M.D.
I regret to report that Isaac Bird, pupil No. 202, of the Edmonton Indian Residential School died very suddenly at 9:10 A.M. Sunday morning. I was advised of his death by Rev. Mr. Woodsworth, Principal of the school at 9:30 A.M. and immediately arranged for a Board of Inquiry to be held in Edmonton at 2 P.M. Monday afternoon.

The father and brother of the deceased pupil arrived from their reserve by train Monday morning and both attended the inquiry. The Principal Mr. Woodsworth stated that at 5 A.M. Sunday morning the Matron Miss McDonald was called by some of the other pupils and that she at once called him and that when he arrived the boy was rigid, the Doctor had been called and the boy was given first aid until the arrival of the Doctor. Mr. Woodsworth stated that the boy came around and knew those around him, but afterwards had one or two attacks. The Doctor arrived at the school about thirty minutes after he was called and had the boy taken to hospital. Mr. Woodsworth also states that the boy was put to bed Saturday afternoon for his afternoon rest and that he ate a good dinner and supper on Saturday and that when he went to bed at about 7 P.M. Saturday night that he appeared to be in good health, the boy had not complained of any pains or of not feeling well. Doctor Williamson stated that upon his arrival at the school the boy was in a semi-conscious condition, he took the boy to the hospital in his car accompanied by Miss McDonald the Matron of the school, he arrived at the hospital about 5:45 A.M. the boy's pulse and heart rate was 72. Doctor Williamson stated that the boy did not complain of any pain but that it was quite possible that he was in pain. Doctor Williamson also stated that he had not seen the boy for about two weeks before when he examined a T.B. gland on the right side level of collar bone. The father of the boy stated that the boy had been subject to fits all his life, and that he had suffered with his stomach a great deal.

Please find enclosed Memorandum of inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of this pupil. Trusting you will find everything in order.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

G. C. Laight,
Indian Agent.

T. R. L. MacInnes, Esq.,
Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Photos of scene of Accident where Joe Shamp was fatally injured January 24th 1948.
Copy of Statement made by Mr Joseph Rouault.

Re: Death of Joe Stamp, Pupil No.216, Edmonton Indian Res. School.

I left my home at about 10 A.M. on Saturday January 24th 1942. I live about two and one half miles from the scene of the accident. I was going to assist my son to build a barn; he lives one and one half miles from St. Albert, Alta. When I got to the bottom of the hill I saw it follow the road running East and West. I saw two boys coming down the hill on two small bob sleighs, and when I saw them I applied my brakes and one of the boys came under my car between the front and hind wheels; the other one stopped about one or two feet in front of the front wheel of my car. I jumped out of my car and picked up the boy that had gone under my car; he was about eight or ten inches from the back of the car. I put the boy into my car on the back seat and my wife held him until I got to Dr. Perier's at St. Albert, when we got to Doctor Perier's place I called the doctor right away, the doctor came out to see the child right away, the doctor then ran into the house to put on his overcoat and then came along with me to the hospital with the child; when we got to the hospital the child was put on a stretcher and was taken up to the operating room, that is all I know about it. My drivers License is No.15267.

Signed. Jos Rouault

Witness.

G. G. Leight,
Indian Agent.
"I am 55 years of age, and on June 26th, 1948 I left my farm 3 miles east of MacLaren to go by my own place near MacLaren, driving my Plymouth sedan Alberta license plate 7066, and accompanying me was my wife Mrs. V. McMillan.

I was driving along the road about 30 miles per hour, and arriving at the intersection of the road leading south to the Indian School. Then that accident happened. I just saw three or little boys sliding down with a slight slope to my car, just in the middle of the road. I put the brake on, but all at once one of these boys went under the car between the front wheel and the hind wheel, and I opened the door, and got back behind the car, and I find the little boy lying there, so I picked him up, and I put him in the car and came to the aid of MacLaren, with his help, to hospital.

Then I flew to the rope they were about 30 feet ahead of my car, the boy that went under the car also, from the south road and swung just beside my car; the other boy turned a little side.

I was pretty near into the corner before I saw the boys, the boys were travelling somewhat faster than I was, so fast as I think.

The accident took place about 10:10 or 10:15 am, in whether was clear, and about a little later my wife was sitting in the front seat close to me.

I have driver's license No. 18897

Then I had the little boy in my arms, the other boys came close with their mother.

The other boy that went west and I stopped at the same time, and he stepped just in front of my car, about 2 feet in front of the car.

My car is insured for accidents.

Witness: J.J. John / Upde. Joseph McMillan.

G. C. Leight, Esq.,
Indian Agent, Winterburn Agency,
Winterburn, Alberta.
