Commanding Edmonton Sub-Div.
At approx. 11:45 AM of the 26th Inst., a phone call was received by the author from Dr. ROULIN of St. Albert, from the Blackfoot Indian Reserve, Edmonton, that she had heard a young Indian boy from the above school had been hit by a car near the school, which is situated 2 miles East and 1 mile South of St. Albert, and that there was no chance of the boy living.

On receipt of this information I immediately accompanied by Const. Thomas Tapp, Detached to Highway Patrol, with Police car No. 1867, proceeded to watch the boy to investigate this matter. On arrival at the scene I met Const. Dr. ROULIN, and from him learned that one Joseph ROULIN, a farmer residing 5 miles East of St. Albert, whilst driving his car into St. Albert, had been in an accident with his car, and a sleigh upon which the above described was slung, on the highway 2 miles East of St. Albert; that the top of the boy's head was badly crushed in, brain matter was protruding, and the boy was bleeding badly from the brain; that there was no hope of his recovery, and his death would be expected at any time. Dr. ROULIN had brought the boy to the Dr. Office at St. Albert, and from there he had been brought into the hospital by the Dr. and Dr. ROULIN in ROULIN'S car, which vehicle was in the hospital grounds, and ROULIN waiting for us in the hospital.

I then contacted ROULIN, and from him learned the bare facts of the accident, which were to the effect that he was driving West towards St. Albert on the highway running East from St. Albert, when on arriving at the 2 mile point East of St. Albert, the South Road leading to the Indian School from that corner, as he arrived at the intersection, the Indian Boy, had come from the south road onto the East Road, on a small sleigh turned in due North Easterly Direction towards his car. He ROULIN had fully applied his brakes, and turned to his right to avoid the boy, but the boy had gone underneath the car between the front and rear wheels, and he suspected had been run over with the rear wheels, as he had the car stopped practically as soon as the boy hit the car, but when he got out and ran back, the boy was lying at the back of the car, just beside the rear of the right rear fender. He had then picked up the boy, and rushed him to Dr. ROULIN'S office; and from there to the hospital.

Before leaving the hospital, I thoroughly examined ROULIN'S car which was a 1946 Plymouth sedan, and found it to be in perfect shape, the brakes in same being in perfect condition, even, and full holding pressure also to save time, and as this accident had taken place fairly an hour or more by this time, and I wanted to examine the scene before all marks were obliterated, I requested Const. Richards to proceed to the hospital and take pictures of the car, as Dr. ROULIN was proceeding with me to the scene of the accident, and the Dr. himself returning to St. Albert, with ROULIN'S car.

Patrol was made to the corner above noted and the scene of the accident investigated, which resulted in the following picture of the accident being found.
5. The deceased along with the following Indian boys, namely, Richard Norman, Gordon Snowchild, James Johnson, Oscar Hudson, Billy Lapinack, Howard Skinner, Bobbie Stember, Billy Johnson, and Herbert Harris, all boys residing at the Indian Residential School, Rama's Baral, and all between 9 and 15 years of age, were sleighing down a steep incline on the highway which runs from South to the Indian School, from the East and West Highway, East of St. Albert, from the 2 Mile Corner, from which corner the highway South has a steep upgrade for approx. 700 feet, and both roads being covered with snow a coating of ice, makes a great allusion slide for the boys, the bad feature being that they do not stop before reaching the East and West Highway, but cross over onto the North Highway, and down into the field on the other side of the East and West Highway, sometimes they turn to the East or West, and continue along that Highway. At the South East corner, running to the South and to the North, there is heavy and high brush, making this corner absolutely blind, and any person proceeding West, can not see anything on the South Highway until he is right up in line with the North and South fence lines, and since the boys were close to the ground, the situation is very much worse.

6. The deceased was the first to start down, with Oscar Jackson being the second, and the others starting a second or so later. The deceased on reaching the corner, turned to the East, and arrived at the intersection, was practically at the same time as Richard Norman, who was proceeding his sleigh about 30 miles per hour, although the track would tend to show that his speed was slower than that, but on stopping the boy immediately applied his brakes hard, and turned his sleigh to his right (to the North), the car stopping just as the right front wheel rested on the shoulder of the highway. The boy were riding small horse made sleighs, with steel runners and the deceased was riding being one of the largest, and a rather heavy sleigh, with wide steel runners, and as the road was a steep down grade, long, and covered with ice, the speed of these sleighs could be I would judge about 30 mph. Which speed would naturally intend to keep the sleigher's head down to break the wind, and therefore no watch ahead would be kept for cross traffic, indeed this point was backed up by questioning the other boys later, as they admitted that they did not look for traffic, but when going down the hills, they were obliged to each other to keep clear of each other owing to their speed, and once reached the bottom nearest together, they would split to clear each other's sleigh. The deceased and Jackson therefore split, which resulted in the sleigh the deceased was riding not the horse on just about the last line of the intersection, on the North side of the highway with the sleigh meeting the car, that above the front end of the left running board, the sleigh rope caught only the frame of the left running board, which stopped it there, and the boy kept on going, underneath the running board, which his head cleared, but the frame of this car provides towards the ground, about 4 to 6 inches lower than the running board, and his head would therefore smash against this frame, which of course caused the injuries he received, smashing the top of his skull in, this then stopped his forward movement, and the car still proceeding ahead for a few feet more, the rear wheels ("off") passed over his legs, breaking same, the car stopping just after this, and the boy's body stopping where it did just to the rear of the car, nearer the right rear wheel.

7. The other boy Jackson also kept proceeding across the highway, and he stopped about 2 feet in front of the car, both his sleigh and the car stopping at practically the same second, Norman at the time thought that this boy was also under the car, but luckily this did not happen although it was a very close call.

8. From the top of the hill, the boys can not see an part of the East and West road, and here again the situation is the same as when proceeding West, the corner to the East is blind until one is just about at the fence line, making in other words a very bad, and dangerous corner, at any time, without including the matter of children using
I am 69 years of age, and on June 26th, 1948 I left my farm 5 miles east of Shellburne to go to my own place near Shellburne, driving my Plymouth sedan Alberta, license No. 69-375, and accompanying me was my wife Mrs. V. M. McMillan.

I was driving along the road about 20 miles per hour, and arriving at the intersection of the road leading south to the Indian School. Then that accident happened. I just saw these two little boys sliding down with a sleigh close by my car, just in the middle of the road. I put the brake on, and all at once one of these boys went under the car, between the front wheel and the hind wheel, and I opened the door, and saw both behind the car, and I find the little boy lying down, and I picked him up, and I put him in the car and came to the R.C.A.F. at Shellburne, with him, to Edmonton.

The first time the boys they were about 30 feet ahead of my car, the boy that went under the car ran from the north west and west east towards my car, the other boy almost a little more.

I was going very fast before the accident, but after the boys, the boys were travelling considerably faster than I was, so fast as I was I didn't see them.

The accident took place about 10:10 or 10:15 a.m., the weather was clear, and a little foggy, my wife was sitting in the front seat close to me.

I have a driver's license No. 18867.

Then I had the little boy in my arms, the other boys came close with their sledges.

The other boy that went west and I stopped at the same time, and he stepped inside in front of my car, about 5 feet in front of the car.

My car is insured for accidents.

Witness J. L. Smith, A.O.P.I.E., Joseph McMillan.

OF CHILDREN USING, the highway for sliding, the addition of which made the highway a dangerous place for any traffic to travel on, at no matter what speed the vehicle was travelling, thereby placing any vehicle operator in a very bad spot.

Photographs and measurements were taken by the writer and a police officer, and attached hereto, are copies of photos, and plans which show shows that this accident was purely accidental, and no blame whatever can be laid against ROBINSON.

Whilst interviewing the boys at the Indian School I was informed by phone by Mr. WOODSORTH J.F., Principal of the Indian School who was at that time at the scene, that the boy had died. This would be approximately 14:00 p.m. I therefore contacted Mr. SMITHWAITE, Chief Coroner, giving him all particulars of the accident, and he informed me that he did not think that an Inquest would be necessary, but asked that Mr. ROBINSON, who is coroner for St. Albert, would proceed out to the scene of the crash and investigate same; give him a report, and if his report was as mine, the investigation would be all that was necessary and Inquest would not be required.

Mr. ROBINSON was therefore contacted, and he proceeded to the scene, examined all tracks etc., and reported to Mr. SMITHWAITE, who instructed Mr. SMITHWAITE, after receiving this report that an Inquest would not be necessary, as the accident was purely accidental, and no blame could be placed on ROBINSON.

The body of the boy on instructions of Mr. WOODSORTH was taken over by ROBERT & MERRILL Undertakers, and is being held by them pending final instructions of Parish from Mr. LAIGHT, Indian Agent, in whose district the School is situated.

The boy's parents are of the Saddle Lake Indian Reservation, his father being Francis SHAW of that Reserve, and he has been notified of the matter by the Agent at that point, by Mr. Laight, and it is in accordance with the Indian Act, for an enquiry to be held by the Indian Agent into such matters, this enquiry will take place at 10:00 am on Monday the 26th Inst., at the "main School," with Mr. LAIGHT presiding, the writer will be in attendance, on request of Mr. LAIGHT, when such my evidence of investigation will be submitted, such request granted by instructions received.

The deceased is 10 years of age, has been at the School since 1896, and his father is a full blood Indian.

Reference to the plan, tracks of the car show for a long ways back, and show that gradually easing over to the right of himself, determined with slight brake pressure being applied, thus as they came about reach the North and South fence line, the brake was fully applied, which makes up the statement of ROBINSON, that was he close near each fence he slows down, drives over to his right side of road, in order to protect himself and others should any traffic be coming on to the highway, and of course was just at the corner the boy rushed into view, he carried out the action already described.

The two gateways marked in the bottom of the plan, is the two gates used by the boys to continue the slide down the hill after crossing the East and West highway. Indeed the last gateway is really part of the fence taken down by them in order to make a longer slide.

Owing to the foregoing therefore I respectfully submit that this accident was purely accidental, that no blame can be attached to the car driver, that no infractions or offenses was committed by him, and the matter be concluded by this report, as far as we are concerned. Further report will be submitted on conclusion of the Inquiry to be held by Indian Agent LAIGHT.

Chief Coroner Dr. SMITHWAITE requested that a copy of our report be forwarded to him, attached hereto is extra copy.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of 
[Signature], Pupil No. [Number]
of the [School Name] Indian Residential School at [Location],
who died at [Place] (place) on [Date] 1948.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Sir:

I beg to report that Joe Stamp, age 11 years, pupil No. 216, Edmonton Indian Residential School, died on January 24th, in the Misericordia Hospital in Edmonton, from the result of sliding under the motor car of one Jos. Rouault, of St. Albert, Alta.

Joe Stamp was the son of Zaccias Stamp, of the Saddle Lake Indian Agency.

I was advised of the accident at 11:35 A.M. by the Rev. Mr. J.F. Woodsworth, Principal of the school, and at 12:15 P.M., Mr. Woodsworth advised me that the boy had died. I arranged for an inquiry to be held at 10 A.M. Monday January 27th, 1942. On Sunday January 25th, I was advised by Mr. W.P.B. Pugh, Indian Agent, Saddle Lake Agency, that it would be impossible for the boy's father to reach Edmonton until the 2:15 train on Tuesday January 27th; I therefore changed the time for the inquiry to take place at 3 P.M. Tuesday January 27th.

The inquiry was attended by Zaccias Stamp, father of the boy, Dr. R. Porier, M.D., who had attended the boy, Corp. J. Muir, R.C.M.P. Police, Mr. Jos. Rouault, Rev. Mr. Woodsworth, Principal of the school, Mr. W.P.B. Pugh, Indian Agent, Saddle Lake Agency and myself.

Corp. Muir produced a drawing of the scene of the accident also photos showing the position of the car when it came to a full stop, and other photos showing the condition of the road at the time of the accident. The photos are enclosed herewith and the drawing is being forwarded under separate cover to the Department. Corp. Muir explained the drawing and photos, and stated that the driver of the car had done everything possible to avoid the accident and that no blame could be attached to Mr. Rouault. I did not take a statement from Corp. Muir at the inquiry as he handed to me a copy of his report on the case and I considered that sufficient; this copy of Corp. Muir's report is attached to Form No. 414.

A statement was taken from Mr. Jos. Rouault at the time of the inquiry and a copy is attached to Form No. 414. Doctor Porier's and Mr. Woodsworth's statements are embodied in Form 414.

The father Zaccias Stamp was given an opportunity to ask any questions when the statements were given, at the end of the inquiry I asked him if he was satisfied with the evidence given and he replied that he did not blame anyone but the school. I explained to him that I had given instruction that the boys were not to be allowed to toboggan down any hill on the public roads, and he was quite satisfied.

Respectfully submitted,

I am Sir,
Your obedient servant,

G. C. Laight,
Indian Agent,

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have just received a very complete report from Indian Agent Laight with reference to the circumstances surrounding the accidental death of Joe Stamp, pupil No. 216 of the Edmonton Residential School. It appears that the boys have been in the habit of using one of the roads near the school for a toboggan slide. At the foot of the hill another road crosses this road at right angles and unfortunately young Stamp arrived at the corner at the same time as an automobile. For your information I attach a copy of a letter which is being forwarded to the Rev. Principal of the Edmonton School.

Injured at Play,
Indian Lad Dies

Fatally injured when his sled crashed into a moving auto three miles east of St. Albert, Joseph Stamp, 16-year-old Saddle Lake Indian, died at Edmonton General Hospital at 12:15 Saturday.

He and a group of other children attending the Indian Residential school east of St. Albert were coasting down a hill, across a road, and down onto the highway. Young Stamp came down the slide as the car of Joe Rouault, St. Albert, approached.

Rouault, according to Dr. Richard Paterson, who operated on the boy, and almost had his car stopped when the sled crashed between the front wheels and wheel. The boy's head struck the car frame, and the rear wheel.

The accident occurred about 10:35 a.m., and the boy was taken to St. Albert General Hospital and then into hospital at Edmonton, arriving at 11:00 a.m., but young Stamp died an hour and a quarter later from a fractured skull.

No hearing will be held. It was announced by the coroner, although an investigation will be made into the accident.
Indian Residential School

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report for the month of January 1942, somewhat late but owing to my absence on trap line work at Lac La Biche on February 2, 3 & 4th.

GENERAL

The accident at the Edmonton School in which Joe Stamp son of Zac Stam of the Saddle Lake Band of Indians was very sad, this being the second child that this same Indian had lost while attending the Edmonton School. I think I did everything possible to see that the father of the child was satisfied and I feel safe in saying there will be no repercussions which I was very anxious to avoid especially towards any of our Boarding Schools. I assume the responsibility of having the boys body shipped home at the expense of the dept. the account I have submitted already under an explanatory letter.

W.P.B. Pugh
Indian Agent.

STATEMENT OF JOSEPH ROUAULT, R.R. 2 St. Alberts taken on above date.

"I am 59 years of age, and on Jan. 26th, 1942 I left my farm 5 miles East of St. Alberts to go to my son's place near St. Alberts, driving my Plymouth Sedan Alberta Lie No. 63-383, and accompanying me was my wife Mrs. V. ROUAULT.

I was driving along the road about 30 miles per hour, and arriving at the intersection of the road leading south to the Indian School. When that accident happened, there were these two little boys climbing down a slight slope to my car, just in the middle of the road, past the bushes, and all at once one of these boys went under the car, between the front wheel and the hind wheel, and I opened the door, and ran back behind the car, and I find the little boy lying down, and I picked him up, and I put him in the car and came to the Dye at St. Alberts, with him to Dr. BORRIER.

When I first saw the boys they were about 30 feet ahead of my car, the boy that went under the car came from the south road and swung East towards my car, the other boy turned a little West.

I was pretty near into the corner before I saw the boys. The boys were travelling considerably faster than I was, as fast as I think.

The accident took place about 10:10 or 10:15 a.m., the weather was clear and Road a little icy. My wife was sitting in the front seat close to me.

I have driver's Lie. No. 15547

When I had the little boy in my arms, the other boy came close with their weights.

The other boy that went west and I stopped at the same time, and he stopped just in front of my car, about 2 feet in front of the car.

My car is insured for accidents.

Witness J.J. Muir A/Opl. Sgt. Joseph ROUAULT."

G. C. Laight, Esq.,
Indian Agent, Winterburn Agency,
Winterburn, Alberta.

Re: Joe STAMP - Indian School, Edmonton
Sudden Death of Cont (3)

Para. 8 Cont.

OF CHILDREN USING, the highway for sliding, the addition of which made the highway a dangerous place for any traffic to travel on, at no matter what speed the vehicle was travelling, thereby placing any vehicle operator in a very bad spot.

9. Photos, and measurements were taken by the writer and a plan drawn, and attached hereto, are copies of photos, and plan which alone shows that his accident was purely accidental, and no blame whatever can be laid against BOUQUET.

10. Whilst interviewing the boys at the Indian School I was informed by phone by Mr. WOODSWORTH, J.P., Principal of the Indian School who was at that time at the Hop, that the boy had died; this would be Approx. 1400 p.m. I therefore contacted Dr. BRAITHWAITE, Chief Coroner, giving him all particulars of the accident, and he informed me that he did not think that an Inquest would be necessary, but asked that Dr. ROBERTS, who is coroner for St. Albert, proceed out to the scene of the accident and investigate same, give him a report, and if his report was as mine, the investigation would be all that was necessary and Inquest would not be required.

11. Dr. ROBERTS was therefore contacted, and he proceeded to the scene, examined all tracks etc., and reported to Dr. Braithwaite. He was instructed by Dr. Braithwaite, after receiving this report that an Inquest would not be necessary, as the accident was purely accidental, and no blame could be placed on BOUQUET.

12. The Body of the boy on instructions of Mr. WOODSWORTH was taken over by HOWARD & McBRIDE Undertakers, and is being held by them pending final instructions of Burial from Mr. LAIGHT, Indian Agent, in whose Dist. the School is situated.

13. The Boys parents are of the Saddle Lake Indian Reservation, his father being Zacarias STAMP of that Reserve. He has been notified of the matter by the Agent at that point, by Mr. Laight, and as it is necessary under the Indian Act, for an Enquiry to be held by the Indian Agent into such matters, this enquiry will take place at 10.00 am. of Monday the 26th Inst. at the Indian School, with Mr. LAIGHT presiding, the writer will be in attendance, on request of Mr. LAIGHT, when my evidence of investigation will be submitted, such request granted by instructions received.

14. The Decedent is 10 years of age, has been at the School since 1939, and his father is a full blood Indian.

15. Reference to the plan, tracks of the car show for a long ways back, and show them gradually easing over to the right of highway, with slight brake pressure being applied, then as they reach about reach the North and South fence line, the brake was fully applied, which backs up the statement of BOUQUET, that when he comes near such corners he slows down, drives over to his right side of road, in order to protect himself and others should any traffic be coming on to the highway, and of course when just at the corner the boy rushed into view, he carried out the action already described.

The two gateways, marked in the bottom of the plan, is the two gates used by the boys to continue the slide down the hill after crossing the West and East Highway, indeed the East Gateway is really part of the fence taken down by them in order to make a longer slide.

16. Owing to the foregoing therefore I respectfully submit that this accident was purely accidental, that no blame can be attached to the car driver, that no infractions or offenses was committed by him, and the matter be concluded by this report, so far as we are concerned. Further report will be submitted on conclusion of the Enquiry to be held by Indian Agent LAIGHT.

17. Chief Coroner Dr. BRAITHWAITE requested that a copy of our report be forwarded to him, attached hereto is extra copy.
The deceased along with the following Indian boys, namely, Richard MORGAN, Gordon CROWCHILD, Oscar JACKSON, Billy LAPTACK, Howard STEINER, Bobbie STEINER, Dick CURRIE, and Herbert RABBIT, all boys residing at the Indian Residential School, Edmonton Rural, and all between 9 and 13 years of age, were sleighing down a steep incline, on the highway which runs South to the Indian School, from the East and West Highway, East of St. Albert, from the 2nd Corner, from which corner the highway South has a steep grade for approx. 100 feet, and both roads being covered with snow, a coating of ice, making the sleighing extremely hazardous for the boys, the bad feature being that they do not stop before reaching the East and West highway, but cross same, over the North Ditch, and down into the field on the North side of the East and West Highway; sometimes they turn to the East or West, and continue along that Highway. At the South East Corner, running to the South and to the East, there is heavy and high Brush, making this corner absolutely blind, and any person proceeding West, cannot see anything on the South highway, until he is right up in line with the North and South fence line, and since the boys were close to the ground, the situation is very much worse.

The deceased was the first to start down, with Oscar JACKSON being the second, and the others starting a second or so later. The deceased on reaching the corner turned to the East, and arrived at the intersection, practically at the same time as BOUULT arrived there with his car. BOUULT was proceeding his stated about 30 miles per hour, although the trucks would tend to slow him down, his speed was slower than that, but on seeing the boy he immediately applied his brakes hard, and turned his car to his right (to the North), his car stopping just as his right front wheel rested on the shoulder of the highway. The boy were riding small homemade sleighs, with steel runners and the one the deceased was riding being one of the largest, and a rather heavy sleigh, with wide steel runners, and as the road was a steep downhill grade, long, and covered with Ice, the speed of these sleighs would be I would judge about 30 m.p.h., which speed would naturally tend to keep the sleighs going down to break the wind, and therefore no watch ahead would be kept for cross traffic. Indeed this point was backed up by questioning the other boys later, as they admitted that they did not look for traffic, but when going down the hill, they were pushing each other to keep clear of each other owing to their speed, and reached the bottom nearly together, they would split to clear each other sleighs. The deceased and JACKSON therefore split, which resulted in the sleigh the deceased was riding met the BOUULT car just about the East line of the intersection, on the North side of the highway, and the sleigh meeting the car, just about the front end of the left running board, the sleigh rope caught onto the front of the left running board, which stopped it there, and the boy kept on going, underneath the running board, which his head cleared, but the frame of this car protrudes towards the ground, about 4 to 5 inches lower than the running board, and his head would therefore smash against this frame, which of course caused the injuries he received, smashing the top of his skull in, this then stopped his forward movement, and the car still proceeding ahead for a few feet more, the rear wheels ("eft") passed over his legs, breaking same, the car stopping just after this, and the boys body stopping where it did just to the rear of the car, nearer the right rear wheel.

The other boy JACKSON, also kept proceeding across the highway, and he stopped about 2 feet in front of the car, both his sleigh and the car stopping at practically the same second, BOUULT at the time thought that this boy was also under the car, but luckily this did not happen although it was a very close call.

From the top of the hill, the boys can not see an part of the East and West road, and here again the situation is the same as when proceeding West, the corner to the East is blind until one is just about at the fence line, making in other words a very bad, and dangerous corner, at any time, without including the matter of children using
At approx. 11:00 AM of the 26th Inst., a phone call was received by the writer, from Dr. FORRIER of St. Albert, from the Misericordia Hosp., Edmonton, that the above named young Indian boy from the above school had been hit by a car near the school, which is situated 2 miles East and 1 mile South of St. Albert, and that there was no chance of the boy living.

On receipt of this information I immediately accompanied by Const. INTERS, went to Highway Patrol, with Police car Code No. 8247, proceeded to stated Hosp. to investigate this matter. On arrival at the Hosp. I contacted Dr. FORRIER, and from him learned that one Joseph ROUAULT, a farmer residing 5 miles East of St. Albert, whilst driving his car into St. Albert, had been in an accident with his car, and a sleigh upon which the above deceased was sleighing on the highway 2 miles East of St. Albert, that the top of the boy's head was badly crushed in, brain matter was protruding, and the boy was bleeding badly from the brain, that there was no hope of his recovery, and his death could be expected at any time. Mr. ROUAULT had brought the boy to the Dr.'s office at St. Albert, and from there he had been brought into the Hosp. by the Dr. and Mr. ROUAULT in ROUAULT's car, whose vehicle was in the Hosp. Grounds, and ROUAULT waiting for us in the Hospital.

I then contacted ROUAULT, and from him learned the bare facts of the accident, which were to the effect that he was driving West towards St. Albert, on the highway running East from St. Albert, and on arriving at the 2 mile corner East of St. Albert, the South Road running to the Indian School from the corner, as he arrived at the intersection, the Indian boy, had come from the South Road onto the East road, on a small sleigh turned in North Easterly direction towards his car, he ROUAULT had fully applied his brakes, and turned to his right to avoid the boy, but the boy had gone underneath the car between the front and rear wheels, and he suspected had been run over with the rear wheels, as he had the car stopped practically at same time the boy hit it, but out of sight, he came out and ran back, the boy was lying at the back of the car, just inside the rear of the right rear fender. He had then picked up the boy, and rushed him to Dr. FORRIER's office and from there to the Hospital.

Before leaving the Hosp. I thoroughly examined ROUAULT's car which was a 1941 Plymouth Sedan, and found it to be in perfect shape, the brakes on same being in perfect condition, even, and full holding pressure, also to save time, as this accident had taken place fully an hour or more by this time, and I wanted to examine the scene before all marks were obliterated, I requested Const. Richard's to proceed to the Hosp. and take pictures of the car, as Mr. ROUAULT was proceeding with me to the scene of the accident, and the Dr. returning to St. Albert with ROUAULT's car.

Patrol was made then to the corner above noted and the scene of the accident investigated, which resulted in the following picture of the accident being found.

Form No. I.A. 518
Dear Sir,

Re Accident (Fatal) at Edmonton School.

With reference to the two Vouchers attached No.31-42 in favor of Howard & McBride Ltd., Edmonton, and No.31-42 in favor of myself, I beg to herewith state the circumstances under which I incurred the expenditure.

You will have no doubt received by this time Agent G.O. Leight's report of the Court of Enquiry held into the accidental death of a pupil by the name of Joe Stamp, son of Zac Stamp No.281 J. Seenum's Band. It is a matter of record that this same Indian Zac Stamp had his daughters die at the Edmonton School some two years ago of natural causes. You will well understand the attitude of this Indian when this boy met with the accidental death while toccoganing on a road off the Edmonton School premises, the boy running into a car and died within two hours.

I proceeded to Edmonton on Jan 27th with Zac Stamp to attend the Court of Enquiry so that I would obtain a first hand knowledge of the accident at the same time assure myself that Stamp was satisfied that it was a pure accident and that he would not have any resentment towards the school authorities. I am of the opinion that Stamp is aware that all was done to assure him of very fair Court of Enquiry and that an Indian's rights have been respected.

I asked Stamp what he would like done with the corpse and he stated he would like to have the same sent back to Saddle Lake for burial. I mentioned to him that this was not in accordance with the department's instructions but that I thought under these most extenuating circumstances (and I can assure the department they were) the department would pay the account.

I am satisfied that all of the Indians are satisfied that Stamp received courteous treatment and that no ill feelings are felt towards the Edmonton School. I might also mention that Mr. Woodworth was very kind and considerate.

In regards to the voucher in my favor in the sum of $2.00, as Stamp was hard pressed for cash I gave him this to assist in his out of pocket expenses and the payment rests entirely with the generosity of the department. I would however ask you to make payment of Howard & McBride's Ltd. Voucher in full and I can assure the department that it would be much appreciated by both Stamp and myself.

Respectfully submitted,

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

WP.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

INDIAN AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF JANUARY 1942.

Sir:

I beg to submit my report for the month of January 1942 as follows:

GENERAL:

I regret to have to report that on Saturday January 24th there was a fatal accident near the Edmonton Indian Residential School when a number of boys were tobogganing down a very steep hill, one of the ran under a motor car, he was taken to the hospital in Edmonton but died shortly after being admitted, an inquiry was held at the School on January 27th and a full report sent to the Department.

G.C. Laight,
Indian Agent.

AIR MAIL

Mr. J.T. Faunt, Acting Indian Agent, Winterburn, Alta.

I am in receipt of a letter from Indian Agent Pugh, Saddle Lake, in which he states that Reverend Mr. Woodsworth advised him by telephone on December 11 that George Breast, a pupil of the Edmonton School from the Saddle Lake Agency, lost his left foot at the ankle as a result of an accident in using an ensilage cutter.

The Department desires you to investigate this matter thoroughly. You should obtain a signed statement from the Principal regarding the accident and also a signed statement from the member of the staff who was in charge of the boys at the time the ensilage cutter was being used.

A report from the Medical Officer regarding the boy's condition should also be attached.

An early reply to this letter would be appreciated.

Acting Director.

Sir,

Having been requested by the authorities of the R.C. Church, I beg to recommend that Esquimau's School, in addition to being a day school, be also admitted by the Department as a boarding school.

Owing to the distance that some of the members and adherents of this Church reside from the day school, it is impossible for them to send their children.

If children are to be compelled to attend school, I think that reasonable accommodation should be provided for them.

I would more urgently recommend this form of school from the fact that on several occasions I have endeavoured to dissuade the

Sir:

With reference to Erminskin Boarding School, I beg to state that I consider that it is very much to be deplored that there appears to be a hitch about the money grant which we expected would be forthcoming for the maintenance of the school.

From your letter No. 010, of the 1st March, I took it for granted that arrangements were being made by you to put this school on a per capita basis, and as the Church had secured the services of an excellent staff of teachers and as it was very noticeable that the children were making very rapid progress, especially in the English language, and also such work as will be a permanent benefit to them after they leave the school, I assisted Rev Father Gabillon in selecting, from those families who live at too great a distance to attend the day school, to the number of twelve pupils.

Now the school have on their hands those twelve pupils without any means of clothing them, and only receive a very small portion of the provisions required for them to live on, from the Department.

With

The Asst Indian Commissioner.

Regina.
With these facts before you, I hope that you will see your way clear to supply the school with the ordinary money grant, which the promoters expected; however should you not be able to do this, then it seems to me that the Department should grant them a sufficient amount of clothing and provisions which would be the equivalent of the per capita grant, until the money is forthcoming.

I understand that this has been done in other parts of the Territories under similar circumstances.

I am, etc.

sgd D.L. Clink.

I beg to say that I regret very much that our application for the increased number of pupils for Ermin-skins Boarding School was too late to be placed in the Estimates, could you not have it placed in the supplementary Estimates.

A new building is, I understand, to be erected in the spring which will accommodate considerably more than forty pupils.

The staff will be quite able to take charge of even more than the number asked for. There is probably no other school, of this class, nearer the line of Railway, in the Territories than this one, hence we will in all probability have from time to time a large number of distinguished visitors from the East.

Now when you consider that we will have the building and the staff and that the Government has to feed and clothe those children in any case, why not add them to the school and have a proper training that they may have a better chance in life.

Sir:

I beg to write to you on the subject of the Boarding School at Hobbema.

It is nearly two years since this school was opened, and the Department has not yet given it any grant in money, either for the board or clothing for the children which have been received in it.

On the 7th of July 1895, the Department granted $00.00 (in fact) for each child; but Mr Clink, your Agent notwithstanding all his good will and interest which he had towards the school, has only been able to furnish a small portion of what had been allowed; so that a great part of the expense of this school, since its opening, has been borne by the Rev Sisters. These nuns, in order to procure what was necessary for their boarding pupils, have been obliged to incur considerable debt, and declare that they can no longer continue this system. They pray you then to arrange that the grant which you allow them be made in money instead of being in kind.

You have heard, yourself, in what manner they are obliged to live, they and the children who are intrusted to
to them, it would only be right that the Department granted at least to their school the means of supporting viz:- what they grant to other institutions of this description, $72.00 in money per child, each year.

I trust, sir, that you will do all in your power to grant their request.

Yours, etc.

sgd J.O. Perrault, Priest.

The improvements therefore that I think are most urgently needed are:

I. More room in sleeping apartments.

II. A better means of ventilation E.G. A pipe from each room to acupola and controlled by a trap or grate.

III. A chance to play in all kinds of weather outside of both school-room and dormitory E.G. In a well furnished gymnasium.

These additional privileges, with what they have, and all properly used, should, I think warrant a far greater degree of health among children attending that institution than could be found among those on the Reserves.

Hoping this may commend itself to you and the Department I remain, etc.

sgd E.M. Sharpe M.D.
in the rooms. The ventilation is very poor. In the school room the only means for it are the doors and windows, while in the bedrooms there is only one window for each. This is kept open at night during the summer, but owing to the strong draughts, that a wind may cause that mode of ventilation is not always desirable, while in winter it is quite objectionable.

If those beds were filled, and the windows closed, as they would likely be, at least in the coldest weather, by morning the rooms must contain such foul air as to very much increase the susceptibility to tuberculosis.

I found present fifteen pupils (6 boys and 9 girls) but was told there were often more. They are kept in the school room five hours each day (9--12 & 1--3.30, less 2 recesses of 15 minutes each) In cold weather they are in the building about all the time. Now I think this is a great drawback to any school. I remember when a boy in a country school, that when we could not play outside doors during recess and at noon we made the school room very dusty. How much worse must it be for children who have to live in that house all the time. If they play they raise a dust, just the thing to cause weak lungs and if they don't play they suffer for want of that exercise necessary to develop a good strong
strong physique.

The improvements therefore that I think are most urgently needed are:

I. More room in sleeping apartments.

II. A better means of ventilation E.G. A pipe from each room to acupola and controlled by a trap or grate.

III. A chance to play in all kinds of weather outside of both school-room and dormitory E.G. In a well furnished gymnasium.

These additional privileges, with what they have, and all properly used, should, I think warrant a far greater degree of health among children attending that institution than could be found among those on the Reserves.

Hoping this may commend itself to you and the Department I remain, etc.

sgd E.M. Sharpe M.D.
In July 25th I visited the Reserves of Hobbema Agency, and as you requested (No 0130) I send you a report of the R.C. Boarding School from a hygienic standpoint. The school is nicely situated on elevated ground with good surroundings. The building is a wooden structure about thirty feet square, finished inside with wooden ceilings and walls. In the first flat were two large rooms, one for school purposes and furnished with homemade desks and benches. The other room was furnished as a reception room. Upstairs there were four rooms for sleeping apartments containing in all twenty-five beds. In the boys' room there were twelve beds in girls seven, a third one contained three beds for nuns, while in the fourth were three beds and washing accommodation. All was clean tidy and well kept. The ceilings downstairs were a very good height, but in the upper flat they are too low for so many to be sleeping.

Sir,

I am sorry to have to inform you that Small Pox has made its appearance, and I arrived at the Indian Commissioner last night. There are seven cases of a mild type at the Roman Catholic Boarding School, but Indians came in from Pigem Lake with it pretty bad, and there is another very bad case across the Battle River within a few hundred yards of some Indians and the Battle House.

The Medical Officer is here vaccinating and taking all precautions, and I am arranging to purchase an old Indian house or such reserve house as Hospital, and which can be burned afterwards.

I have notified the Commanding Officer North West Mounted Police that a couple of men should be

The Secretary
Dept of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
be sent here to assist in carrying out any quarantine regulations.

I have taken upon myself the responsibility of arranging about Indian Forces for Hospital. Enclosing Brooms and Medicine (have not allowed me to ask you authority.) I therefore trust you will approve of my action. I can assure everything is being done but Indians are so reckless that it is very difficult to carry out all we could desire.

Have the honor to be,

Yours obediently,
W. H. Grant
Indian Agent
Ex'd.

25 February 1901.

Sir,

I am sorry to have to report small-pox has made its appearance in this district and I wired you last evening to that effect. It came to my notice last week that there was sickness at the Roman Catholic Boarding School, and owing to the many reports going about I immediately sent for the Medical Officer and to bring vaccine points; on his arrival he found there had been seven cases which the Sister Superior thought was chicken-pox, but which turned out to be a mild form of small-pox, and all have appeared amongst the children last come to the School, and who have not been vaccinated.

An Indian arrived here from Pigeon Lake with small-pox pretty bad, and who states he must have got it from Fraser's family, Fishery Inspector out there, and I am having this Indian isolated away from the rest, but I am sorry to say he called in some of the Indian houses coming through the reserves.

There is a very bad case - a girl, daughter of a Half-breed, 16 years, living within a mile of the Battle river cattle range and some Indians.

The Medical Officer is vaccinating man, woman and child having ordered vaccine from Calgary, and he will after doing all on the reserves proceed to

Pigeon

The Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg.
Pigeon Lake where there are several Indians and Halfbreeds and there is no doubt the disease is there.

I have also notified the Commanding Officer N.W.M. Police at Edmonton to send one or two men to see that the school and Indian houses are quarantined.

I am endeavoring to purchase an Indian House on each reserve to use as a Hospital and which can be destroyed afterwards, and can assure you every precaution is being taken that is possible, but you know Indians are so restless that it is very difficult to carry them out as we could wish.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) V.S. Grant,
Indian Agent.

There is one case of pneumonia, very mild, and every precaution is being taken. Another case occurred at Red Bull's but the party has already recovered.

I have the honor to be

October 9th 1871

I visited a few days ago the Indian School on the Edmonton Reserve and I think that the school has a right to receive the $625 grant for each of the 50 pupils attending said school.

The complete system of waterworks, closets and other facilities has been installed and is working in perfect order. The ventilation has been installed according to the demands of the Department.

The Sisters have a separate hospital for pupils who might be attacked by infectious diseases, and it seems to me that the school has a right to the increased grant. The principal will undertake to have the school basement constructed and furnish shall replace the stone in use at present. Such as this was the school is well located and should be encouraged by the granting of the grants of $125.

Ottawa, October 17, 1911.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant in which you ask that the Ermineskins Boarding School be placed in Class "A" and that the maximum grant of $125.00 be allowed.

In reply I beg to say that the accommodation and equipment in this school in all respects except the basement and heating plant are satisfactory and would entitle the school to rank in the grade above referred to. However, as you are aware, one of the requirements for a school of this class is that it shall be built on a stone or cement foundation, with a light and airy basement the full size of the main building with a cement floor, and another is that there shall be a modern heating apparatus, hot water, steam or hot air. The condition of the foundation timbers of the present building is such that the Department doubts whether it is practicable to place a proper foundation under the structure. If, however, you will submit plans showing how it is proposed to put in this foundation and heating plant; then, if considered satisfactory, the Department will upon your assurance that the work will be at once undertaken and carried continuously to completion allow the grant of $125.00 and will make this grant payable from the first of April, last. This is, of course, conditional upon these

Rev. H. Grandin, O.M.I.,
Edmonton, Alta.
these plans being submitted at an early date and the work carried out as above stipulated.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Secretary.

I suppose that you have been notified of the resignation of Rev. F.L. Dauphin, O.M.I., as principal, and of his removing to Cold Lake according to his desire, and that I was left in charge of the Ermineskin Boarding School.

(Signed) P. Moulin, O.M.I.
Hobema 1st October 1915

Dear Sir,

This year, after the holidays, we had many new children at the Boarding School. As you may see by the last report, we have an average attendance of 49 and would have so, had the little Eliza Johnson, adopted child of the councillor Saddleback been admitted in time.

We have yet one more pupil, which makes our number 51. Some Indians are also willing to place their daughters at school, and in the first of December I could have two or three more pupils. But we are only authorised for fifty.

Dear Sir, you have visited yourself our school, the reports of the Inspectors have always been very favorable, often highly satisfactory. In consideration of this, could you not, Dear Sir, grant us the favor to be authorized by the Indian Department to receive in our Boarding School sixty (60) pupils instead of the present number of 50 fifty, consequently to receive the grant of money for all the children who would then be admitted to the school by the Department.

I think also we have the cubic air space required for sixty or near sixty children. We have two class rooms, one = 44 x 24 x 12 ft., a second 22 x 22 x 12 ft.

Boys Dormitory 44 x 24 x 12 ft. Girls Dorm. 48 x 44 x 9 ft.

Hope, Dear Sir, to receive from the Indian Department a favorable answer to my request for the benefit of our B. School and of the Indian children.

Believe me, Dear Sir, your most obedient servant.

P. Macdonald, Principal A.C. B. School

Dear Sir,

Is it possible to raise the pupilage of the Hobbema school from 50 to 60, or at least to 55? Not long ago I visited this school and saw that the Rev. Principal had to refuse children because he was authorised for 50 only. You know as well as myself, how hard it is generally to induce Indians to bring their children to school, and it seems a great pity to have to refuse them when they are well disposed. So if it is at all possible, I would beg of you to grant the increase I ask today.

MEMORANDUM,

Mr. Scott,-

In reference to the application made by the Rev. Father Grandin for an increase in pupilage at the Ermineskins Boarding School I beg to say that a similar application was made last October by the Rev. Father Moulin, the Principal of the school, which was not allowed for lack of funds. Since then the Birtle and Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding schools have been allowed to take an additional number of grant earners.

Reports received show that the Ermineskins School is doing good work and a memorandum prepared by Mr. Chene shows that there is ample accommodation for the additional number of pupils asked for, both in the class-rooms and dormitories.

There are four reserves in the Hobbema Agency and the total number of children of school age is 143. There is an improved day school on the Samson's Reserve, but there are no day schools on the other three reserves.

Father Grandin asks that the pupilage be increased from 50 to 60 or at least to 55. There are 50 now enrolled and the school can accommodate 63. Would
the Department allow an increase of five, making 55 pupils allowed for this school.

[Signature]

With best wishes, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Indian Office Winnipeg,
Oct. 4th, 1916.

Sir,

When I returned to Red Deer I called on Inspector Markle and the following morning September 12th, I took the train for Hobbema where Dr. Welker of Letaskiwin met me and we went through the Institution there. This Institution struck me as being about the most unique one that I have ever come across in my travels. It is thoroughly up-to-date without having bread mixers and washing machines, so the children can be educated into the ways which will be the most beneficial for them for their future environment.

O.I.Grain.
Honored Sir,

Last year, on the recommendation of Rev. Father Grandin O.M.I., you authorized us to receive in our Boarding School 55 pupils, 5 more than previously.

I am this year again compelled to make you a similar request and beg from your kindness to give us the grant for 60 pupils. We have already them present in our school, and if authorized I will forward you the forms for their admission with the certificate of the Doctor.

I am sure you know how sometimes it is a hard question to have the Indian children at school; therefore when they are anxious to come I cannot but be pleased to accept them.

I may say, the way our school is kept (cleanliness and the devotion of the Rev. Sisters to the children) is certainly a great inducement for the Indians to have their children at our school.

With the hope to have soon a favorable answer to my demand

I remain, Honored Sir,

Yours very respectfully,

P. Moulin

Principal of the R.C. Ermineskin P.S. School.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,-

With reference to the application made by the Rev. Father Moulin, Principal of the Ermineskins Boarding School, to be allowed to take five more pupils I beg to say that the grant is now paid for 55 and they have accommodation in the dormitories for 63 pupils and in the class-rooms for 71. This allows plenty of room for the additional number asked for.

The school is doing good work and Mr. Inspector Markle in his last report, which was made on the 26th ultimo, states as follows,- "Class work is satisfactory. The institution is well managed and a credit, I think, to the Church and to the Department". They will have no difficulty in obtaining the extra number of pupils and I think the application might be granted.

[Signature]

Martin Borden
Ottawa, November 22, 1916.

Rev. Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant asking the Department to allow the grant for sixty pupils at the Ermineskins Boarding School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department has decided to grant your request and will pay for sixty pupils at your school from the first of the current quarter.

Your obedient servant,

A.S. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. P. Moulin, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Ermineskins Boarding School,
Hobbema, Alta.
Ottawa, November 22, 1916.

Sr.-

I beg to advise you that the Department has decided to increase the number of grant earning pupils at the Ermineskins Boarding School from 55 to 60 from the first of the current quarter and the Principal of the school has been informed accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Jos. Butlin, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.
Honorable Sir,

I received a few days ago the communication of the Indian Department that we were now authorized for 60 pupils.

Honorable Sir, I am very thankful for your granting my request, specially for your kindness and prompt attention to this matter.

With pleasure I subscribe myself yours very devotedly and thankfully.

P. Moulin

Principal of Drumstick's P.S. School.
Sir,

I have the honor to report that, while Dr. Walker and I were visiting the reserve yesterday, we called at Ermineskin's Boarding School, and found eight cases of measles amongst the pupils, which had not been reported. The Doctor gave instructions to have the cases quarantined in the ward adjoining the school.

The school was visited by the Doctor on the 1st of March, and all pupils in good health, the cases of measles developed since that date.

I might also report that there are a few cases of measles on the different reserves, also a few cases of illness of long standing. The Doctor has visited all cases reported, and who have requested medical attendance.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Erminston Boarding School
Hobema 20th November 1920

Honorable Sir,

A few days ago we had the visit of our Inspector Mr. Christiansen from Regina. He told us that the new compulsory law for schooling the Indian children was to be put in force and therefore all the children from 7 to 15 years of age would have to go to school.

Our Boarding School (Erminston P.) is only authorized for 60 pupils as you may know by the reports. Even if all the children of age for school belonging to our denomination (R. Cath.) are to come to school we will have to find or make place for about 50 more children at the present we have our full number even 61 present.

If really this new law is to be executed we should be advised by the authorities and as my superior told me:

Will the Indian Department grant us authorization for one hundred (100) or more pupils provided we build an addition to our present Boarding School?

We would be ready and willing to make such an expense if we are made certain that the Indian Department will grant us such an increase in the number of our pupils and if the department will also oblige all children of school age and good health to come to school.

It will be a very good step for the advance of the Indians.

Please, Honorable Sir, accept my most respectful salutations.

Yours very sincerely,

Rev. P. P. McLean
Principal 1918-1920
December 15th, 1920.

Rev. P. W. Moulin, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Ermineskin's Boarding School,
Hobbema, Alta.

I have your letter of the 20th ultimo in which you ask whether the Department, in the event of necessary accommodation being provided, would increase the pupilage at the Ermineskin's boarding school from 60 to 100. In reply I beg to say that it is not possible for me to make a definite promise at the present time. This large increase would involve a considerable sum of money which would have to be provided by Parliament, as the vote for Indian Education as it now stands would not bear this extra call upon it. I shall, however, endeavour to have the necessary funds provided at the next session of Parliament and if successful will communicate with you again.

Yours very truly,

Rev. P. W. Moulin, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Ermineskin's Boarding School,
Hobbema, Alta.
Regina, December 7th, 1920.

To W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

Here there are 33 girls and 27 boys. Examination of these children showed none requiring surgical or hospital treatment. There are no cases of suppurating glands of the neck or other parts and though fully 50% have enlarged glands of the neck they would not be looked upon as requiring anything more than good hygienic surroundings, food and fresh air to become cured. There are no children in the school who should be sent home though four boys and three girls are found to be below par in general condition, are anaemic and have enlarged glands, but I believe the extra care now being given them viz; extra diets of milk and eggs, cod liver oil and iron tonics, and their being kept out of doors as much as possible, should be sufficient to bring them up to a standard of good health. The eyes are in good condition, though in the case of four pupils the usual bathing with Boric acid solution and the occasional use of Argyrol are necessary to keep them in good condition. Two pupils have blindness of one eye from infantile infections and two others have partial blindness for the scar of an old ulceration of the cornia long ago healed.

The teeth of all are passably good, and none are showing signs of any active involvement of the lungs.

The General health, weight and color of the pupils of this school are fully up to the standard.

The building itself is an old one but fairly good, is kept very clean and is fairly light and airy.
The dormitories are now somewhat crowded. Thirty-three now sleep in one room where the maximum capacity should be 28. The windows are very small though fairly numerous and the ceiling is a foot or two lower than is desirable. There are several fairly good balconies but they are not used as much as they should be. The addition of a modern building to the one now in use is very desirable as the present capacity is overtaxed and there are still a number of children on the reserve not attending school. The present building is too good to be condemned but in time should be replaced by one more modern.

F. A. Corbett, M.D.
Commissioner's Office,
Regina, Sask., Dec. 5, 1920.

Dear Sir:

The situation at Hobbema is very satisfactory, although the School and Dormitories are not what you would call ideal; however, I do not consider the children's health is in any way impaired through attending the School. The building is old, but kept spotlessly clean - and above all, the children are well clad and well fed - I understand there are between forty and forty-five Roman Catholic children still on the Reserves at this Agency, who are not attending School. A request was made to have additional accommodation provided. This matter will no doubt have to receive the attention of the Department at an early date, as educational facilities will have to be obtained.

W. M. Graham,
Commissioner.

DeGroot, Sec.,
Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Honourable Sir James Lougheed,

I beg to send herewith important reports from the Indian Commissioner and Doctor F. A. Corbett, of Regina.

When I was in Regina last summer I had an interview with Doctor Corbett, and it was arranged that he should make these inspections. Doctor Corbett is greatly interested in the welfare of the Indians, and his report justifies the inspection.

I regret extremely that it is possible to draw such a comparison between the Protestant and Roman Catholic schools. The Crowfoot, Arminekin's and St. Albert schools are all conducted by the Roman Catholic Church, and the Old Sun's and Sarcee are conducted by the Church of England. The comparison does not hold good over the whole field, however, as we have excellent protestant schools in other parts of the country. The Anglican schools in the diocese of Calgary have always unfortunately been badly managed.

The conditions at the Old Sun's school are disgraceful, and the principal and medical attendant are worthy of serious censure for allowing such health conditions to exist.

As you are personally aware of the general conditions at the Sarcee reserve, this additional information with reference to the school and the Indians there will be of special interest. If this land is to be saved at all we must take vigorous measures and I would propose to turn the school into a hospital and to treat the whole reserve as a hospital area. These Indians have a large reserve and more of it should be turned into cash as soon as possible and used for their benefit, and the funds we have on hand should be fully used.

It would be advantageous if Doctor Corbett could continue his inspections and visit all our reserves and schools, but as he has a large practice in Regina, I do not think we could expect him to spend the necessary time in making inspectorial visits.

I should like to discuss these matters with you.

Duncan G. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

548486

Ottawa, February 15, 1921.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Rev. Father Moulin, Principal of the Indian Boarding School on Ermineskin's Reserve, has asked if it would be possible to have the Department pay for the erection of a telephone line from the school to the Agency headquarters, which would then give him connection with the Rural System.

The material used in connection with this work would be fifteen posts and sufficient wire for three-quarters of a mile of line. The total cost with labour included and rental of rural system for one year would be $114.00. Could not this expenditure be charged to Ermineskin's Band Funds?

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
February 15, 1921.

Dear Mr. Graham,

With reference to your memorandum of the 15th instant, I have to say that you may inform the Principal of the Ermineskin's Indian boarding school that we will approve of the erection of a telephone line from the school to agency headquarters which would give him connection with the rural system, the cost to be charged to the Interest Funds of the Ermineskin's band.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Ottawa.
MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

The Travelling Nurse reports that, at the Ermineskin's Boarding School, in February 1922, she found the Boys' Dormitory overcrowded. Favourable consideration should not be given to requests for increased pupilage until such time as more accommodation has been provided.

Ottawa, April 25, 1922.
Erminstion Boarding School
Hobema 23rd Oct. 1922

Honorable Sir,

About the Twentieth of November 1920, I had the honor of writing to you about being authorized to increase the assistance and number of children to our Boarding School.

The Inspector of the Indian Department, Mr. Christianson, from Regina, had told us of the compulsory law for the education of the Indian children.

I was then writing:

"you know that our Boarding School - Erminstion Boarding School - is only authorized for 60 pupils. (Since last spring only 1922 we have been authorized to take 70 pupils, 10 more than before for what I am very thankful.) If all the children of school age belonging to our denomination, i.e., R. Catholics, are to come to school, we will have to make place for about 50 more pupils. If this law is to be put in force we should be advised by the authorities and then will the Indian Department grant us authorization for about 100 to 120 pupils provided we build a sufficient addition to our Boarding School?"

We were at the time thinking of enlarging the school. We were speaking of
building in order to accommodate 25 to 30 more pupils.

Since then, speaking with his Grace, the archbishop of Edmonton, R.R. O'Leary who is our superior, he encouraged us to build a certain addition if the Indian Department be willing to give us, when we are ready, the grant for about 100 pupils.

Furthermore, he said it would be better and more just to ask the Indian Department to build at its own expense as it is for the interest and the advancement of its wards, or at least to grant us a certain sum for the building.

In fact, after an examination of the number of R.Catholic children of school age, I find that on Louis Bull's Reserve there are 8 children of our denomination, and only 3 are enrolled in our Boarding School.

On Eymunski's Reserve there are about 48 children, only 17 in the school; some of the others are coming as day scholars although we have no day school authorized for them.

On Jamson's Reserve there are about 46 children of ours, and 34 of them only at school.

From Montana Band on 9 catholic children 5 only are in.

Total: 89 children in school and about 69 out of school.

Honorable Sir, I expose these facts and desiderata to you, with the sincere hope that something in the near future will be done in order to give more
accommodation to a greater number of children; or the Indian Department will encourage us to build and assure us that we will be authorised for such a number as a hundred pupils, or yet better, that the Indian Department will grant us a sum for building purposes with authorisation to receive as many pupils as we can take in the school, or if necessary after taking up by pupils without authorisation, if you so desire, I shall myself will build a new house (School). I remain,

Honorable Sir,

Yours very sincerely

Rev. P. P. Moulton

Principal of the Erinmakin B. School.
ERMINSKIN INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL

1o-PUPILAGE:- Increase in proportion of the planned enlarging of the School as outlined in the next request.

2o-ENLARGING OF SCHOOL:- The accompanying letter gives all details in connection with the enlarging of the school and consequently the increase in pupilage. Rev. Fr. Grandin highly favors the plans set forth by the Rev. Principal and for my part totally endorse this project.

[Signature]

[Stamp]
Ottawa, Dec. 15, 1922.

Reverend Sir:-

I have to acknowledge receipt of your communication of the 23rd of October, directed to this Department by the Rev. Father Guy of this city. I have noted your request that the Department either enlarge the building at the Ermineskin Boarding School or arrange for a greater pupilage, in the event of the Church Authorities erecting an addition. I have also learned that there are a large number of Roman Catholic Indian children in the vicinity, that could be recruited for the institution.

In reply I regret to state that, as there are so many pressing claims on the Parliamentary Appropriation for Indian Education, it will not be possible for this Department to undertake building operations at Hobema at the present time. However, it is our earnest wish that there be a development in the work of educating the Indian children of Canada, and I am pleased to inform you that the pupilage of the Ermineskins Boarding School will be increased from 70 by any number up to 30 for which you may see fit to provide accommodation. Our inspectors will report on any new building that you may erect for the purpose of educating the Indian children, and you will be informed at that time of the exact pupilage allowed.

I wish to add that every reasonable assistance will be given by our officers in recruiting pupils, if more accommodation is added by the Church Authorities.

This Department wishes you, the staff and the pupils of the Ermineskin Indian Boarding School the compliments of the Season.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. P. P. Moulin, D.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Boarding School,
HOBEMA, ALTA.
Dear Sir,

Although it was quite a while ago since I had your kind letter, I will not forget to thank you and the Indian Department for your willingness to increase the number of pupils in the Erminieton Boarding School, when the said school will provide for their accommodation.

Recently I have seen my superiors and when the spring will be here we will start the enlarging of our school: 30 x 45 basement, main floor, 2 stories and attic. We hope to be ready in the month of August to receive a larger number of Indian children.

I remain, Dear Sir,
Yours very thankfully and sincerely.

Rev. P.P. Moulin
Principal of Erminieton B.D. School.
Ottawa, July 20, 1923.

Dear Father Guy:

I wish to acknowledge your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to the present building activity at the Ermineskin Indian Boarding School. I have noted that the cost of the addition, which is being erected by the school authorities, will be about $5,000 more than was planned at the outset.

I believe that the Deputy Superintendent General is favourably disposed towards assisting with capital expense, when funds can be found or provided for the purpose. I wish to suggest that all accounts and tenders be kept in order and that a statement concerning the activity, generally, be prepared. This could be brought to Dr. Scott's attention when you return from the West.

I am pleased to state that the Department can arrange to grant an increase in pupilage in the immediate future, and I shall communicate with the Indian agent, with a view to arranging for such increase without delay.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy Secretary.

Rev. Jos. Guy, O.M.I.,
697 Mobermot Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
Ottawa, July 20, 1923.

Sir:

The Department has learned that an addition is being constructed at the Ermineskin Indian Boarding School. I should be pleased if you would indicate the nature of the addition and the extra classroom and dormitory accommodation for both boys and girls. This information is needed, so that we can intelligently increase the pupilage at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. G. Askey, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.
Commissioner's Office,
Regina, Sask., June 14, 1923.

Dear Mr. Graham,

Ermineskin Boarding School.

The church authorities are building a new addition to the school; work had commenced at the time of my visit to the reserve. The size of the new building is 35 x 45; three story, with full size basement. The ground floor of this building is to be utilized for two classrooms; the second floor for Boys' dormitories, and the third floor for the Girls' dormitories. The building will be modern-steam heated, running water, and electric lights. The estimated cost is $15,000.00.

I examined the classroom work, and according to the register there are twenty-five children in grade one, twenty-four in grade two, nine in grade three, and nine in grade four, and six in grade five. I might say that this is an exceptionally well-conducted school. The building throughout is well kept and everything in perfect order. The children look healthy and are well-fed and well-clothed. The classroom work is good. The children in the senior classes, especially, are bright and alert, more so than in any other Indian classroom I have visited. I have no hesitation in saying that the school is doing a good work among the Indians.

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Sir,— In compliance with the instructions of your letter No. 112-1-I dated the 20th instant, referring to the addition which is being constructed at Ermineskin's Boarding School. I have the honor to report as follows:

The addition is a frame building 34 x 45 - three stories and basement. In the basement there will be a furnace room and play room for the children.

First floor, two class-rooms 22 x 34 each. Second floor has a dormitory for boys, 34 x 45, and the third floor has a dormitory for girls, 34 x 45.

The present school provides accommodation for 70 pupils, and with the addition it should be sufficient for at least one hundred pupils.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 7, 1923.

Sir:

I have your No. 7 of the 24th ultimo, with reference to the addition provided by the Ermineskin Indian Boarding School.

I have to inform you that, as from October first, next, the pupilage at this school will be increased. Per capita grant will be allowed up to, and including, 100 pupils, based upon the total actual attendance. Please inform the principal.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. G. Ankey, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.
Ottawa, August 7, 1923.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the pupilage at the Ermineskins Indian Boarding school has been increased to 100, as from October first, next. This action has been taken, following Mr. Inspector Christianson's report and a recommendation from the local agent.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
