To attached Invoice.

Contract Plumbing & Heating.
Mr. Dunbar Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear Mr. Scott:

In the course of previous conversations and in my letter of July 2nd, 1923, I have asked financial help from the Department in favour of Brimskin Indian Boarding School.

As you are aware a three-story annex (34'x45') with basement (subfloor) has been constructed in the course of last year giving accommodation as follows:

- 1st floor: 2 class rooms, each 28'x24'x12'
- 2nd floor: dormitory for boys, each 36'x45'x12'
- 3rd floor: dormitory for girls, each 34'x45'x10'

The total expense has reached $16,706.68 and it was my suggestion to ask from the Department, if this school of Brimskin is eventually to be sold to the Government, to reimburse the Sisters of the Assumption on the amount of the above outlay, same to be considered as an account on the price to be paid for the school. A lien could be secured on the property in order to protect the rights of the Government.

I enclose the accounts for the general contract and for the Plumbing and Heating and take the liberty of heartily recommending that a generous course be followed in this instance.

Hoping that a favourable answer will be given to the present request, I remain

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

[Handwritten note:]
Not a school
That I had visited
as on the school trip
In 1920 the Rev. Principal of the Ermineskins Indian Residential School signified his intention of erecting an addition to the building and asked the Department to increase the pupilage. Favourable consideration was promised. In 1922 the Principal indicated that he had been requested by Archbishop O'Leary of Edmonton to ascertain if the Department would bear part of the capital expense and he suggested that, if we could not, he would like a definite promise of an increased pupilage. A per capita grant for 100 was promised if the addition was erected by the Church Authorities.

Last year Father Guy drew your attention to the financial condition of the school. They had commenced an addition and found that the bills would run to at least $15,000, which was $5,000 more than they had intended. Financial assistance was requested. The Department required that all accounts and tenders be kept and that a statement concerning the activity be prepared.

Father Guy has now presented accounts totalling $16,706.68 which refer to expenditure on the new wing. These bills have apparently been paid by the school management. The Oblate representative requests that we reimburse the Sisters of the Assumption, who appear to be the owners, and take a lien on the property to protect our equity. Father Guy suggests that this school be purchased by the Government eventually. As the main building is not modern I had not considered it as one the Department should purchase. When the school was built in 1897 and in following years the Department met capital expense amounting to more than $4,500.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, March 6, 1924.

Dear Father Guy:

I have your letter of the 15th ultimo, with reference to a grant to assist the Erminekins Indian Residential School. I regret to inform you, in reply, that the appropriation for this fiscal year has been completely assigned and I am unable to give your request favourable consideration.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Jos Guy, O.H.I.,
University of Ottawa,
Ottawa, Ont.
Regina, Sask., April 3rd 1924.

Dear Mr. Scott;-

I have just returned from the Province of Alberta, where I have been for nearly three weeks. I visited the Blood, Peigan, Sarcee, Blackfoot, Hobbema and Edmonton Agencies, and eight Indian Boarding Schools.

HOBBERMA AGENCY.

I visited the school, which is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. I found everything in first class shape, the children well fed, well clothed and healthy. Since my last visit here the school has been almost doubled in size, and the building is now all that we require. I spoke to the Reverend Father of the necessity of giving the boys more outside training. There is no farm in connection with the Institution. I pointed out to the principal that if he would farm even 80 acres, and did it well and in a modern way, it would be a great benefit to these boys who are in their teens. The Father assured me he would do something in this line at an early date. The Government should arrange to have a piece of the Indian Reserve set aside for this purpose. It does not necessarily mean it should be bought. The Indians have more land than they can use. Let the school authorities have a quarter section.

(Sgd.) W.M. Graham,

Indian Commissioner,
D.C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. Gen. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 22, 1924.

Sir:

I am directed to refer to that portion of your general letter of the third instant, concerning the advisability of releasing a quarter section of the Indian reserve for the benefit of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. I should be pleased if you would take steps to have a suitable quarter section set aside for this purpose. A Resolution of the Band in Council should be secured, if possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., June 18th, 1934

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that when I visited the Ermineskin School last Fall, I found that the school had been teaching practically no Agriculture. This struck me as being entirely wrong, to have boys of 15 and 19 years of age discharged from the school and knowing absolutely nothing about plowing or the growing of grain. They might just as well have been attending day school, because they would get a certain amount of farm training at home.

I understand that these Indian Boarding Schools are for no other purpose than for teaching the boys to become useful to their parents when they return home, and have a certain amount of knowledge of how to carry on farming.

I discussed this matter with Father Moulin, the Principal, and he said that he would be glad to start a farm if they could get the land. I never thought for a minute that there would be any doubt about getting all the land he required, as this has never been questioned at other reserves. I instructed the Agent to see the Indians and get them to agree to hand over a certain amount for the purpose mentioned.

Duncan J. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
It appears now that Father Moulin told them he was not particular about undertaking the work of running a farm, as he was no farmer, and could not stand the expense of engaging an instructor, buying machinery, etc., and besides the boys had plenty of work at the school. This statement was made by the Indians to the Agent, who in turn went to Father Moulin who corroborated it; a most extraordinary action for the Principal to take, in my opinion.

Is it your intention to insist on a certain amount of farming instruction being given at these schools or not? The matter should not end here.

For your information I may say that this school has four acres of garden, and 120 acres of pasture land.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, June 28, 1924.

Reverend Sir:

It has been brought to the attention of the Department that the older boys, pupils of the Ermineskins Indian Residential School, are receiving very little training in farming and other outside work. We understand that at present there are 4 acres of garden and 120 acres of pasture land in connection with the school. The question of having the Indians release one quarter section of the reserve for the benefit of the school is receiving consideration.

I am sure you will see advantage to the boys after leaving the school in having a good general knowledge of farming operations, the care of stock and the raising of crops. The Department would therefore emphasize the value of a training in this work to the older boys and I have to request that this matter receives your attention and that you will make every effort to give the boys a good practical training in farm work. We are requesting the Indian Commissioner to endeavour to arrange with the Indians to set aside a quarter section of reserve land for the use of the school, in order that farming work can be carried on for the benefit of the school and for the instruction it will give to the boys.

I shall be pleased to hear from you, outlining the plans which you can undertake to carry out the Department's wishes in arranging that the boys will receive a practical training in farming operations.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. P. P. Moulin, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Ermineskins Indian Res. School,
Hobbema, Alta.
Ottawa, June 28, 1924.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your No. 604-11A of the 18th instant, regarding the instruction the boys are receiving in farming at the Ermineskin Residential School. I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter that is being directed to the principal in the matter. I note that you have instructed the agent to have the Indians set aside a certain amount of land from the reserve for school purposes. It is considered that a quarter section at least should be obtained from the Indians, if possible. I agree with you that it is very important that the Indian boys receive a practical training in farming operations, in order that they may have a certain amount of knowledge of farming to carry on after they leave school.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Dear Sir,

A few days ago I received your letter of the 28th of June requesting me to state what we could do for a better training of our older boys in farming and taking care of the stock.

For a few years past I have been thinking this question over knowing fully well the benefit that our boys could gain by it, the better renown of our school and as a means also to keep with us all our children.

Recently the Indian agent by order from the Indian Commissioner asked the Indians to lease for 5 years the land for the use of the school. When I heard of the 5 years lease I told him I was not anxious about it at all and even would not accept it for only 5 years but as long as the school would be there. Moreover as the land asked for was in the settlement of some Indians it was voted down by the members of the Band.

Really at the present time I do not see the possibility of going into the expenses of a farm. You know that last year we went into debts to the extent of $16,000.
We need a modern laundry system. Last year the washing by hand took nearly two days every week to the prejudice of the school work. We have asked and are yet asking the Department to grant us a more modern system of a Laundry.

It is why, dear Sir, we can not for the present go into other expenses for farming purposes, buying stock, of machineries, of fencing land.

But I may say, as soon as we can see clear through our debts we will take in hand this training of our pupils, even if we can not get land from the Indians we will take on our pasture 40 to 50 acres for this farming purpose.

Also if the Department would grant us the necessary implements, maybe we could very soon carry out the wishes of the Indian Department and our earnest desire to give our older pupils a very good training in all farm work.

With my regretful oblations,

I remain, dear Sir,

Yours truly,

Rev. P. P. Moulis, A.M.,
Principal, Erminville Residential School.

Ottawa, August 11, 1924.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your No. 404-11A of the 25th ultimo, with reference to the farming instruction at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. The Rev. Father Moulin has indicated his willingness to give some instruction to the older boys, but states that he is unable to meet the expense incidental to initiating such training. Some $15,000 debt was incurred last year in the erection of new buildings and the Rev. Principal hesitates to undertake a new activity without assistance. He is prepared to commence farming some forty or fifty acres of their present pasture, if the Department will grant implements and stock.

I am favourably disposed to assisting the school management with this new activity and I should be pleased if you would make a recommendation concerning what equipment and stock should be supplied.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Indian Commissioner,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,

REGINA, SASK., August 16th, 1924.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, No. 118-1-1 with reference to the farming instruction at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School.

I note that Father Moulin has indicated his willingness to give some instruction to the older boys, but states that he is unable to meet the expense incidental to such training.

I think I had better wait until I go to the Ermineskin reserve myself next, or till the Inspector makes a visit there, because if we are going to grant any assistance we want to have it thoroughly understood that the work will be carried on with zest, and if the Father is indifferent about it we had better not begin.

40 acres of land to begin with is too little, and I do not think it would be wise to put in a full line of equipment and stock unless we are prepared to do farming on a fairly decent scale. The season is fairly well advanced and nothing can be done in this matter until next Spring.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Regina, Sask., Sept. 17th, 1926.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that I left here on August 28th, to visit some of the Western Agencies.

HOBBEMA AGENCY:

While at the Agency I visited the Roman Catholic School, and found everything in connection with the institution in good shape. The building was clean from basement to garret. The matter of taking this school over by the Department is under consideration. I doubt very much whether satisfactory work can ever be carried on with these old buildings, and it appears to me that the money that would be spent on this old school, with an addition, would be better applied in building a new, modern school. The Principal of the school concurs in this. However, I had no opportunity of discussing the matter with Archbishop O'Lary, but it should be thoroughly investigated before any purchase is made. I know I have your instructions to do this, but I thought it wise just to let you know the condition of the building before going any further in the matter.

The school, as you know, started a small farm two years ago, and this year they have thirty acres of wheat, and a fine field of oats. A small amount of breaking has been added to this farm this year; about eight acres.

On the whole, I would say that this school is obtaining good results.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir,

A few days ago I returned from France and was sent back by my superior to Hobbema to be in charge of the Ermington Res. School and of the Indian Mission. As in the past I will do my best to cooperate with the Indian Department for the welfare of our Indians.

It is with great pleasure that I take this opportunity to express my best thanks and sentiments of gratefulness to the said Department and especially to the General Superintendent of the said Mission for his kindness in sending me so different games and a bathing over.

Honorable Mr. Scott,
Deputy Supt. Gen of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Honorable Sir,

Four years ago, it was a question of selling the Ermineskin Residential School to the Indian Department, and Mr. Graham of Regina came to see the buildings.

As they were wood buildings and partially old, he was not in favor of buying them but said that it was only a matter of a few years before the Indian Department would build another school with all modern conveniences; then, is the Indian Department decided to do it in the near future?

At the present time we have 120 pupils in the School (number we are authorized for). There are moreover on our Reserves about 40 pupils of our faith, who should be in School. In 1922 the Rev. Sisters built an addition at their own expenses ($15,000) the accommodation is yet rather small and we consider that we will have to do something ourselves if the Indian Department does not intend to build us another school.

Could we then be authorized to have the grant for 160 pupils? If the Indian Department will authorize us to take that number, we would consider the means of building another addition to the school. We would make it quite spacious and if possible in Brick.

With respectful salutations

I remain, Honorable Sir,

Yours very truly,

Dear Father Moulin:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to increasing the accommodation at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. At the present time, the Department is not disposed to recommend the appropriation of funds for a new building. Further, the advisability of increasing the present accommodation is in doubt, as I understand there is plenty of accommodation for Indian children at the residential school at St. Albert. The Department considers it advisable to enlist for the St. Albert School those Roman Catholic Indian children for whom you have no room.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Hobema, Alta., February 28, 1929

Dear Sir,

Over a month ago, I asked the Honorable Deputy Minister Duncan Scott, if the Indian Department would not consider, in the near future, the building of a new modern school to replace the actual Ermineskin Residential School.

The answer was negative. He recommended to enlist our Indian children for Saint Albert School. It is a very hard proposition, as you know very well.

I am not to refuse the children that the parents are bringing to us. In the past years, I had too much hardship to make them understand a little, the great benefit of a good education.

We have already a few more pupils than the number we are authorized for; 120; and after Easter, many others will be brought to our school.

Would you please, authorize us to take 130 children in our Residential School? We will surely find place to accommodate them very well.

I remain, dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 7th of March stating your regrets that the Department cannot increase the pupilage at the Ermineskin Residential School.

I am very sorry to hear that. Could it not be possible to have at least four or five more? We have over 135 now and moreover every day we give instruction in our school to four children of Mr. John White, the interpreter at the Indian Agency, for which we receive nothing.

You advise me to follow the instructions of the Deputy Superintendent General and recruit children for the St. Albert School, where it seems, as they stated recently to some of our staff, that they have no limit to their pupilage.

I beg to say that, if the Rev. Sisters of St. Albert would go and recruit on the Reserves of Edmonton Indian Agency, also keep their children well in school till they are 16 or 17, they would then fill their school easily. I cannot recruit for St. Albert's School on our Reserves as I would certainly have the parents against me, and it would bring more harm than good.

I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA
COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE
REGINA, SASK., Feb. 14th, 1930

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that while at the Hobbema Agency I inspected the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. At the time of my visit there were 117 children in residence, and as an addition had been built to the school last summer, which had been financed by the Church authorities, they informed me that as soon as the necessary beds, etc., were received they would have accommodation for 145. As there had been some reports to the effect that there were a number of children of school age on the reserve who were not attending school I went thoroughly into the matter with the Principal and the Agent and instructed them that as soon as the addition was ready they should personally recruit these children, in order to bring the number of pupils up to the maximum for which they had accommodation.

I also gave instructions that if any Protestant children of school age were found on the reserve they should be sent to Edmonton. I believe there are 39 children now at Edmonton from this agency. From what I gathered I believe Mr. Askey is doing all he can to recruit children for the different schools. The time will probably come when he will have to take stronger measures to send some of the children to school, as I heard him talking to several of the parents, and from the conversation-

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
conversation I could tell that they had no intention of sending their children to school if excuses would keep them out. You are aware that down on the Blood Reserve if the Agent did not take strong measures only about half the children would be attending school, as the Indians there had just made up their minds that they were going to beat the Government to it. I am fully conversant with what I am talking about as I have had the actual experience there, and I am of the opinion that it is sometimes necessary to take a strong stand in regard to this matter as I do not think there is any excuse for Indians keeping their children out of school where the school is on the reserve. Of course, where the children have to be sent miles away from the agency it throws a different light on the matter, because I can understand that Indian parents have the same aversion as white people to sending their children a long way from home.

I found everything around the school in A1 condition; the children are well cared for and everything around the place was clean and tidy as it always is. The work in the classrooms is also good. The only thing that I am worried about at this institution is fire. It is a long rambling building, two and a half storey, all of frame, and if a fire were to start in it, it would go up like powder, but evidently they have all the fire protection that can be arranged for in a building of this nature. If a fire did start it would not be a question of getting it extinguished, but rather a question of getting the children out. Fire drill is held regularly, and Mr. Askey takes a great interest in it and visits the school quite often for this purpose. The new addition and repairs put on by the Church authorities this year amounted to between seven and eight thousand dollars.

-They have-
They have 12 cows at the school. This, in my opinion, is not a sufficient number for an institution that has 145 pupils, besides staff, and as you will realize, there are always times when some of the cows are not giving milk. The quantity of milk they are receiving at the present time is very small, but they had a number of cows that would freshen shortly. They only have stable accommodation for 12 cows, and I do not suppose the Sisters feel that they are in a position to buy any additional cows or build an addition to the barn. I noticed also that their pig pen is very small, and does not provide sufficient room for the pigs that they wish to raise, but I was told that they could not finance the erection of a better pig sty at the present time.

I may say that in my opinion this institution is doing good work in the agency. I saw a number of young women and men on the reserves that had been discharged from the school and they were certainly a good recommendation for the institution.

While at the agency I was approached by the Missionary, Rev. Mr. Cantlin, the Farming Instructor at the Agency, Mr. McLeod, and Mr. Kramer, with regard to a Day School that has just been opened in the Village. At the present time there are ten children attending this school - three children of the Missionary, one from each of the Farming Instructor's homes, and the other five from the village - children of Elevator men, etc. They are having great difficulty in financing this school, and asked me to take up with the Department the matter of giving a grant to the school. I may say that although there are only two children of school age at the agency now we might, in the changing of staff, have employees there with more children, and it is certainly of great benefit to have a school so
near at hand. The only promise I made these people, however, was that the matter would be submitted to you.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK. Feb. 18th, 1930

Dear Mr. Scott,

I beg to enclose herewith a report on the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, in the Hobbema Agency, which was inspected by Mr. Inspector Christianson.

You will note that at the time of the Inspector's visit there were 117 children in residence. You will also note that there are 39 children from this agency attending the Edmonton School. There are still, however, several children of school age on the reserves who are not attending school, and I do not believe they will ever be sent to school unless steps are taken by the Department to have them taken there by force. On every occasion I have been in Edmonton I have spoken to the Principal of the school there about getting these children into school but he has not had 100% success. I know these children could be sent to school if the Department would agree to have a police officer accompany the Inspector or the Agent when they go out to recruit them.

The children at the Ermineskin's School are apparently well cared for, but it seems to me they are not getting the proper food, when seven or eight cows are supposed to supply milk for 140 people. The Department should insist on the proper amount of milk being supplied to the pupils at our Indian schools. I think that in many cases we are giving medical attention for illness, when the illness could well be avoided. I am sure Dr. Stone will agree with me that when Indian children are not properly fed they are very susceptible

Duncan G. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
to tuberculosis and other complaints.

With regard to the last paragraph of the Inspector's report, I think it is up to Mr. Cantlin and Mr. McLeod to provide for the education of their own children. We have nothing to do with Mr. Kramer, but Mr. McLeod is well paid, and can easily afford to contribute towards the teacher's salary out of his own salary. His position is worth from $175.00 to $200.00 a month, situated as he is.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
February 24, 1930.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 404-11 of the 18th instant, enclosing Mr. Inspector Christiansen's report on the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. It will be possible to allow a pupilage of 140 as from April first, next; but I am today writing to the Reverend Principal, stating that this increase cannot be granted unless a suitable milk supply is provided. I know that there are several hundred children not attending school, and I believe that, next summer, you should arrange to have those that are physically fit sent to Edmonton, using Section 10 of the Indian Act if necessary. Until the pupils from Brandon leave Edmonton, there is no room for others, but it will be a good plan to have a thorough recruiting campaign in August.

The question of assistance to the private school at Hobema will receive consideration if there are more children of our own employees in attendance.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
REGINA, Sask.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., April 12th, 1930

Dear Mr. Scott:

While at the Hobbema Agency the other day I visited the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, and was greatly surprised to see that an addition had been made to this old ramshackle building, which, in my opinion, might be called a fire trap. The situation here is bad, and the addition has not improved matters any.

I understand they have taken in additional pupils and that the number in the school is now 152 and they hope to get it up to 160. This is absurd; 140 is all they should have. I am told by Mr. Askey that they have approval of admissions up to 152, so there is somewhat of a mix-up here; if 140 is the authorized number and 152 applications have been approved there is a surplus of 12 children in the school.

The addition was made by carrying the adjoining one-storey buildings up two storeys high. The attached photograph will show you what the building looks like now.

I am very nervous about this school and I do not think it is at all right to put additional children in there. What is needed badly is an up-to-date school. This reserve can maintain a school with a pupilage of 150 quite easily, and I think the time has arrived when this should be built. I hope the Department will give this matter serious consideration.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
April 15, 1930.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 404-11A R.C. of the 12th instant, with reference to the Ermineaskin Indian Residential School. It is true, there is a great danger from fire in this old building; but the most recent reports indicate that the fire protection is all that can be arranged. Mr. Murison's comment in this connection, of February 14th, last, indicates that fire drill is held regularly and that the Indian Agent and the school management are taking every precaution. As both the school authorities and yourself have been informed, a pupilage of 140 is now allowed. So that grant for this number can be earned, it is all right to have an enrolment of 147 or 148, provided there is adequate accommodation. You might write the Principal, telling him that on no condition should more than 148 pupils be on the roll.

At a later date, we will have to give serious consideration to the question of a new building at this point. When you write the Principal, you should emphasize the Department's wishes concerning fire drill and fire prevention. Neither Mr. Murison nor yourself state that additional fire escapes are required, so I presume that no action in this connection is necessary.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, SASK.
Ottawa, April 16, 1930.

Sir:

Pursuant to the Deputy Superintendent General's letter to you of yesterday's date, I am instructed to have you arrange for the services of a night watchman at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. The Department will allow a grant of $40 a month for this service and considers that the school should be responsible for the man's board. The watchman should be chosen with care and must be a thoroughly reliable person, who will make continuous patrol of the main building at night. Vouchers in this connection should be forwarded once every quarter and should be in favour of the Principal, who will pay the night watchman. Please make the arrangements without delay.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK. Jan. 3, 1931

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that during my inspection of the Hobbema Agency in December I also made an inspection of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School.

At the time of my visit there were 145 children in residence. The work in the classroom I shall not enlarge upon, as the School Inspector had inspected this work on the 1st of December. I may say, however, that I am of the opinion that the classroom work is gradually improving, and the children spoke up much better than they did a few years ago, in fact I think they are receiving a much better education now than they did when I first visited the school.

Since my last visit, new fire escapes have been erected in the building, and while I was there fire drill was held. I was informed that fire drill practise takes place every week. I also found that since my last inspection the school had been connected up with the Hydro Electric Power, which did away with the old lighting plant, and the water is now pumped with a motor

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
instead of an engine.

Everything around the school was in good order as usual, and the buildings are kept in as good a state of repair as possible. I do not need to go into a description of the school building, as both yourself and the Department are thoroughly familiar with it. I have frequently mentioned that due to the nature of its construction, this building would be a fire trap if a fire should occur, but I consider now that every possible precaution has been taken to ensure safety. There are electric alarm bells on each floor that can be sounded by pressing one button, and the additional fire escapes which were erected give the pupils and staff every possible chance of making their escape in case of a fire.

The children were well clothed and presented an exceptionally healthy appearance. Both the boys and girls have five complete changes of clothing. They have two pairs of shoes each, besides moccasins; one pair for every-day, and a pair for Sundays. The girls are instructed in cooking, sewing, mending, darning, and in all branches of housekeeping. Although most of the washing is done by machinery, a certain amount of clothes are washed by hand each week in order to give the girls a training in this line. From April 1st until the freeze-up in the Fall, the girls do the milking, but during the winter months this is done by the boys. The farming—
farming at this school is done in a very small way, and the boys do not receive much training in this line of work, with the exception of gardening, milking, doing chores, etc. At the present time they have 14 cows, 7 calves, two 2-year-old steers and one bull. They were milking 11 cows at the time of my visit, and getting about 20 gallons of milk per day. They have 25 pigs and 200 hens, and the Principal informed me that he was buying some more chickens so as to have an abundance of eggs for the children. They raised a splendid garden, but the potato crop was light on account of the dry weather. However, they will have sufficient for the use of the school, and also plenty of other vegetables.

At the present time the school is recruited up to full strength and above it, as there are 145 children enrolled and the Principal only receives a grant for 140. In going around the reserve I noted that there were quite a number of children of school age at home with their parents. Some of these I believe are Protestant and should go to Edmonton.

During my stay there, Mr. Woodsworth was down to the Agency and I made arrangements with him to come down some time during January and stay a couple of days for the purpose of recruiting some children. You, of course, know the attitude of the Indians there, as soon as steps are taken to recruit for the Edmonton School they flock over to the Roman Catholic School, so as not to have their children sent away. No doubt—
doubt there will be some children discharged from
the Roman Catholic School next summer, which will
leave room for some that are not attending school
at present.

Taking it on the whole this institution,
in my opinion, is doing very good work. The only
thing that I believe could be improved on is the
matter of giving the boys more training along
agricultural lines. The school has only about
sixty acres under cultivation, and naturally this
does not give the boys much chance to learn farming.

Everything else is satisfactory, and the
best of harmony exists between the school and the
Agency.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., January 7th, 1931.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, in the Hobema Agency, which was inspected by Mr. Christianson during the month of December.

The work carried on at this school seems to be satisfactory, excepting, as the Inspector points out, that the boys do not get sufficient training in farming and the care of stock. It is pleasing to note that the girls of this school do the milking during the summer. It is also satisfactory to note that the children are so well clothed, and that a fair quantity of milk is supplied daily to the school. The school has more pupils in the building than I think they should have. I am not going to comment any further on the type of building we have here as the Department are in possession of all the facts.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, January 13, 1931.

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your No. 404-11 of the 7th instant, enclosing Mr. Inspector Christianson's report on his recent inspection of the Ermineskin's Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say it is noted that the general conditions at this school are satisfactory; that the classroom work is gradually improving; that the buildings are kept in as good a state of repair as possible and that the children presented a healthy appearance and were well clothed and fed.

Regarding the pupilage, I would refer you to official letter of April 15th, 1930, in which you were informed that it would be all right to have an enrolment not exceeding 148 pupils.

It is also noted from the Inspector's report that every precaution has been taken to insure the safety of the pupils in case of fire and that each week they receive practice in fire drill.

Ottawa, November 5, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

Your letter of the 15th ultimo, concerning improvements at the Ermineskins Indian Residential School, has been forwarded to the Department by Very Reverend Father Langleis. Father Langleis was informed that consideration would be given to the various requests. I write now with reference to the pupilage which is authorized for your school. It is true that there is air space in the dormitories for some 140 pupils, and perhaps a few more might be safely accommodated; but there is such grave danger of fire in the main building, that the Department must insist that there be no overcrowding whatever. I note there was an average attendance of 141 for the September quarter. This was secured with an enrolment of 148. This return is satisfactory, but I have to urge that you will not take in any more pupils without there being a corresponding number of discharges. As long as you remain in the present building, the Department believes it is not wise to increase the pupilage beyond 140.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. P. P. Moulin, O. M. I.,
Principal,
Ermineskins Residential School,
Hobbema, Alta.
Ermineskin's Residential School,
Hobbema, Alberta. Jan., 8th, 1933

Dear Sir:

In the past months we had some trouble caused by some young men coming around the school, trying to have relations with our girl pupils.

Two of them were Indians and one halfbreed, Lawrence White, 20 years of age and son of the Interpreter at the Indian Agency.

In October three of our girls ran away with them.

I had these young men arrested and they were given a year on suspended sentence by Judge Angus of Metaskiwin.

The case was serious.

Nevertheless since the trial, this Lawrence White has been coming around the school again at night. He wrote and spoke to one of the girls.

Judge Angus does not find that there is matter enough for a conviction.

Could you not give Colonel F. Palmer, Indian agent, order to have this young man driven from the Reserve and if being seen around the school to have him arrested for trespassing.

I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal

Sir:—

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No.112-1-1 of the 14th inst. enclosing a copy of a letter from the Rev. Principal of the Ermineskin's Indian Residential School, regarding Lawrence White and two Indians who had been causing a great deal of trouble, by interfering with the girl pupils.

There is no doubt that these young men have been causing the Rev. Father a great deal of trouble, and I have supported him in every way in his action on this case.

With reference to the second complaint against Lawrence White, there was a considerable delay in getting the magistrate to try the case, as he considered the evidence insufficient.

However, Lawrence White, son of the Interpreter, was tried before Magistrate Angus, at Hobbema, and sentenced to two months at Fort Saskatchewan, on Monday, January 16th.

As soon as this young man has completed his sentence, may I have the authority to order him off the Reserve entirely, and have him treated as trespasser should he return here, as he is not a treaty Indian, and he is quite old enough to go out and earn his own living, and I do not wish his parents to be held responsible for any improper actions of his.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Col. R.H. Palmer,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

Referring to your report for the month of March, last, on the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, it is noted, with respect to fire drill, escapes and protection, that, while the equipment is now in good order, no fire drill is held.

It is of the utmost importance that principals give constant and intelligent thought to the danger of fire. In this connection I would refer to circular letter dated February 6, 1932, sent to the Principals of all Indian Residential Schools. The Department requests that you take up with the Principal of this School the matter of fire drill, informing him that, at the very least, two fire drills per month should be held, one of which should be after the pupils retire at night. The staff and the older pupils should receive definite instructions as to their specific duties during fire drill or in case of fire.

I am enclosing copy of circular letter referred to and would request that you will advise the Department, later, if the instructions contained therein, especially with reference to fire drill, have been carried out by the Principal and staff of the Ermineskin School and if the instructions as set forth in the circular are being complied with in all respects.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Enc.

Colonel R. H. Palmer,
Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.
Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No.112-1-1 of the 5th instant regarding the absence of fire drill at the Ermineskin Residential School of this Reserve.

The reason that no fire drill was held during the month of March was because of the fact that the school grounds were so deeply covered with snow - the month of March being especially stormy - and that a large number of the pupils were suffering from "flu", the Reverend Principal did not dare to take any risk of endangering the health of the children through fire drill.

I am forwarding a copy of your letter to the Reverend Principal, and will see that your instructions with regard to fire drill are carried out as closely as possible.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

R.H. Palmer
Col. R.H. Palmer,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Last April I notified the Indian Department that I had the permission to go to the old country to visit my mother in France.

These happy days are past and now I am back at my work and my superiors returned me to the Ermineskin Reserv. School.

I will again do my best for the work I have at the school and also cooperate with our new Agent Colonel Lewis for the general work amongst the Indians of Kobbema Reservation.

Please accept my most sincere salutations.

Yours truly,
P. Moulton Principal.
Hobbema, Alta., Oct. 5th, 1937.

Sir:

I find a large number of children of school age and over, that have never been to school. These children range from 8 to 13 years of age and I am insisting that all children go to school. At a meeting of the Chiefs I explained to them the "Indian Act" with respect to children attending school, and with the exception of one, I was promised their co-operation and support. I also find a number of young farmers who had neglected attending school and I have asked several of them if I could get a night school started for two nights a week, if they would like to attend and all those I have asked have signified their willingness to attend. This school, if started, will be held in this office. The Chiefs are in favour of this. I spoke to Father Moulin about this and he is going to try and arrange for one of the young priests to act as teacher. It will be undenominational in character. Do you approve of this, please?

A. G. B. Lewis,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 29, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 5th of October, the Department approves the arrangements you have made for conducting a night school at the Agency.

I am extremely favourable towards the operation of such schools and later on would appreciate your advising the results obtained and the plan followed, as such information might assist us in arranging similar courses at other agencies.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A.G.B. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.

But also... I have omitted quite a few others because I am not quite sure of the date of birth and for some, they seem rather to be not very strong...

F. Moulin

Ermineskin Residential School,
Hobbema, Alberta, Nov.10, 1937.

To the Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

Before the estimates of expenses during the coming year, are placed in the House of Commons, will I be permitted to state again, that it is of absolute necessity to have a new School for your Indian Pupils of Hobbema Reservations.

If yet impossible for a couple of years, I would insist on having the Indian Department build an addition: 30' x 40' (2 stories, to our present School) to give us more space, especially for dormitories, so as to increase the pupilage in Ermineskin Res. School from 140 to 160 at least. Fiscal Year: 1st April, 1938, would be greatly appreciated.

I remain,

Yours truly,

P. Moulin
Principal
Ottawa, December 1, 1937.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of November 10th, requesting the Department to provide in the next year's appropriation for an addition to the Ermineskin Indian Residential School.

Very Reverend Father Langlois visited the Department recently and I discussed with him the probable amount that we would have available in next year's vote for repairs and improvements at your school. He expects to visit the Ermineskin School in the near future and will then take up the matter with you.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. P. Moulin, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Ermineskin Residential School,
Hobbema, Alta.
Sir:-

I beg to report that the Rev. Father P.P. Moulin, O.M.I., who has been Missionary and Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School here, leaves tomorrow for Lac St. Anne, to which place he is being transferred by the Superiors of his Order.

The Rev. Father Pratt, who has been for 5 years at Onion Lake School, is to be acting Principal in his place.

This is for your information. I have had no official notification of this change, please.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. B. Lewis,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Copy to Mr. Inspector Schmidt, Calgary.
Extract from letter received by P. Phelan from Reverend U. Langlois, O.M.I., Edmonton, Alta.

I ask the Department of Indian Affairs to kindly note that the following change will soon take place at the Ermineskin School: The Reverend Edward Pratt will become "Acting Principal" in place of Reverend Father Moulin whom we are placing in another position.
Copy sent to Inspector Schmidt

Ottawa,
March 12, 1938.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant the Department has just received a communication from Very Reverend U. Langlois, O.M.I., advising us that Reverend P. Moulin, O.M.I., who has been Principal of the Ermineskin Residential School is being transferred to another field of activity. Father Langlois has nominated Reverend J. E. Pratt, O.M.I., as Acting Principal of the Ermineskin School. This appointment is being approved.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A. G. B. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.
Ottawa,
March 12, 1938.

Very Reverend Sir:

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 26th ultimo which refers to the Principalship of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School the Department approves the appointment of Reverend J. E. Pratt, O.M.I., as Acting Principal.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Very Rev. U. Langlois, O.M.I.,
Oblate Fathers' Provincial House,
9916 - 110th Street,
Edmonton, Alta.
Hobbema Indian Agency,
June 30th, 1938.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith the following report for
the month of June 1938.

I inspected the Ermineskin Residential school
on the 30th and found everything clean and in good order.
Pupils well clothed and healthy. I attended the closing
exercises in the evening as the pupils were leaving the
following day for their summer vacation.

Alfred G.B. Lewis,
Indian Agent.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pagging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is determined by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for whom grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. A return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will credit be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days present of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The column of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The column of the Return should be correctly added and the total placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pagging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is obtained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the rate of the grant allowed. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The column of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pagging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in quarter of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The annual per pupil grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount of grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days present of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively; and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter" means the total number of days' residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The quarterly per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is obtained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount of pupils' grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pacing it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarter per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount of the grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the grant per capita. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
