NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered in this Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry-forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupil in residence during quarter means the total number of days in quarter all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly grant. In no case, however, will any credit be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Principal

Indian Agent

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days pupils have been enrolled on the Roll and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Principal

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will provision be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE:

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, shall payments be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, should any grant be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence at school ended off the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE:

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, so called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. In cases referring to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2 and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the columns under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant for quarter is determined by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I hereby certify that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the School for the Quarter ended Sept., 30, 1948.

Principal

Dated Oct. 29, 1948

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings therein.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in quarter all pupils entered on the Return are included by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the number of pupils attending during quarter.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, shall claims be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. Where owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days' attendance of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per pupil grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per pupil grant. In no case, however, shall claims be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is determined by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The greatest per centage grant due quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per centage grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pasting it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days present in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, shall any grant be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days of attendance of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the rate of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will provision be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entering the Return and is ascertained by adding the columns under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, putting it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, shall any credit be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, any adjustment is made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days pupils are in all cases enrolled on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

June 24, 1952.

Mr. J.H. Wild,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Hobbema, Alta.

The Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School when completing the March Return claimed eighty-one days grant for pupil #0796 Adele Minda. He has neglected to indicate in the Remarks Column the dates when this girl left residence and later returned to residence.

It would be appreciated if you would supply us with this information as soon as possible.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pacing it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days pupils in residence during quarter, and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Principal

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, shall any credit be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

November 17, 1952

Mr. J.R. Wild,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Hobbema, Alta.,

With reference to your letter of November 5th regarding pupils # 0763 and 0774 shown on the September Quarterly Return for the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, in view of the contents of your letter, please advise the Principal that the school was overpaid two days for each of the two pupils. This overpayment will be deducted on the December Return.

The admission of Bella Lightning to the Ermineskin School is approved.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of such residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Ermineskin Residential School for the Quarter ended December 31, 1958.

Principal

Dated December 31, 1958

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

Dated at this

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of the Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. Where owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

FILE 112/23-26-754 VOLUME 1
St. Albert,
January 5th 1895.

My dear Sir:

I am fortunate now to have Nuns on Ermineskin's Reserve. At the present moment all the Indians are away from the Reserve and the Sisters can have but a few children at the school. It seems to me that when going to so much trouble to procure good schools, we should take steps to have the Indians to profit by them.

With but few exceptions, there is no real success in schools, excepting the Industrial or Boarding ones. I therefore pray you to be kind enough to give one of these latter to the Reverend Sisters there.

The Sister Superior has already shown what she is able to do at Onion Lake and I have every reason to believe that she will, if provided with the means, succeed quite as well on Ermineskin's Reserve.

Such means are, the necessary buildings, the grant per capita given by the Department to provide the children with clothing and board.

Relying on your good-will in that respect, I offer you my thanks beforehand.

Yours very faithfully,

(Sgd) X Vital J. Bishop of St. Albert
O.M.I.

H. Reed Esq.,
Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
St. Albert,
January 5th 1895.

My dear Sir:

I send you herewith a letter which I beg you to forward to Mr. H. Reed adding thereto all the recommendations you may think fit.

I am asking of the Indian Department to be good enough to build one Boarding School on Ermineskin's Reserve, next spring. We have gone to considerable expense there for the Indians to procure for them the advantage of a good education. Nuns have come from the Province of Quebec, and to give them proper accommodation nearly $2000.00 have been spent. We have besides given them the Mission House and will next summer, build a house for the Missionary in charge.

It would now be but just if the Department came to our help, erecting a satisfactory house where the children can be accommodated, for classes and necessary adjuncts, and authorizing us to admit at the start 30 to 40 children at the rate of $72.00 per head.

Receive, Dear Sir, my best salutations,

(Sgd) X Vital J. Bishop of St. Albert.

O.M.I.

A. Forget Esq.,
Asst. Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
Sir:-

I enclose translated copy of two letters, one from His Lordship Bishop Grandin to yourself and the second from Rev. Father Leduc to this office, asking a grant for the erection of a suitable building for the purpose of a Boarding School at Ermineskin's Reserve and a per-capita allowance of $72.00 for 30 or 40 pupils.

A Boarding School under the patronage of the Roman Catholic Church on that Reserve under the efficient direction of Sisters cannot but prove successful; and it being further in line with the policy of the Department, I take much pleasure in recommending the application of His Lordship for the same to your favourable consideration.

Should it meet with your approval, I beg to submit the advisability of placing in the estimates the following sums: $2,500.00 towards the building and $2,160.00 maintenance for 30 pupils at $72.00.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient Servant,

To the Deputy of,
The Supt. General of,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Asst. Commissioner,
I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant forwarding a list from His Lordship Bishop Franklin to your office at the Indian Reserve. I have looked over the list and find it contains the names of 30 pupils who are now attending school at the Reserve. The total number of pupils attending school at the Reserve is 40.

In reply I have to say that the Superintendent has estimated the cost of building a new schoolhouse at $2500.00. It is only right that I should add that there is great uncertainty whether these items will be allowed to pass, owing to reasons already given you generally.

Your obedient servant,

The Assistant Indian Commissioner

Regina, N.W.T.
No 365.

Hobbema,
8th November 1895.

Sir:-

I beg to request that you will supply us with, say, one hundred sacks of flour, the greater portion of this would be for Ermineskin's Boarding School, they now have twenty boarders, and I fancy will use about thirty pounds of flour per day.

We have been supplying them out of our Mill flour, but owing to the wheat being damaged by frost, and our poor machinery, the flour is very unsuitable.

We will require some for the Staff here, as we ran out of flour before the Mill started and I issued our own flour to the Indians and we can hardly live on the flour we are making here.

Yours obediently,

(sgd) D.J. Clink.
Indian Agent.

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant forwarding a letter from His Lordship Bishop Grundin and one from the Rev. Father Leduc asking for his great aid in erection of a boarding school building on Brantshin's Reserve and a per capita allowance for 30 or 40 pupils of $72; and in reply I have to say that the Department has estimated for one building to be built up at the Blackfoot agency.

The request of His Lordship Bishop Grundin for a school for Brantshin's Reserve was received too late for the Main Estimates, but provision will be made in the Supplementary Estimates to the amount of $250 for buildings and for the maintenance of 30 pupils at $72 per cap. - $2,160. It is only right that I should add that there is great uncertainty whether these items will be allowed to pass, owing to reasons already given you generally.

Your obedient servant,

The Assistant Indian Commissioner

Regina, N.W.T.

Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith a copy of a letter received from the Indian Agent at Hobbema, requesting to be supplied with 100 sacks of flour for issue to the Boarding School on Ermineskin's Reserve and Employees of the Agency, as the wheat being damaged by frost the flour made at the mill is very unsuitable.

In this connection I would recommend that 70 sacks, covering 7 month's rations for 9 at the Agency and 20 pupils at the School according to the ration allowance, viz: 45 lbs. per month for each ration at the Agency and 30 lbs. per month for each pupil, be ordered from the Ogilvie Milling Company.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of a copy of Mr Inspector Wadsworth's report on the Brimskin's Boarding school; and in reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased to note the progress made by the pupils at this school.

With regard to over-crowding in the dormitories of the present building, the Department trusts that ample accommodation will soon be provided as the sum of £2500 has been provided in the Estimates for buildings. The Department would like to be furnished with a copy of the proposed plan of the new buildings.

In this connection I may mention that it is desirable that arrangements should be made for completing all building operations undertaken on the strength of funds voted for that purpose before the 30th June next. These remarks apply to all the appropriations for buildings for the different schools.

Your obedient servant,

Deputy Superintendent

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina, N.W.T.
Sir:

I am requesting for the sum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2500.00) which has been voted for the construction of our Boarding School. I would feel truly obliged for your kindness in having the said sum forwarded us as soon as possible. We are in a great want of it being the only resource upon which we may count to commence the work of construction.

I am, etc.

Sgd Z. Lizes Pte O.M.I.
Principal.

R.C.Mission.
Hobuema. March 8th 1897.
Sir,

I have the honour to send you, with the present letter, the plans for the new building for boarding school in the Hobema agency, and also the specifications and estimates, as required in your circular No. 15, dated March 8th.

You will be easily convinced that to make a proper construction for less than $5,000, is scarcely possible. Therefore, we hope the Department will be so kind as to add $2,500 to the first sum already voted, in order not to delay the complete termination of this building, of which we are so much in want.

The exterior plan herein will be performed faithfully, except the kitchen, which is to be inside, instead of behind, the new building. The dimensions for the large building are 50 x 49 ft., instead of 55 x 45, as shown on the plan; and for
for the kitchen, 25 x 18.

Persuaded you will take our demand into consideration, I expect, with great anxiety, the sum already granted.

Yours,

[Signature]

Principal.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to the second paragraph 117201-6. of Departmental letter of the 25th October last, and to enclose herewith a plan of the proposed new Roman Catholic boarding school on Erminskin's Reserve, in the Hobbs Agency, with a statement of the estimated cost of the same. The management is being told that no more than the $2500.00 provided can be had in the way of aid from the Department, and that unless the church authorities are willing to meet any expenditure in excess of that amount, the plans must be so modified accordingly, if it is desired to secure the $2500.00 available, also that the expenditure must be incurred before the 30th June next.

I have the honour to be,

OTTAWA 8th May 1907

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th inst.; and in reply to say that no further grant can be made for the proposed new R.C. Boarding school on Brinskin's Reserve; and that the management will as advised by you, have to confine themselves to the $200 already available, or meet extra expenses themselves.

Sir,

With reference to your letter No. II2-1-5, dated the 13th instant, and to the kitchen range, bake oven, bread mixer and repairs asked for by the Rev. Principal of Ermineskin's Residential School. I have the honor to report as follows:

The kitchen range in use at present is very much out of repair, and is too small for the number in attendance. The old bake oven was torn away when the new addition was put on the school building two years ago and has never been replaced. The school has never been supplied with a bread mixer. I would consider the above three items very necessary and recommend the purchase.

The stairs leading to, and the floors of the girl dormitories are in a bad state of repair and will require immediate attention. Regarding the floor for the boys' dining room, I might say that this room is in the basement of the new part of school building, the present floor is of cement and the objection to this is, that it becomes very dusty with many feet tramping over it.

The Rev. Principal intimated to me, that if the materials were supplied for the floors etc., the Rev. Sisters would undertake to look after the labour, and also the installation of the range, oven etc.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, November 3, 1926.

Sir:

I wish to refer to your 404-11A of the 5th ultimo, enclosing a communication from the Rev. Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. You are authorized to purchase a kitchen range and deliver it to the school without delay. You should also arrange for and forward to the girls' dormitories, 44 ft. x 50 ft., or similar size, to renew the staircase leading to the girls' dormitories, 8 ft. wide. The provision of a bake oven will be necessary at the other improvements requested by the school will provide all the labour.

Your obedient servant,

D. McLean,
Deputy Secretary.
Ottawa, November 5, 1926.

Sir:

I have your No. 7 of the 26th ultimo, with reference to improvements at the Ermineskins Indian Residential School. I am today authorizing Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham to purchase a kitchen range and flooring and stairs for the girls' dormitories. The provision of a bake oven and bread mixer will have to stand for the time being, as our funds are extremely limited.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. G. Askey, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.
Sir:

In July, 1925, under Department authority 112-1-5, authority was given to expend $6000.00 on a Laundry and equipment at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School; of this amount $3650.00 were expended.

On a recent visit to this school I found that the roof of the laundry building was sagging and in danger, in time, of collapsing and I requested the Agent to ascertain what would be the cost of furnishing truss rods. He informs me that the cost of material and labour for one truss rod would be $32.00, but after carefully going over the building suggests that it would be more satisfactory to rebuild the roof at a cost of about $100, and if advisable, to furnish a truss rod also, which would entail a total cost of approximately $138.00 and I beg to recommend this expenditure and shall be glad to receive authority to incur it.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, December 7th, 1926.

Sir:

I have your No. 404-11A of the 2nd instant, reporting on the condition of the roof of the laundry building at the Ermineaskin's Indian Residential School.

The Department will approve of an expenditure of approximately $135.00 in having the roof rebuilt and a truss rod supplied, and you may arrange to have the work required to the roof of this building carried out.

Please forward properly certified vouchers in the usual manner covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Ottawa, April 9th, 1927.

Madam:

The Rev. Principal of the Ermineskin's Indian Residential School requested that a bake oven be supplied. The type of oven we usually supply is that manufactured by Jean J. Dacust, Limited, St. Boniface, and this firm inform us that their No. 3 and No. 4 bake ovens have a capacity of 42 and 63 square feet baking space, respectively, and will bake from 4 to 5 pounds of bread per square foot according to the size of the pans used. I shall be pleased if you will inform the Department as early as possible as to whether you require a No. 3 or No. 4 oven to meet the requirements at this school.

I may say that the width of the door space necessary to admit either a No. 3 or No. 4 oven is 39 inches. You should state whether the door through which this oven would have to be taken into the building would admit the oven, and, if not, please state definitely the exact width of the door space. Should there be any difficulty as to the width of the door, the above firm state that they can make an oven to meet requirements in this respect, having the same capacity as mentioned above.

When we have the information asked for above, an order will be placed for the supplying of an oven.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Sister Superior,
Ermineskin's Indian Res. School,
Hobbema, Alta.
Hobbema, Alberta,
April 15th, 1927.

J. D. Mclean, Esq.,
Acting Deputy and Secretary,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of yours of the 8th instant in connection with the Bake Oven which the Rev. Principal of Brindeskin's Residential School had requested be supplied.

We are deeply grateful to the Department for the kind consideration they have given this request, and words are inadequate to express our thanks for their sanctioning it.

I must state, however, that we had anticipated getting a larger one as it is considered that the No4 oven manufactured by the J.J. Daoust would be rather small to meet our actual requirements. Besides, the number of pupils is steadily increasing, and we are, even now, looking eagerly forward to the time when the Department will put up a larger school for us.

The door through which the oven would have to be taken into is 32 inches, and there is an opening of 42' by 26' in the bakery.

We have lately visited a school where they had an oven which had a capacity of 156 square feet of baking space. Now, if this can not be supplied can we hope to obtain one having a capacity of, at least, 144 square ft. of baking space?

With renewed thanks for this and all past favors,

I remain

yours very truly,

Acting Principal.
Ottawa, April 22nd, 1927.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, relative to the size of the bake oven required for the use of the Ermineskin's Indian Residential School. I may say that the No. 4 oven manufactured by Jean J. Daoust, Limited, St. Boniface, has an average capacity of approximately 350 pounds of bread at each baking. Please state as soon as possible what quantity of bread you require at each baking for the needs of this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Sister Superior,
Ermineskin's Indian Res. School,
Hobbema, Alta.
Hobbema, Alberta

April 22nd, 1927.

J. D. McLean Esq.,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of the 22nd instant, relative to the size of the bake oven we requested. I must say that we need one having an average capacity of approximately 500 to 600 pounds of bread. This would mean that we would have to bake twice weekly for our actual needs, but oftener as the number of pupils increase. A smaller oven would necessitate baking every day, reason for which we request a larger one, and we hope it will be granted,

Thanking you for your kind and prompt attention in this matter, I remain

Yours very truly,

Acting Principal
Ottawa, May 15th, 1927.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 22nd ultimo, relative to the size of the bake oven required for the use of the Ermineskin's Indian Residential School. The Department has given this letter careful consideration, and we regret that we have not sufficient information to enable us to place the order for a suitable oven. I would point out that it would take considerable floor space in the bakery for an oven having the capacity which you require. Please state definitely the exact dimensions of the floor space in the bakery or other place where you propose to install the oven, also repeat the exact width of the doors through which this oven would have to be taken.

I may say that in other schools having approximately the same enrolment and staff as at your school, we have supplied the No. 4 "Economy" oven, which has a capacity of from 350 to 400 pounds of bread each baking, and this oven has proved satisfactory to the schools in which it is used. Having in view the width of the door space necessary to admit a larger oven, and the floor space required for the placing of same, and also the number of pupils and staff in residence, the Department does not understand why in the case of your school an oven having a capacity of 350 to 400 pounds of bread per baking would not be of sufficient size to meet your requirements.

Please give further information as to the space available for the placing of the oven and the exact width of the doors through which it would have to be taken.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Sister Superior,
Ermineskin's Indian Res. School,
Hobbema, Alta.

MODEL K.

Baking Surface ................................................................. 135 square feet

This large bread oven has a capacity equal to the largest brick oven—a comparison of price is distinctly in favour of the Hubbard Oven—it requires only half the floor space—it is easily moved from one location to another—and has a high resale value. The top and base are made in two parts, and any part will pass through a common doorway. There is a cooling damper to regulate the heat and carry off the bread gas.

Heated with two oblong shaped furnaces, firepot 30" long, firing door 6" x 12", outer furnace doors insulated make work pleasant.

The baking decks for stock ovens are level, but they will be supplied with a rise of six inches to the back if desired, for one or both decks.

Electric or gas oven lights can be supplied as an extra, when specified, for any oven.

These larger ovens are built for bread baking, they are heavy and strong, the walls are insulated with 4" thickness of mineral wool.

Four doors make it easy to reach every position, and two men may be engaged at one time to load or peel the oven quickly.

Electric or gas oven lights can be supplied as an extra, when specified for any oven.

The top and base are made in two parts for ease in handling, and no part is too large to go through a common doorway. There is a cooling damper to regulate the heat, and carry off the bread gas through the chimney.

Heated with two oblong shaped furnaces, the fire pot for model G. is 18" long, model H. 24" long, the fire door is 6 x 12, the outer furnace doors are insulated, and being detached from the ash door remain closed to prevent loss of heat.
