May 22nd, 1927.

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:-

In connection with bake oven required for use of our school, I beg to state that the one we had set our minds on obtaining was as model herewith enclosed: having two baking decks, thus taking less floor space; with top and base made in two parts, enabling it to pass through a common doorway.

The reason for our choice of this type of oven, is, that we would need to bake but twice weekly, whereas with the No.4 Economy we would be obliged to bake four times, and oftener yet, as the number of pupils increases.

The amount of bread consumed at our school is, from 1100 to 1200 pounds weekly.

If the Department should consider it best to supply us with the No.4 Economy they may disregard our wish, and they may be sure that we shall be very grateful for whichever they may see fit to accommodate us with.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Acting Principal.
Ottawa, June 1, 1927.

Ovens may be finished in aluminum or black with nickeled fittings, and have a pleasing appearance. Other finishes may be had on application.

Even the largest oven can be set up in a day and ready for use. There is no fitting to be done. Every section goes together in its place. You simply cement the sections as you place them and bolt them together.

The ovens shown in this catalogue are stock sizes. Other sizes will be built to meet local conditions, if requested. The doors will be supplied in any size to meet your particular need.

Any Hubbard Oven may be purchased on a small first payment, and the balance paid in monthly instalments. Price lists and terms of sale are shown separately and reprinted as market conditions make changes necessary.

The Hubbard oven is so well known it has a high resale value and if you should wish to sell the oven or dispose of your business at any time, you can always find a ready buyer. They pass from one baker to another and command a good price, even after years of use.

The small ovens are always carried in stock. Large ovens are assembled for orders and one week is usually sufficient notice to ensure prompt shipment.

Undoubtedly there are questions which will come to the mind of the reader which we cannot anticipate, and we shall gladly reply in detail to any subjects which are not set out here.

Ottawa, June 7, 1927.

Gentlemen:

Referring to your letter of April 4th, last, quoting a price for the supplying of your "Economy" Oven special, f. o. b. Hobbema, Alta., I now have to inform you that, after making enquiry as to the door space, etc., available for the installation of the oven, it has been decided to accept your offer for your No. 4 special oven, at the price quoted, viz.: $417.50, f. o. b. Hobbema.

This oven is for the use of the Ermineskins Indian Residential School and we are informed by the Rev. Sister superior that the door in the building, through which the oven will have to be taken, is 32" wide and that the opening into the bakery is 42" x 26". It may be necessary for you to make up a special oven of the capacity of your No. 4, to go through the space available, or it may be that you can arrange to ship the oven in sections and it could be set up at the school. I shall be pleased if you will communicate with the Rev. Sister Superior, Ermineskins Indian Residential School, and ascertain definitely from her the space available for taking this oven into the building. After receiving this information, please forward, addressed to the Rev. Sister, Hobbema, Alta., an oven of the No. 4 special size.

Your account covering the cost should be forwarded to Mr. W. G. Askey, Indian Agent, Hobbema, Alta., who is being informed of the order placed with you and requested to certify the account and send it to the Department when the oven is received.

I shall be pleased to hear from you after you have communicated with the Rev. Sister Superior in the matter.

Yours truly,

21. Natural Gas May be Used as Fuel.

Natural gas may be used as a fuel in any Hubbard oven. The coal oven is particularly well adapted for natural gas because the enclosed system of flues carries off any bad odor through the chimney. Ovens for manufactured gas are illustrated in the back pages.

22. Heating with Oil.

There are many companies offering oil burners for heating the house or building. Any of these systems may be used in the Hubbard coal oven, or we can supply the burners and equipment with the oven. It is a convenience to place the furnace at the back, if the oven is to be heated with oil.

23. Capacity of Ovens.

The capacity in loaves is estimated. To say the oven had a given capacity without stating the size of the pan would be misleading. The dimensions of each baking deck is given under the illustration and you may easily determine the capacity of the oven by measuring the pan you will use or frame of pans. Therefore, any comparison of ovens should be by the square feet of baking surface—never by the number of loaves.

24. Built-in Convenient Sections for Assembling.

The ovens are built in sections. They are fully assembled and knocked down for shipping. No section is too large for ease in handling and will pass through a common doorway.

25. Fire Proof Base.

The oven stands on legs and may be placed without danger on a wood floor. Only a mat is required in front of the furnace to receive any hot coals that might fall when removing the ashes. The legs are 3" high and if the oven is placed on a brick or cement base, it will be supplied without legs.

26. Solidity without Excessive Weight.

The ovens are heavy and solidly built, yet not too heavy to be placed in any building of very ordinary construction, weighing about 125 pounds to the square foot.

This larger door will be supplied where wood only is used for firing the oven.

June 14th, 1927.

F. H. Page, Esq., Accountant & Purchasing Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

We have your letter advising us that an oven has been purchased for shipment to Hobbema.

We regret losing this business, and would like to inquire, if we may do so without seeming presumptuous, if you purchased an oven of the same capacity for less money than we offered you the Hubbard oven for. We are prompted to ask the question because the model H oven has a rated capacity of about 300 loaves. Other manufacturers offer an oven of the same capacity for less money, but the oven is actually smaller, as you would readily see if the comparison were made by the square foot of baking surface.

The capacity, of course, is determined by the size of the pan used, and we fear that we have placed ourselves at a disadvantage. You will see that it is a matter of vital importance to us to know if you have made your selection on the rated capacity of the oven, or by the number of square feet of baking surface. This has been done before, and if possible we want to find a way to avoid a recurrence, because we are losing business that goes to others, as their price seems to be lower, but the comparison is an unfair one, both to ourselves and to our customer.

Yours very truly,

HUBBARD PORTABLE OVEN COMPANY LIMITED.

We are very grateful to the Department for the Bread Mixer and we greatly appreciate all the past favours it is why we are most confident that the present request we lay before you will also be taken into consideration.

The desks in one of our class-rooms are very old, it often happens that some of them are broken and cannot be repaired. There are such desks in another class-room (Primary) but not so old; we could replace the older ones by the latter and ask your approval for another set of desks for the Primary Grade. We have extracted page 10 from the Western School Supply Catalog which illustrates the desks no. 25 and 26. We need 12 of each number, that is 24 desks in all for four rows in a room 22x26x11.

Ermineskin Residential School,
Hobbema, Alta., October 16, 1928.

Honorable Duncan Scott,
Deputy Supt. Gen. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Honorable Sir,

In the past, a few times we have been favored with some extra grants from the Indian Department, for the improvement of the Ermineskin Residential School. For those we are indebted towards you and the officers of the Department to a very deep gratefulness.

This coming year, we would like again to be the recipient of some such favors.

We would like very much to have a Knitting Machine; we know that P.T. Legare from Quebec has some in stock for $55.00. As we have quite a number of pupils, we find it hard to make all our supply by hand work.

Many of our straw-beds are worn out; we had received a good number of them from the Department a few years ago. Would it be possible to send us 4 dozen of such straw-beds, so as to enable us to replace those that are now worthless?

For the past years, we had a very poor chicken house, parts of old barns joined together but giving very poor shelter to the chickens and every day less satisfactory. Could we not have a certain grant for building a new chicken-house? It would cost approximately $700.00 or $800.00

With the hope to see our requests granted,

I remain, honorable Sir,

[Signature]

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK. February 23rd, 1929

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the Ermineskin R.C. Indian Residential School, in the Hobbema Agency, which was recently visited by Mr. Inspector Christianson.

You will note that the fire protection at this school appears to be in good order, and in my opinion it is well that it is, because this is a building that requires extra precautions taken in the way of fire protection. The school has, of course, been found in its usual good order. I doubt whether there is accommodation here for 200 children or not. You will note the Principal states that there is. This school has always been favourably reported upon.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that while making an inspection of the Hobbema Agency, I also visited the Ermineskin R.C. Boarding School, and am glad to report that this institution is doing excellent work, not only in the school, but also in the community in which it is situated. There are 120 grant earning children in the school, and at the time I was there 123 children were enrolled. The Principal explained that he always carried 2 or 3 extra as he has so many on the waiting list that he is sometimes obliged to take an odd one in without getting the grant for it.

I visited all the classrooms and was well impressed with the work that is carried on there. One girl is in Grade 8 and it is the intention of the school authorities to get her into high school next year. However, I will not enlarge on the classroom work at all as this school was inspected by the Public School Inspector on November 15th last.

I would just like to say that I checked up on the meals, etc., as I was so impressed with the healthy appearance of the children, and I consider that they are certainly well cared for. They are well clothed and well fed. Besides the regular three meals a day, they all get a good lunch at 4 o'clock when they come out of the classroom.

As usual

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
As usual, the school was spotless from top to bottom. You know what the building is like. The old part is getting the worse for wear and if school is to be carried on for some years in this building, a lot of repairs will have to be made, but the Principal is in hopes of the Department building a new school in the near future, and he informed me that if he had the room he could get 200 children. However, I informed him that I knew nothing about the Department's intentions with regard to a new school being built.

There are 12 cows kept at the school. At the time of my visit they were milking 4, but some of the others were due to freshen in the near future. Very little land is farmed, but an excellent garden is grown at the school.

Regarding fire protection, in my report dated February 14th, 1928, I gave a full explanation of the fire escapes and apparatus. I found this all in good order. Fire extinguishers had all been re-filled and tested during last month. A regular fire drill is carried out from time to time and in the summer time generally every week, and every little while Mr. Askey goes up to the school in the evening to conduct the fire drill himself so, as far as I could see, every precaution is being taken against fire.

In conclusion I wish to state that I am always well impressed with this institution. Father Moulin, the Principal, is a splendid example of what a Missionary on an Indian reserve should be. If there is sickness he drives night and day. The best of feeling exists between the school and the Agency, which is the way
way it should be. This, as you are aware, is sometimes hard to bring about.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, March 1st, 1929.

Sir,

I have your No. 404-11 of the 23rd ultimo enclosing the report of Mr. Inspector Christianson on his recent inspection of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. In this connection, the Department is pleased to note that this school is doing excellent work, also, that the pupils are all in a good state of health and that the general conditions are satisfactory. I note that there is proper fire protection and that fire drill is practised regularly.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, May 6, 1929.

Sir:

The Reverend Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School has urged the Department to replace the old hen house, and I should be grateful if you would let me have a report and recommendation in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Your obedient servant,

Ermineskin Residential School,
Hobema, Alta., December 29, 1929.

To the Superintendent of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

Sir,

A few weeks ago, Right Reverend J. Guy, advised us to forward to you, if possible in duplicate, our bills for the new installation of Electric Light by the Calgary Power Co. He said that he had a great hope to see these bills refunded to us by the Indian Department, which bills we are enclosing. You will note that the motor has not yet been purchased; we shall take the 5 H.P. motor marked $104.53 from the O'Neill Motor Co., it will be sufficient to pump water and to work the laundry machines.

It was a necessary improvement as our old engine and batteries were in very bad condition after many years of service.

We have been favored in the past years with such help from the Indian Department, for which we cannot adequately express our gratitude; we certainly would be very grateful if you could again come to our assistance.

I remain,

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
Principal
Ottawa, January 7, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, enclosing accounts in connection with the installation of electric light at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. I regret to state, in reply, that there has been unusually heavy expenditure from the Vote for Indian Education for the last few months, and there are therefore no funds for the purpose of assisting you in this improvement.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. P. P. Moulin, O. M. I.,
Principal,
Ermineskin Indian Res. School,
Hebema,
Alta.
Ottawa, April 16, 1930.

Sir:

Pursuant to the Deputy Superintendent General's letter to you of yesterday's date, I am instructed to have you arrange for the services of a night watchman at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. The Department will allow a grant of $40 a month for this service and considers that the school should be responsible for the man's board. The watchman should be chosen with care and must be a thoroughly reliable person, who will make continuous patrol of the main building at night. Vouchers in this connection should be forwarded once every quarter and should be in favour of the Principal, who will pay the night watchman. Please make the arrangements without delay.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:-

Referring to Department's letter No. 112-1-1, of the 16th April last, I now wish to make application for authority to purchase a night watchman's clock, and a fire alarm bell for use at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, in order to obtain the proper service from the newly appointed Night Watchman, Mr. Hector Nault, who has been engaged on your authority.

I have instructed the Agent to make inquiries as to the cost of erecting two iron fire escapes. When this information is received shall again communicate with you.

Your obedient servant,

W. W. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 16, 1930.

Sir:

I have your 404-11 of the 10th instant, requesting authority to purchase a night watchman's clock and fire alarm bell for use in the Ermineskin Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of a suitable fire alarm bell. The school authorities could, no doubt, arrange for any installation required without expense to the Department. If you consider that a night watchman's clock would be really necessary, you may also purchase same.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
April 15, 1930.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 404-11A R.C. of the 12th instant, with reference to the Ermineskin Indian Residential school.

At a later date, we will have to give serious consideration to the question of a new building at this point. When you write the Principal, you should emphasize the Department's wishes concerning fire drill and fire prevention. Neither Mr. Murison nor yourself state that additional fire escapes are required, so I presume that no action in this connection is necessary.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Dear Mr. Scott,

With further reference to my letter of 12th ultimo and your reply of the 15th idem, 112-1-1, I beg to say I have secured a quotation from the Edmonton Iron Fence and Wire Works for two fire escapes of the kind erected at Edmonton Residential School and at one of the schools at Onion Lake, to be erected at Ermineskin School, one at each end of the building. They are willing to fit two new doors with casings and locks and remove one radiator and erect the two escapes with poles complete for $440.50 plus sales tax.

I beg to recommend that their offer be accepted as the old building is nothing but a fire trap. At any time we decide to raze the building the fire escapes would be part of the salvage and could be erected elsewhere.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner

the railroad: Calgary to Edmonton; it is only 1 mile from the station.

Our deep well 245 feet if enlarged to 4 or 6 inches would give an abundant supply of good and soft water.

The Roman Catholic Corporation and the Rev. Sisters of the Assumption who have practically built the actual School agree not to ask any indemnity for these buildings if the Indian Department builds such a good school as the one on the Blood Reserve or the one built now at St. Paul de Metis.

Secondly: for the good renown of the Department as we have quite often visitors inquiring into our work: as this summer: 4 parties from the United States: 3 visitors from Ceylon: The Scouts of France with M. Ermineskin Residential School
Hobbema - Alta

5th Sept., 1930

Dear Sir,

Three times in the past we built additions to our Residential School: in 1914, 1922, and 1929; and even now we can not find place for all the pupils we could have from the Reserve at Hobbema Indian Agency.

The buildings are of painted and repainted wood, some parts dating back to 1876 so there is always great danger of fire.

I give here my most sincere thanks to the Indian Department who granted us last May a night watchman. We recently engaged a man who is giving all his attention and heart to his work.

Now could I say that it would be quite a credit to the Indian Department to build a new and all modern school.

The same place or near seems to be ideal in many ways; it is not far from the Indian agency; only ½ mile and at about the same distance from
Ottawa, September 9, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to a new main building for the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. The Department knows that the old building is far from satisfactory, and, when plans for the future are being determined, your request will receive consideration.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Form No. 101
Ermineskin Residential School,
Hobbema, Oct. 15th, 1931.

Mr. Russel Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Twice in the last years we have called the attention of the Indian Department on the necessity of having a new and larger building to replace our old Ermineskin school.

In September last, we were answered that "when plans for the future are being determined, your request will receive consideration."

Although, it seems, times are not in a way very propitious, nevertheless again we ask you respectfully to consider our urgent need of an up-to-date school as the one built recently at St. Paul.

May we say, it would be a relief to many who would find work at this building, and it may be also economical to the Indian Department as at present material and work are cheaper.
If impossible for the next year to have the school we would ask the Indian Department to give us some assistance to renew one of the floors in our old building.

Boys' refectory, Size 30x 60

2 staircases 15 steps each staircase and 2 1/2 feet wide.

Some assistance to repair an old stable so that we may have more place for a larger live stock.

One sulky plough, as requested last year and again much needed.

We need also very much:

One Reversible Blackboard with Stand, Size 3 x 6.

Pending the building of the New School, we ask the Indian Department to grant us authorization for five more pupils, that is to have the grant for 145 instead of as now for only 140. Last year we had always more pupils than the number authorized for.

With the hope that all our requests will receive a favorable answer,

We remain,

Dear Sir,
Yours very truly.

P. Moulin,
Principal.
Missionnaires Oblats de Marie Immaculée
Administration Provinciale
9916 - 110e Avenue
Edmonton - Alberta

October 28, 1931

Mr Russell Ferrier
Supt of Indian Education
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have been visiting lately the Erminskin Residential School and I am prone to endorse the plea of the Principal of that School for a larger, more modern and fire proof building. The actual School is too small to accommodate all the children of school-age, and besides it is a perpetual fire-trap that may at any time play havoc with the staff and the children. They have now a night watchman and the pupils seem to have very good spirit, but one never knows when the fire-bug will get hold of those small Indians.

We spoke together already a few times about the need of a new fire-proof school at Erminskin, but allow me once more to lay much stress on the subject.

In the mean time and to promote furthermore the good work done by the actual School, I recommend to your benevolent attention the other few items mentioned in the Principal's letter.

Yours truly,

A. Langlois O.M.I.
Provincial
Ottawa, November 4, 1931.

Very Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with enclosure, concerning the needs at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. I have made a note for consideration when estimates are being prepared. Until such time as a new building can be provided, every energy should be directed towards safeguarding the staff and pupils in the event of fire. Constant watchfulness and regular organized fire drill are absolutely essential.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Very Rev. U. Langleis, O.M.I.,
Oblate Fathers' Provincial House,
9916 - 110th St.,
Edmonton, Alta.

AGENT'S REPORT

Respecting the Ermineskin Indian Residential School

For the month of December 1931

ROUTINE

At the time of my visit there were:

- 122 pupils in the classrooms.
- Are the classroom registers kept up to date? Yes.
- 7 pupils in vocational training departments.
- 1 pupil sick.
- Pupils absent. Reasons: One truant.

Total number on roll: 140

Are there any pupils in residence whose admission has not been approved by the Department?

No

HEALTH, SANITATION, Etc.

Appearance of pupils: Well fed and happy.
Cleanliness of school: Spotless.
Appearance of school grounds: Snow.
Care of the sick: Intelligent and kindly.
The children's meals: Wholesome and plentiful.
Fire drill, escapes and protection: Inspected them good condition.

VOCATIONAL TRAINING

Domestic Instruction: Three girls learning to cook.
Instruction in Farming and Gardening:
Training in the care of live stock: Five boys help milk.
Manual training: All.
Care of agricultural machinery and other equipment: All.

GENERAL

Discipline at the school: Good.
Efficiency of the staff: Excellent.
General management: Patient, firm and sound.

Suggestions: Stairway cover used at night should be removed & a gate placed at top of stairs to stop children falling down stairs; this is a fire trap danger, if the bolts got caught.

Indian Agent

Form No. 217
Sir:

I enclose the report of his visit to the Ermineskin Indian Residential School in December by the Indian Agent at Hohema. You will note his remarks under the head of "Suggestions" at the foot of the report. I think Colonel Palmer is right in that what he refers to as a cover over the stairway should be removed at once and a railing, and a gate if necessary, set up to enclose the well of the staircase. If you approve of this and will advise me, I will take steps to have the alteration effected.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Ottawa, January 16, 1932.

Sir:

I have your HON-11 of the 11th instant, enclosing the report of Mr. Agent Palmer for the month of December last, on his inspection of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School.

With reference to the Agent's suggestion regarding the cover of the stairway, I have to say that you may arrange with the school authorities to have this cover removed at once and a railing and gate, if necessary, set up to enclose the well of the staircase.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., January 14th, 1932.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a copy of an official letter which I have received from Indian Agent Palmer this morning. You will notice that he has purchased candy for the Ermineskin Residential School and Mission on the Samson Reserve. In the first place, he had no right spending this amount without first securing the proper authority. I would not do it myself. I think Col. Palmer should be told that he should at least receive authority before making purchases.

Kindly advise what is to be done in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, January 20, 1932.

Sir:

I have your 404-40 of the 14th instant, enclosing copy of a communication which you received from Mr. Agent Palmer, Hobblema, Alta., with reference to reimbursement for the purchase of a pail of candy for the Christmas trees at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School and at the mission on the Samson's Reserve.

In this connection I have to say that it is not the policy of the Department to provide grants for Christmas treats to the pupils of Indian residential schools and missions, and Mr. Agent Palmer will have to be responsible for payment.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Form No. 101
Ermineskin Residential School

In Case of Fire

(1) Each Sister in charge of a Dormitory will make a list (in Duplicate) of the names of all Children in the Dormitory. The second copy to be given to Rev Father Moulin. This list will be revised each month.

(2) When the Fire Alarm is sounded: Sisters in charge of a Dormitory have one Duty only, That is to see that all children get out of the Dormitory. When the Children are out of the building, call the Roll and check the names, and report to the Rev Father.

(3) Sisters in charge of a Dormitory must not attempt to fight Fire.

(4) The Farmer and Night Watchman can attack the fire, after the Alarm has been given, NO CHILDREN TO BE USED IN THIS WORK.

(5) The Rev Mother and Sisters have only one duty, that is to get the children out of the building, check over the lists, and hold them together in some safe place, until arrangements have been made for their welfare.

Each dormitory should previously arrange where the children should assemble, the spot should be known to the Children.

(6) Rev Father will detail a Lay Brother or Sister to ring the Alarm on the Church Bell, and detail one of the bigger boys to call the Agent and Interpreter. Then he should proceed to personally check the list of names WITH each Sister in charge of a Dormitory.

(7) The Rev Mother will check the list OF SISTERS AND LAY HELP, that may be living at the school.

R.H. Palmer
Indian Agent
AGENT'S REPORT

Respecting the Ermineskin Indian Residential School
For the month of March 1932

ROUTINE

At the time of my visit there were:
- 174 pupils in the classrooms.
- Are the classroom registers kept up to date? Yes
- 6 pupils in vocational training departments.
- 6 pupils sick.
- 6 pupils absent. Reasons: at home unwell
- Total number on roll: 144

Are there any pupils in residence whose admission has not been approved by the Department?
Yes Wilfred Buffalo

HEALTH, SANITATION, Etc.

Appearance of pupils: Happy
Cleanliness of school: Spotless
Appearance of school grounds: Spring thaw made it look bad
Care of the sick: Excellent
The children's meals: Well cooked and plentiful
Fire drill, escapes and protection: I looked over escapes...and had 2 alarms, one at night, in both cases everything worked well.

VOCATIONAL TRAINING

Attached is a copy of Instructions issued by myself And I would appreciate your criticisms on it.

Domestic Instruction: 4 girls cooking
Instruction in Farming and Gardening:
Training in the care of live stock: 4 boys milking
Manual training:
Care of agricultural machinery and other equipment:

GENERAL

Discipline at the school: Stiff but kindly
Efficiency of the staff: Very good
General management: Sound

Suggestions

Form No. 217
Ottawa, April 11, 1932.

Sir:

I have your report on your inspection of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School during the month of March, last, together with a copy of the instructions issued by you to the school authorities, setting forth the action to be taken by the staff in case of fire.

The Department approves of the instructions which you issued regarding the duties of the staff. Your orders, in conjunction with the official instructions to Principals of Indian Residential Schools, dated February 5th, last, should be sufficient guide as to the action to be taken in case of fire and the prevention of same as well as the proper oversight of fire equipment. In your regular visits to the school, you should see that the instructions issued are carried out by the Principal and staff.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, June 14th, 1932.

Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 6th instant, I beg to say that, while the Department supplied the watchman's clock for the Ermineskins Indian Residential School, also a supply of record forms, it is expected that additional supplies of these forms will be secured by the school management and paid for by them.

The clock for the Ermineskins Residential School was purchased from England's Jewelry Store Ltd., 1776 Hamilton Street, Regina, Sask., and, if you write to this firm, they will, no doubt, be able to secure the additional record forms that you require.

The sample which you enclosed with your letter is returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

HOBEMA, Aug.27, 1932.

To the Secretary
Dep. of Indian affairs.
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir,

Some three weeks ago I wrote to you about the cheque at the school being overdue...and also the cheque overdue for our night watchman...months of April, May, June.

The first cheque allowance for the school was received a day or two before your answer...but the other for the services of Mr. Geo. Rogier has not yet been received... His salary is due for 5 months.

If your intention is that we dispense with the services of a night watchman in the future, I hope that you will notify me.

I will regret it specially at the moment the children are coming back to school, at the beginning of the cold season and as you can well understand it when we have in our building 150 and 150 children, some of a very young age.

I remain, Dear Sir,
Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

It is our intention to continue the grant of $40 a month towards the night watchman's salary.

To the Secretary
Indian Dept.
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

We beg respectfully from the Ind. Dept. to give us some material for the School as follow:

6 desks complete,
6 front desks,
2 backs.

All of the same size i.e., for pupils 5 to 7 years old. Table Red color, seats and backs wood color, only varnish, to match those we have already in our class room.

Also, one (1) Primary Arithmetic Chart, as in catalogue of the Western School Supply Co., Ltd., No. 206.

We would appreciate very much also if the Ind. Dept. could send us some games for the children, most especially an outfit for baseball, boys 15 to 17.

With hope that our demands will receive a favorable reply. We remain, Dear Sir,

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal
